topics.topicName: 1.1 Introduction
topics.content:
1. Introduction To GMAT Reading Comprehension

1.1 Introduction

Strong reading skills are a significant asset for anyone taking the GMAT. So, it should come as no surprise then that most people who earn high GMAT scores are strong readers. Therefore, although becoming a strong reader may take time and effort, the investment you make in yourself will return big dividends in your GMAT score.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

Although becoming a strong reader may take time and effort, the investment you make in yourself will return big dividends in your GMAT score, as well as beyond.

In the modules that follow, you’ll master the knowledge, skills, strategies, and techniques that will liberate your Reading Comprehension performance; after completing them, you’ll be armed with the skills necessary to correctly answer every Reading Comprehension question you face on test day.

However, to build these necessary skills, many of you will require a deep mindset shift in the way you think about and train for reading comp, because many of you have either not devoted the time necessary to mastering Reading Comprehension or practiced endlessly without ever learning how to do things correctly – or worse – you’ve learned gimmicky, bankrupt Reading Comprehension strategies, which are almost certainly holding down your score.

From this point onward, we’re doing things the right way, the TTP way …

Let’s begin by discussing the mindset necessary for mastering Reading Comprehension.

topics.topicName: 1.2 Developing the Winning Reading Comprehension Mindset
topics.content:
1. Introduction To GMAT Reading Comprehension

1.2 Developing the Winning Reading Comprehension Mindset

Most, if not all, people can perform at a high level on Reading Comprehension. However, the way in which people tend to prepare for this section almost guarantees that they won’t improve their RC skills.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

While preparing for the GMAT, many people actually go out of their way to almost guarantee that they will never improve their Reading Comprehension Scores.

This unfortunate phenomenon begins with a few pervasive misconceptions about Reading Comprehension. These are:

Losing Mindset: One’s performance in Reading Comprehension can’t be improved because reading ability is fixed.

Some believe the crazy idea that they won’t be able to improve in Reading Comprehension; they believe that their skills are fixed, so they don’t even try. They instead focus their efforts on improving their skills for other question types.

Winning TTP Mindset: The truth is that there is nothing mystical (or nefarious) about Reading Comprehension. Just as is the case with Quant or Critical Reasoning, we can absolutely improve our Reading Comprehension scores by developing knowledge, skills, and strategies, and through proper practice. We must have faith that our work will pay off.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

We can absolutely improve our Reading Comprehension scores by developing the necessary knowledge, skills, and strategies, and through proper practice.

Losing Mindset: There is nothing specific that one can learn in order to master Reading Comprehension, so people just need to keep practicing it.

Other people believe that there is no specific knowledge or skills that must be learned in the pursuit of strong Reading Comprehension scores. These people have the idea that the way to improve is just to practice.

These are the people who tend to practice passage after passage with no improvement whatsoever. In doing so, these people exemplify the “definition of insanity,” which is doing the same things again and again yet expecting a better outcome. Of course, because these people continue to do things incorrectly time after time, their Reading Comprehension scores never improve.

Winning TTP Mindset: The truth is that there is a great deal that we can learn that will help us to significantly improve our Reading Comprehension scores. In other words, people who earn high Reading Comprehension scores have acquired Reading Comprehension specific knowledge, strategies, and skills that others have not. We’re going to teach you all of these things … ;)

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

People who earn high Reading Comprehension scores have acquired Reading Comprehension specific knowledge, strategies, and skills that others have not.

Losing Mindset: I just don’t have enough time in the verbal section to complete all the Reading Comprehension questions, so I will skip through entire passages.

Because they are worried about time, some people skip one of the Reading Comprehension passages altogether (by clicking through the answer choices). Don’t make this mistake. Getting 3 to 4 questions wrong in a row (because you clicked through the answers) could potentially have a disastrous effect on your GMAT score.

Winning TTP Mindset: I’m going to train hard in all aspects of GMAT verbal to ensure that I CAN complete the verbal section on time. The good news is that, if you are following the TTP verbal study plan, you likely have greatly improved your Critical Reasoning skills, and your Reading Comprehension skills will be greatly improved after completing our Reading Comprehension course. With your greatly improved skills, there is no reason why you can’t complete the verbal section on time.

Losing Mindset: I excel in Reading Comprehension passages that interest me; however, I’m easily bored by passages that do not.

Some people completely “zone out” when they encounter subject matter that is not particularly interesting to them. They never discipline themselves to effectively handle any passages they face.

Winning TTP Mindset: The GMAT is just a few hours of my life. Regardless of the topic of the passage in front of me, I’m going to attack it with the vigor and interest necessary for getting all of the questions correct.

Losing Mindset: Reading Comprehension passages are too hard/dense to understand in the time allowed, so people must resort to tricks, hacks, and test-taking gimmicks.

Some other people believe that Reading Comprehension passages are too hard to understand in the time allowed, so they resort to a wide-range of gimmicky strategies that – let’s just be honest here – don’t work well.

So, if you were hoping to learn gimmicks that make you feel good yet probably fail miserably come test day, it might be time to enroll in another GMAT prep course. We don’t teach gimmicks at TTP; we teach things that work – period.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

We don’t teach gimmicks at TTP; we teach things that work – period.

What are some of these gimmicks that we see students using? See whether any sound familiar:

- Reading only the first and last sentences of each paragraph of a passage

- Reading only the first and last paragraphs of the passage

- Skimming the passage for the main idea

- Speed reading and other reading “hacks”

- Reading the first question before reading the passage

- Re-reading the passage multiple times

- “Pre-thinking” the answers to questions

- Eliminating all “extreme” answer choices

- Reading only the keywords in the passage

- Selecting answer choices simply because they use words that match words in the passage

- Add your gimmick here __________.

Winning TTP Mindset: You don’t need these gimmicks. We’re going to provide you with all of the content, skills, and strategies necessary to crush RC! You just need to provide the hard work, and together we’ll get you a GREAT score!!! Therefore, from this point forward your mindset must be one of complete mastery.

Let’s continue with a discussion of what GMAT Reading Comprehension tests.

topics.topicName: 1.3 What does GMAT Reading Comprehension Test?
topics.content:
1. Introduction To GMAT Reading Comprehension

1.3 What does GMAT Reading Comprehension Test?

In general, GMAT Reading Comprehension questions are designed to test how carefully we’ve read a passage, whether we understand what we’ve read and can accurately interpret the information given, and whether we can identify relationships between the ideas that are presented in the passage.

Why is Reading Comprehension tested on the GMAT? Well, the skills tested in Reading Comprehension are essential skills that you’ll need to be successful in business school and beyond. As an MBA student or business professional, you’ll often encounter scholarly writing similar to that found in GMAT Reading Comprehension passages. You’ll need to be proficient in reading and understanding this type of material. Thus, performing well in GMAT RC is one way to demonstrate to business schools that you’re prepared to handle some of the challenges you’ll face in an MBA program.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

In general, Reading Comprehension questions are designed to test how carefully we’ve read a passage, whether we understand what we’ve read, and whether we can identify relationships between the ideas that are presented in the passage.

But what does that all mean? We’re going to see that Reading Comprehension can be viewed through a five-part lens of understanding. The better we are at each level of this understanding, the better we’ll do. The levels of understanding are:

- Understanding the exact meanings of words

- Understanding the exact meanings of sentences

- Understanding the connections between sentences

- Understanding the main idea of each paragraph

- Understanding the connections among paragraphs

Understanding the exact meanings of words

Because words are the building blocks of sentences, our first level of reading comprehension comes from being aware of the words we encounter and understanding the meanings of these words in context.

For example, in Reading Comprehension passages, we’ll often encounter words and phrases, such as “however,” “only,” “despite,” “most,” “in contrast,” and “in conclusion.” All too often people either don’t pay close enough attention to these words and phrases, or when they do notice them, they don’t seek to develop a contextual understanding of them.

However, it’s important that we pay attention to these words and phrases because, when we understand the meaning of words, know how authors deploy words as tools, and pay close attention to the use of words in sentences, we are setting the stage for the deeper comprehension that comes at the sentence level.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

Because words are the building blocks of sentences, our foundational level of reading comprehension comes from being aware of and understanding the exact meanings of the words we encounter.

In the sections that follow, we’ll show you a bunch of skills that savvy readers use to notice and understand the words they encounter.

Understanding the exact meanings of sentences

Because sentences express the author’s complete thoughts, the next level of understanding comes at the sentence level. The best readers carefully digest each sentence, taking care to pause at multiple points in a sentence to summarize what the sentence has communicated. In other words, the best readers engage in an active approach to comprehending sentences. People who struggle with Reading Comprehension read sentences without ever gaining a full understanding of what these sentences communicate.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

The best readers carefully digest each sentence, taking care to pause at multiple points in a sentence to summarize what the sentence has communicated.

Of course, we’ll soon be discussing how to crush any sentence you encounter in a Reading Comprehension passage.

Understanding the connections between sentences

Next, because all of the sentences in a passage are interconnected, each sentence has a specific, important relationship with each of the other sentences. The best readers continuously seek to understand these interrelationships. They ask questions such as “Why is this sentence here?” “Why did the author take the time to include this sentence?” and “What is the role/purpose of this sentence?”

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

The best readers carefully connect the sentences in a passage.

In the sections that follow we’ll show you how to efficiently and effectively pull together each of the sentences in a passage.

Understanding the main idea of each paragraph

The best readers take the time and invest the energy to be sure that they completely understand the main idea of each paragraph they encounter. We’ll soon talk about how to summarize in a way such that the main ideas come to life for you.

Understanding the connections among paragraphs

The best readers seek to understand the purpose of each paragraph. By doing so, they’re able to put all of the pieces together and see how each paragraph fits together into the passage.

Of course, understanding what we read is valuable for many reasons. At the same time, the reason why understanding what we read is important in Reading Comprehension is that the path to RC success is not to seek to game the test; it’s to arrive at correct answers by understanding what we read.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

The path to RC success is to arrive at correct answers by understanding what we read.

Let’s now discuss how exactly Reading Comprehension is different from leisure reading.

topics.topicName: 1.4 Reading Comprehension is Different From Leisure Reading.
topics.content:
1. Introduction To GMAT Reading Comprehension

1.4 Reading Comprehension is Different From Leisure Reading.

Most people have read books, magazine articles, or other pieces of writing for the pure enjoyment of reading. Perhaps you read a few mystery novels each year or perhaps you enjoy reading the Sunday version of the New York Times.

This type of reading is wonderful, but we’re going to quickly see that leisure reading is very different from the type of reading that we’ll do for best results in Reading Comprehension. When reading leisurely, we may or may not be reading actively; we may or may not be fully engaged with the material. Think about sitting in a big comfortable chair on Sunday morning with a cup of coffee and a magazine or sitting in a lounge chair at the beach with a mystery novel. Probably not exactly reading gymnastics, right?

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

Leisure reading is wonderful, but we’re going to quickly see that leisure reading is very different from the type of reading that we’ll do for best results in GMAT Reading Comprehension.

We must approach GMAT Reading Comprehension with full engagement, as if it were a wrestling match with the passage. Whereas leisure reading is often downtime, we need to show up for Reading Comprehension and bring our A-game; we need to be prepared for some heavy lifting.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

Whereas leisure reading is often downtime, we need to show up for Reading Comprehension and bring our A-game; we need to be prepared for some heavy lifting.

So, whereas we could engage in leisure reading in a less-than-fully focused state of mind, we need to attack GMAT Reading Comprehension passages and understand that we must be “all in” when reading them. This advice applies when you’re practicing RC here in the TTP course, when you’re taking practice exams, and of course, on test day.

This theme will be one we underscore throughout the sections and chapters that follow.

Let’s now discuss how many RC questions we’ll see on the GMAT.

topics.topicName: 1.5 How Many Reading Comprehension Questions Are on the GMAT?
topics.content:
1. Introduction To GMAT Reading Comprehension

1.5 How Many Reading Comprehension Questions Are on the GMAT?

On the GMAT, Reading Comprehension questions are always presented in groups along with their associated passages, and we’re likely to see a total of 4 Reading Comprehension passages, each of which will typically have 3 or 4 associated questions. So, we’ll see a total of 12 to 14 Reading Comprehension questions. 

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

On the GMAT, we’re likely to see a total of 4 Reading Comprehension passages, each of which will typically have 3 or 4 associated questions, for a total of 12 to 14 Reading Comprehension questions.

Let’s now discuss the length of RC passages.

topics.topicName: 1.6 There Are Short and Long Reading Comprehension Passages.
topics.content:
1. Introduction To GMAT Reading Comprehension

1.6 There Are Short and Long Reading Comprehension Passages.

Reading Comprehension passages are classified as either “short” or “long.”

Short passages are generally made up of 1 to 2 paragraphs that run for fewer than 50 lines of text, for a total of about 200 to 250 words, although occasionally a short passage may be 3 paragraphs. Typically, though not always, short passages are accompanied by 3 questions.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

Short Reading Comprehension passages tend run for fewer than 50 lines of text on the computer screen and consist of 200 to 250 words in 1 or 2 paragraphs. Sometimes, however, a short passage may consist of 3 paragraphs.

A short Reading Comprehension passage tends to look like the following:

Long passages are generally composed of 3 to 4 paragraphs that run for more than 50 lines of text, for a total of more than 300 words, although occasionally a long passage may be 2 paragraphs. Typically, but not always, long passages are accompanied by 4 questions.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

Long Reading Comprehension passages tend to run for more than 50 lines of text on the computer screen and consist of more than 300 words in 2 to 4 paragraphs.

A long Reading Comprehension passage tends to look like the following:

Of the four Reading Comprehension passages that most people see when they take the GMAT, typically two to three of the passages are short, and one to two are long. However, it’s important to be prepared for whatever number of long and short passages we’re presented with.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

Of the four passages that most people see when they take the GMAT, typically two to three of the passages are short, and one to two are long.

The length of a Reading Comprehension passage is not indicative of its difficulty. Some long passages are hard to read, while some are easy. Similarly, some short passages are hard to read, while some are easy. In addition, hard passages don’t always have hard questions associated with them, just as easy passages don’t always have easy questions associated with them.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

The length of a Reading Comprehension passage is not indicative of its difficulty. Also, hard passages don’t always have hard questions associated with them, just as easy passages don’t always have easy questions associated with them.

Let’s now discuss how Reading Comprehension questions will be presented to us.

topics.topicName: 1.7 Reading Comprehension Questions Are Presented One at a Time
topics.content:
1. Introduction To GMAT Reading Comprehension

1.7 Reading Comprehension Questions Are Presented One at a Time

The GMAT presents Reading Comprehension questions in a split-screen format, with the passage presented in its entirety on the left side of the screen and the questions about the passage presented one at a time on the right side. After a particular question is answered, a new question replaces the old one on the right-side pane while the passage remains fixed in place.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

Reading Comprehension questions are presented in a split-screen format, with the passage presented in its entirety on the left side of the screen and the questions about the passage presented one at a time on the right side.

Also, although multiple questions are associated with each passage, the same rules that apply to other GMAT question types also apply to Reading Comprehension questions: we can’t view the next question until we’ve submitted an answer to the current question, and we can’t go back to a previous question once we’ve hit the “confirm your answer” button.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

The same rules that apply to other GMAT question types also apply to Reading Comprehension questions; we can’t view the next question until we’ve submitted an answer to the current question, and we can’t go back to a previous question once we’ve hit the “confirm your answer” button.

So, while we’ll be able to see a passage continuously, once we’ve answered a question and hit “confirm your answer,” another question will populate in the prior question’s place. Also, for any given passage, we won’t know in advance how many questions we’ll be required to answer.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

For any given Reading Comprehension passage, we won’t know in advance how many questions we’ll be required to answer.

Lastly, it’s also important to know that, although Reading Comprehension passages are viewed on a computer monitor, we do not have the ability to use “control f” to search the passage or have access to any sort of highlighting tool. This applies to both the in-person and online GMAT.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

In Reading Comprehension, we do not have the ability to use “control f” to search the passage or have access to any sort of highlighting tool. This applies to both the in-person and online GMAT.

Now that we have discussed how Reading Comprehension questions appear on the GMAT, let’s discuss your Reading Comprehension pacing strategy.

topics.topicName: 1.8 GMAT Reading Comprehension Pacing Strategy
topics.content:
1. Introduction To GMAT Reading Comprehension

1.8 GMAT Reading Comprehension Pacing Strategy

The pacing strategy that works best is to spend about 2 minutes reading each short passage and about 3 to 4 minutes reading each long passage and then spend about 1 minute to answer each question associated with a given passage. In other words, reading a short passage and answering all the questions associated with it will typically take about 5 minutes, and reading a long passage and answering all the questions associated with it will typically take 7 to 8 minutes.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

Reading a short passage and answering all the questions associated with it will typically take about 5 minutes and reading a long passage and answering all the questions associated with it will typically take 7 to 8 minutes.

Of course, during the test, you’re not going to be counting words in order to gauge how much time you should spend on a passage. However, you will be able to eyeball Reading Comprehension passages and get some sense of whether you’re, for example, spending an inordinate amount of time reading what looks like a relatively short passage.

It’s also good to be aware that, if you’re faced with, for example, a long passage featuring 2 or 3 paragraphs that all look fairly long, you don’t have to start panicking if you need longer than 3 minutes to read the passage, because a 2-paragraph or 3-paragraph long passage is still a long passage. It’s the number of words or lines that determines whether a passage is long or short, not the number of paragraphs.

As you practice answering RC questions, your sense of what are appropriate amounts of time to spend on passages of different lengths will become more finely tuned, though keep in mind, there is no exact method for determining how long passages of different lengths will take you to read. After all, every passage covers a different topic, and some passages will be denser than others. This variation among passages is yet another reason why it’s important to think of your Reading Comprehension pacing in terms of ranges of time, rather than fixed numbers.

Let’s now briefly discuss the ten primary types of Reading Comprehension questions.

topics.topicName: 1.9 The Ten Primary Types of Reading Comprehension Questions
topics.content:
1. Introduction To GMAT Reading Comprehension

1.9 The Ten Primary Types of Reading Comprehension Questions

Although we will cover each of these question types in detail shortly, it’s helpful to know that there are the following ten primary types of Reading Comprehension questions.

(1) Primary Purpose (Main Idea)

The correct answer to a Primary Purpose question will summarize the big picture of the passage. Primary Purpose questions appear along with most RC passages. Therefore, as we read a passage, we should seek to identify its primary purpose or main idea.

(2) Passage Structure

Passage Structure questions ask us about the structure and organization of the passage. The correct answer to a Passage Structure question will describe how an author went about presenting ideas or making a point.

(3) Specific Purpose

Specific purpose questions ask us to identify the purpose or function of a specific component of the passage, such as a word, sentence, or paragraph.

(4) Author’s Opinion and Tone

Author’s Opinion and Tone questions ask about the author’s opinion about or attitude toward things discussed in the passage.

(5) Detail

Detail questions ask us about specific details of what the passage says. We never need to memorize specific details as we read a passage because, when we are asked about details, we can always go back to the passage to find what we need.

(6) Inference

An Inference question will ask for a conclusion that follows from information presented in the passage. The answer to an Inference question will not be stated directly in the passage. Rather, the answer to an Inference question will be something that we can “infer” from what the passage says.

(7) Application

Application questions test our ability to use information presented in the passage to answer a question about a subject or situation not discussed in the passage. In order to correctly answer these questions, we have to see how what the passage says is connected to or applies to something else.

(8) Identify the Assumption

Identify the Assumption RC questions are similar to Assumption Critical Reasoning questions. Assumption RC questions will ask us to identify an assumption upon which an argument or line of reasoning presented in the passage depends.

(9) Weaken the Argument

Weaken the Argument RC questions are similar to the Weaken the Argument questions we’ve encountered in Critical Reasoning. The correct answer to a Weaken RC question will weaken an argument or cast doubt on a conclusion presented in the passage.

(10) Strengthen the Argument

Strengthen the Argument RC questions are also similar to questions we’ve seen in Critical Reasoning. The correct answer to a Strengthen RC question will strengthen an argument or support a conclusion presented in the passage.

Let’s now discuss what GMAT Reading Comprehension passages are about.

topics.topicName: 1.10 What GMAT Reading Comprehension Passages Are About
topics.content:
1. Introduction To GMAT Reading Comprehension

1.10 What GMAT Reading Comprehension Passages Are About

The subject matter of Reading Comprehension passages encompasses the following:

(1) humanities

(2) social sciences

(3) business and economics

(4) physical sciences

(5) biological sciences

So, we may see passages discussing art, music, film, literature, human rights, international law, history, economics, politics, sociology, medicine, health care, astronomy, technology, philosophy, physics, biology, or chemistry, to name some of the possible topics.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

GMAT Reading Comprehension passages cover a range of topics in the humanities, social sciences, business, and the physical and biological sciences.

An important point to keep in mind is that the subject matter of a given passage does not dictate the difficulty of that passage or the associated questions. For example, people often incorrectly assume that all science passages are considered hard, but that notion is incorrect; some sciences passages are very easy, some are of medium difficulty, and some are hard. The same goes for any other genre of RC passage.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

The subject matter of a given RC passage does not dictate the difficulty of that passage or the associated questions.

Additionally, we don’t need to have any specialized subject knowledge in order to understand RC passages or answer their questions.

All of the information we’ll need to answer RC questions will be contained within the passages. No outside facts or figures, unprovided dates, or expertise in a particular area will be required. Reading Comprehension passages are not subject tests; they’re tests of our ability to understand and interpret what we read. So, in developing our RC skills, we’ll be preparing to handle any passage we see.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

We won’t require any specialized subject knowledge to answer RC questions; all of the information we’ll need will be contained within the passages.

Because there are such a wide array of Reading Comprehension topics, it’s quite likely that some topics will interest you more than others. For example, let’s say you’re most interested in business or history passages, but you encounter a long science passage. Rather than “checking out,” it’s important to engage yourself in the passage as much as you would with topic that you’re interested in. In the chapters that follow, we’ll have a lot more to say about how to be engaged with the passages.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

One key Reading Comprehension skill is to be interested and engaged in all of the passages you face, regardless of the information in those passages.

Let’s now discuss the biggest secret that all RC masters know.

topics.topicName: 1.11 The Biggest Secret that All Masters of Reading Comprehension Know
topics.content:
1. Introduction To GMAT Reading Comprehension

1.11 The Biggest Secret that All Masters of Reading Comprehension Know

The greatest secret that masters of Reading Comprehension know is that, whenever they read, they must be INTERESTED and ENGAGED in what they’re reading, regardless of the topic.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

Test-takers who consistently perform well on Reading Comprehension are interested and engaged in the material presented in each passage, without exception.

The flip side is that one of the biggest mistakes people make when working though Reading Comprehension passages is not becoming interested in the material presented in the passages. Instead, they read simply to “get it done.” Such an approach does not work.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

One of the biggest mistakes people make when working through Reading Comprehension passages is not becoming interested in the material presented in the passages.

When we’re interested in what we’re reading, we help ourselves engage with, and understand, what we’re reading. However, when we lack interest in what we’re reading, our comprehension drops significantly because, to acquire sufficient comprehension, we must fully engage our brains, and it’s difficult to do so when we’re not interested in what we’re reading - the mind just wanders, so to speak.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

When we lack interest in what we’re reading, our comprehension drops significantly.

Thus, one big step we can take in improving our reading skills is to choose to become interested in each passage that we read, regardless of the topic. When we’re curious, engaged, and interested in what we read, we’ll remember – and understand – significantly more.

Even if you have to “fake it until you make it,” do whatever is necessary to be interested and engaged in what you’re reading.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

Even if you have to “fake it until you make it,” do whatever is necessary to be interested and engaged in what you’re reading.

So, we don’t care what you need to do to become interested in what you are reading – just make it happen. If you are not interested, you will not be curious, ask questions, or seek to fill gaps in your understanding.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

If you’re not interested, you won’t be curious, ask questions, or seek to fill gaps in your understanding.

Always remember that there is a circle of interest and understanding: The more interested we are in what we’re reading, the more we’ll understand. Then, the more we understand, the easier it is to be interested.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

There is a circle of interest and understanding: The more interested we are in what we’re reading, the more we’ll understand. Then, the more we understand, the easier it is to be interested.

Keep in mind too that this idea of “being interested” in what we are reading does not have to begin and end with GMAT Reading Comprehension passages. In fact, if you can begin now to train yourself to become engaged in new unexplored content, regardless of the medium, then come test day, your natural inclination will be to eagerly read and explore a new unknown passage.

Over the years, we’ve seen that people who use Reading Comprehension passages as an opportunity to learn something new tend to perform better on Reading Comprehension than those who simply read to “get the job done.” So, do your best to view GMAT Reading Comprehension passages as opportunities to learn something new!

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

People who use Reading Comprehension passages as an opportunity to learn something new tend to perform better on Reading Comprehension than those who simply read to “get the job done.”

Let’s now discuss a way to strengthen our reading skills.

topics.topicName: 1.12 Read High Quality Literary Publications for Supplemental Practice.
topics.content:
1. Introduction To GMAT Reading Comprehension

1.12 Read High Quality Literary Publications for Supplemental Practice.

Let’s face it, at the core of Reading Comprehension is your ability to read well. Thus, just by being an experienced reader, you’ll have a more natural ability to swiftly and effectively work through Reading Comprehension passages.

Therefore, in addition to practicing with the material in this course, regularly reading GMAT Reading Comprehension-like writing is a good way to improve your reading abilities.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

In addition to practicing with the material in this course, regularly reading GMAT Reading Comprehension-like writing is a good way to improve your reading abilities.

However, developing your Reading Comprehension skills does not happen overnight. So, the sooner you can start a routine of reading, the stronger a reader you’ll be come test day.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

The sooner you can start a routine of reading, the stronger a reader you’ll be come test day.

The type of reading that you should be doing is not the type in which you open a low-quality news article on your phone and then read it while also snapchatting with your “friends.” Instead, sit down with a quality book, magazine, or newspaper written at a high level of English and read with no distractions.

There are many good sources of reading material that can help you to boost your Reading Comprehension skills. Let’s talk first about fiction and non-fiction books.

Non-Fiction Books

Non-fiction books are a great choice because GMAT Reading Comprehension passages are also non-fiction. Challenge yourself by reading about topics with which you’re less familiar. For example, if your science background is weak, pick a few science books to read. If you’ve never studied economics, choose some books from this area.

It’s crucial to become interested in what you’re reading and really jump into the text to absorb new and exciting information. This attitude will carry over to test day! If you are unsure of what books to read, here are a few history, science, and business options:

History Books:

Alexander Hamilton – Ron Chernow (an acclaimed biography of a visionary who played a key role in the founding of the United States)

Frederick Douglass: Prophet of Freedom – David Blight (a biography of an escaped slave who became one of the greatest reformers in American history)

Collapse: How Societies Choose to Fail or Succeed – Jared Diamond (an examination of catastrophic collapses of societies, the factors that caused them, and lessons to be learned from them)

The Warmth of Other Suns – Isabel Wilkerson (tells the story of the Great Migration of African Americans from the South to other parts of the country, an event that changed the face of America)

Science Books:

Transcendence: How Humans Evolved through Fire, Language, Beauty, and Time – Gala Vince (an exploration of multiple aspects of human development and progress)

Einstein’s Unfinished Revolution – Lee Smolin (discusses the shortcomings of quantum mechanics and offers alternative options for a theory of the atomic world)

A World Beyond Physics: The Emergence and Evolution of Life – Stuart Kauffman (an explanation of the development of life that goes beyond what physics can explain)

Our Universe: An Astronomer’s Guide – Jo Dunkley (a lively and exceptionally clear introduction to the structure and history of the universe)

Business Books:

Thinking Fast and Slow – Daniel Kahneman (a look into the way humans make decisions – super helpful for understanding the game of taking the GMAT)

The Black Swan – Nicolas Taleb (a fascinating look at how people misunderstand probabilities)

This is Marketing – Seth Godin (a discussion of marketing as creating value and making connections)

The Innovators Dilemma – Clayton Christensen (a discussion of how innovation takes place and why successful companies fail when confronted with disruptive technologies)

Fiction Books

Although GMAT Reading Comprehension passages are always nonfiction, reading fiction books can definitely help us to improve our Reading Comprehension skills. In addition to improving our reading skills, reading fiction books increases one’s ability to understand people’s emotions, a key GMAT Reading Comprehension skill.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

In addition to improving our reading skills, reading fiction books increases one’s ability to understand people’s emotions, a key GMAT Reading Comprehension skill.

Here are some fiction books that will surely help you to improve your Reading Comprehension skills.

Don Quixote – Miguel de Cervantes (a classic novel widely regarded as one of the funniest and most tragic books ever written)

The Great Gatsby – F. Scott Fitzgerald (often called the Great American Novel, tells the tragic story of a self-made millionaire obsessed with a long-lost love)

Catch-22 – Joseph Heller (a satirical war novel written in a unique style and often cited as one of the most significant novels of the twentieth century)

Magazines and Newspapers

In addition to reading non-fiction and fiction books, a great way to train for GMAT Reading Comprehension passages is to regularly read GMAT Reading Comprehension-like writing in the form of magazines and newspaper articles.

High-quality publications such as The New York Times feature writing on many of the topics discussed in GMAT Reading Comprehension passages and in a style similar to that of the writing in GMAT Reading Comprehension passages, and you can generally access some articles in those types of publications for free online.

The more exposure you have to RC-type writing, the more comfortable you’ll feel when you see the real thing. Perhaps you already read some RC-like articles every so often. Make doing so a daily habit. Maybe you read The Wall Street Journal on a regular basis; why not add The Atlantic or Science Daily into the mix?

The following is a list of some high-quality publications that you can check out. Certainly, you do not have to read them all, but you could start with articles from a few and perhaps rotate each week.

• Smithsonian

• BBC History

• Life Magazine

• Economist

• The New York Times

• New Yorker

• Archaeology Magazine

• Science Magazine

• Scientific American

• Science Daily

• Astronomy Magazine

• American Scientist

• Atlantic Monthly

• Physics Today

• Wall Street Journal

• Harvard Business Review

• Harvard Magazine

Just remember that reading high quality books, newspapers, and magazines is supplementary practice; it can’t replace dedicated practice with GMAT-specific Reading Comprehension material, such as that found in this course.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

Reading books, newspapers, and magazines, although helpful as a supplementary learning tool, can’t replace dedicated practice with GMAT-specific RC material, such as that found in this Target Test Prep course.

Another thing to consider, especially when reading articles, is that each article you read is a great opportunity to train yourself for GMAT Reading Comprehension passages. In other words, don’t read for leisure but rather read for practice. With that aim in mind, there are some basic things you can do when reading an article. While we will discuss all of these components, in detail, in the following chapters, we can discuss some brief points here to help you get started.

1. When reading, focus on retention. After reading each paragraph, are you able to recite a short summary of what you just read?

2. When reading, focus on understanding. After reading a particular paragraph, are you able to explain why the author wrote that paragraph and how that paragraph connects to the preceding text?

3. After reading the entire article, are you able to determine the main point of the article? In other words what was the main idea of or driving force behind the article, as a whole.

While you will be learning many other things to look out for and ways to attack Reading Comprehension passage in the chapters that follow, the three points above are a good start of what to be doing when reading an article. At the end of the day, you are always trying to improve your retention and understanding of all that you are reading.

In fact, a great way to practice your reading skills is to read an article and then attempt to explain what you just read to either a friend, colleague, or significant other. Even if you are by yourself, record your summary, so you can play it back after and confirm whether you successfully digested what you had just read. The more you practice these reading skills, the more confident you will be on test day.

Let’s now discuss how to get the most from this course.

topics.topicName: 1.13 How to Get the Most From This RC Course
topics.content:
1. Introduction To GMAT Reading Comprehension

1.13 How to Get the Most From This RC Course

In a sense, Reading Comprehension success comes down to four things:

- understanding passages

- understanding questions

- finding in passages the right information for answering questions

- telling trap choices from correct answers

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

In a sense, Reading Comprehension success comes down to four things:

- understanding passages

- understanding questions

- finding in passages the right information for answering questions

- telling trap choices from correct answers

So, as you go through this course, you’ll get the most from it if you focus on developing skill in doing these four things.

Understanding Passages

In this course, we are going to cover strategies for reading, analyzing, and understanding passages, and as you read the passages the course contains, you’ll get the most out of the process by applying the strategies and seeking to fully understand each passage.

In particular, if you are having trouble understanding what a passage says, you won’t get the results you’re seeking by just continuing on, attempting to answer the questions associated with the passage, and hoping to better understand the next passage.

The way to develop skill in understanding passages is to seek to understand every passage you read, even if sometimes you have to slowly work your way through a passage one sentence at a time. If a passage is on a topic or uses language that you find challenging, consider the passage an opportunity to master handling such a topic or such language. If you find a passage confusing, take the time to reread any portions you don’t understand and unconfuse yourself. In general, stick with each practice passage until you fully understand it. You’ll get great results that way.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

As you read the passages this course contains, you’ll get the most out of the process by applying the strategies discussed in the course and seeking to fully understand each passage.

Understanding Questions

A key aspect of arriving at correct answers to RC questions is understanding what the questions are asking. So, to maximize your RC performance, get into the habit of carefully reading and fully understanding each RC question you see.

It takes only a few more seconds to read a question carefully than it does to read it hastily, and those few seconds are seconds well invested.

Making sure you understand the questions is a key aspect of winning the RC game.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

To maximize your RC performance, get into the habit of carefully reading and fully understanding each RC question you see.

Finding in Passages the Right Information for Answering Questions

As we will discuss more in the chapters to come, GMAT Reading Comprehension is an open book test; the information we need for answering the questions is right there in the passage. Accordingly, skill in finding in a passage the right information for answering a question is a key RC skill.

We’ll discuss approaches for finding the information you need in a passage. To maximize your RC performance, as you go through this course, seek to employ those approaches and become an information finding machine.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

To maximize your RC performance, seek to become an information finding machine.

Telling Trap Choices from Correct Answers

The final step in answering an RC question is determining which choices are incorrect and which is the correct answer. We’ll discuss things you can do to determine whether a choice is a trap choice or a correct answer, and for best results, when you answer practice RC questions, make it your mission to become skilled in noticing the key differences between trap choices and correct answers.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

For best results, when you answer practice RC questions, make it your mission to become skilled in noticing the key differences between trap choices and correct answers.

To develop strong skills, practice untimed at first.

A key fact of training for Reading Comprehension is that we’ll learn the fastest and develop the strongest skills by starting off working slowly and speeding up as we become more skilled.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

A key fact of training for Reading Comprehension is that we’ll learn the fastest and develop the strongest skills by starting off working slowly and speeding up as we become more skilled.

In other words, when we first start reading passages and answering questions, there’s no reason to expect to be able to get the questions correct at the pace we’ll keep on test day. So, the best way to train for Reading Comprehension is to start off practicing untimed to give ourselves the time we need to fully understand passages, carefully answer questions, and learn.

In other words, we’ll get the best results by aiming for understanding and accuracy first. Then, once we’ve learned how to arrive at correct answers consistently, we can seek to speed up. Speed will come with skill.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

When training for RC, we’ll get the best results by aiming for understanding and accuracy first.

Focus on process to achieve RC mastery.

A theme to what we’re discussing here is that, to achieve RC mastery, we have to focus on process. In other words, when we’re training, the point is to develop skill in doing things that work consistently. So, when we’re reading passages and answering practice questions, we should seek to use good form.

If we arrive at a correct answer haphazardly by using a sketchy rationale or by guessing between the last two choices, we aren’t doing what we have to do to master RC. Sure, we got that question correct, but what we did won’t work consistently.

Conversely, if we seek to fully understand passages, carefully locate information, and provide solid support for our choices, we’ll be practicing going through the motions that consistently result in success and thus master Reading Comprehension.

chapterName: 2. Primary Purpose, Structure, Tone and Specific Purpose

topics.topicName: 2.1 Introduction
topics.content:
2. Primary Purpose, Structure, Tone and Specific Purpose

2.1 Introduction

At this point, you already know many of the nuts and bolts of GMAT Reading Comprehension. In this chapter, we’ll learn how to become a master at attacking the following question types:

- Primary Purpose,

- Structure

- Author’s Opinion and Tone

- Specific Purpose

Answering these four question types requires that we focus on the big picture, the macro, of the passages we read. Thus, grouping these question types together in this chapter is fitting.

We’ll see that when we’re at the top of our RC game, we’ll need to read a passage only once, and that, in that single reading, we’ll come away with a solid understanding of the author’s primary purpose, how the passage is structured, the author’s opinion and tone, and the specific purpose of elements. This chapter is devoted to helping you become a master at those things.

As we go, in addition to building a powerful set of new skills, we’ll continue to reinforce all of the concepts you learned in the previous chapter. We’ll begin with a discussion of the idea that there is a simple story behind each RC passage.

topics.topicName: 2.2 Behind Every Reading Comprehension Passage is a Simple Story.
topics.content:
2. Primary Purpose, Structure, Tone and Specific Purpose

2.2 Behind Every Reading Comprehension Passage is a Simple Story.

Behind every Reading Comprehension passage - regardless of how simple or how complex it looks at first - is a simple story. One of our most important jobs while reading a passage is to find that simple story! When we seek the simple story in each passage, we’ll set ourselves up to make answering RC questions easy!

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

Behind every Reading Comprehension passage is a simple story. One of our most important jobs while reading a passage is to find that simple story!

In many cases, RC passages may seem complex or dense. All the same, each passage still has a simple story. In fact, it’s commonly the case that a long passage with numerous details communicates just a few main points that can be summed up in a few sentences. We’ll so often see that all of the “scary” details don’t make much of an impact on the simple story.

So, as you read an RC passage, pretend that you’ll later need to summarize the passage for a five-year-old child by using only a few simple sentences. The more simply we can summarize a passage, the better we’ll understand it, and the better we’ll perform on the questions that follow.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

The more simply we can summarize a passage, the better we’ll understand it, and the better we’ll perform on the questions that follow.

At this point, many of you lack the skills required to distill RC passages into simple, rephrased stories; don’t worry at all. A major portion of this chapter is devoted to teaching you exactly how to look at any passage – regardless of its complexity – and find the simple story.

Let’s now talk about the basic ingredients found in all GMAT reading comprehension passages.

topics.topicName: 2.3 Basic Ingredients Found in GMAT Reading Comprehension Passages
topics.content:
2. Primary Purpose, Structure, Tone and Specific Purpose

2.3 Basic Ingredients Found in GMAT Reading Comprehension Passages

Knowing what to expect from Reading Comprehension passages will make it easier for us to read, analyze, and answer questions on them.

The good news is that we’ll see that most GMAT Reading Comprehension passages have the same basic set of ingredients; the “chefs” who cook up these passages tend to follow a very strict rubric in creating them.

We’ll be talking a lot about these ingredients in the sections and chapters to follow, but to get started, let’s discuss from a high-level these common ingredients.

Passages will contain theories, opinions, or viewpoints.

It’s important to know that passages often contain theories, opinions, or points of view. Shorter passages tend to present one theory, opinion, or point of view, whereas longer passages tend to present multiple theories or viewpoints. It’s important that we pay close attention to any theories, opinions, or viewpoints we encounter.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

Shorter RC passages tend to present one theory, opinion, or point of view, whereas longer passages tend to present multiple theories or viewpoints. We must pay attention to any theories, opinions, or viewpoints we encounter.

In fact, one of the most common points of view that we encounter in RC passages is the “myth structure.” In the myth structure, a group of people (scientists, historians, psychologists, researchers, management consultants) believe something. At the same time, the author of the passage does not agree with what these people believe; he or she believes that their theory or point of view is not quite right (what they believe is a myth). The author develops the passage by highlighting why the viewpoint of the mentioned group of people is not correct.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

In RC passages, be on the lookout for the “myth structure,” which is common. Pay close attention to what the author believes the myth is and what he or she feels is more accurate.

Passages will contain evidence to support theories, opinions, or viewpoints.

Because GMAT Reading Comprehension passages are modeled after scholarly articles, and because in scholarly writing authors always present evidence to support their claims, theories, and points of view, a second common ingredient in passages is supporting evidence.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

GMAT Reading Comprehension passages are modeled after scholarly articles, and because in scholarly writing authors always present evidence to support their claims, theories, and points of view, a second common ingredient in passages is supporting evidence.

When an author takes a point of view or proposes a theory, we can expect that he or she will give us evidence supporting that position. Similarly, we can expect to learn about evidence that supports opposing theories. Regardless of which side of the argument the evidence supports, it’s important to understand the nature of that evidence, although, as we’ll soon see, we never attempt to memorize details.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

When an author takes a point of view or proposes a theory in an RC passage, expect that he or she will give us evidence supporting that position. Also expect to learn about evidence that supports opposing theories.

Just remember, although we don’t want to attempt to memorize the details of the evidence provided, we always want to understand it from a big picture point of view. We can ask ourselves some simple questions about supporting evidence.

- What evidence does the author provide to support his or her viewpoints?

- What evidence is offered in support of any opposing viewpoints?

- Is the evidence strong (a scientific experiment, for example) or weak (someone has made an observation, for example).

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

We don’t want to attempt to memorize the details of the evidence provided in an RC passage. Instead, we want to understand it from a big picture point of view. We use evidence to enhance our comprehension.

This evidence can take the form of scientific studies, statistical data, analogies, examples, anecdotes, or other supporting information.

So, we won’t be surprised at all when we encounter RC passages that introduce a theory, provide some evidence for that theory, make the claim that that theory is somehow incomplete, inaccurate, or just plain outdated, and then present some reasons why.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

Many RC passages introduce a theory, provide some evidence for that theory, make the claim that that theory is somehow incomplete, inaccurate, or just plain outdated, and then present some reasons why.

Passages will contain descriptive information.

While many Reading Comprehension passages will present opinions or viewpoints, some passages simply describe topics, such as natural phenomena, technological innovations, or historical developments, without mentioning or stating any strong opinions about the topics; these passages will be written in a neutral tone.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

Some RC passages simply describe topics, such as natural phenomena, technological innovations, or historical developments, without mentioning or stating any strong opinions about the topics.

Because these passages are written with a neutral tone, without the author taking any stance one way or another, in reading a passage made up entirely of descriptive information, our job will be simply to understand what’s being said about the topic and prepare to answer questions about specific details or implications of the information provided.

Passages will contain explanations.

Many passages will be somewhat or mostly made up of explanatory information. For instance, a passage may explain in detail how a certain type of scientific experiment was set up or how a technology works. In reading such a passage, our job will be to understand the logic of what’s explained while avoiding getting bogged down in details (way more on this later), and we’ll prepare to answer questions about implications or applications of what has been explained.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

In RC passages somewhat or mostly made up of explanatory information our job will be to understand the logic of what’s explained while avoiding getting bogged down in details.

As we prepare for Reading Comprehension, we’ll become familiar with the ways in which the passages typically work.

As we prepare for Reading Comprehension and read numerous RC passages, we’ll become familiar with how the passages tend to work. As a result, when we’re reading a passage, we’ll quickly notice whether it’s presenting viewpoints, a description, an explanation, or a combination of those types of information.

Also, we’ll become increasingly skilled in seeing the simple story to each passage, such as “All this passage says is that there’s a disagreement regarding what this historical person achieved,” or “All this passage does is discuss some reasons why this type of machine is better than similar ones,” or “This passage simply presents four ways in which a strategy has been applied and then wraps up with an overall take on the usefulness of the strategy.”

As a result, the passages will appear less complex and cease to seem intimidating; we’ll become comfortable with RC passages, understand what they say, and be prepared to answer questions about them.

Now that we know more about what types of ingredients we’ll see in RC passages, let’s resume with our idea of finding the simple story.

topics.topicName: 2.4 An Effective Recipe to Find the Simple Story
topics.content:
2. Primary Purpose, Structure, Tone and Specific Purpose

2.4 An Effective Recipe to Find the Simple Story

The good news is that there’s a three-part recipe that we can follow to help us determine the simple story of any passage. Of course, over time we’ll help you build upon this simple recipe, but for now, this recipe will be a significant asset to your RC toolkit.

The Simple Story is Specific. It is Never Overly Broad.

If we’re not careful, we’ll have a tendency to overgeneralize the simple story. That is, we may make the simple story too broad, leading to a conceptualization that is not truly the simple story.

We must not make this mistake. Our simple stories must be at an appropriate level of detail.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

When we create a simple story, we must take care not to make it too broad. The simple story should contain the appropriate level of detail.

For example, consider the following sentence:

Throughout his life, Ernest Hemingway attempted to supersede the influence of his domineering mother and depressive father.

When we ask students what the simple story of that sentence is, the following are incorrect responses that we often encounter:

Hemingway

Hemingway’s life

Hemingway’s parents

Hemingway’s relationship with his parents

Hemingway’s bad parents

Notice that all of these are just too broad, and that the truth of the matter is that none strike upon the true simple story. Why do we have a tendency to provide simple stories that are too broad? Well, because it takes less thinking to do so. When we overgeneralize the simple story, we fool ourselves into believing that we’ve understood what we’ve read.

We can’t fall into this trap. Our simple stories must accurately reflect what we’ve read.

A more accurate simple story of the sentence would be:

Hemingway tried to break free from his parent’s unhealthy influence.

Notice that this simple story is not too broad – it accurately depicts the sentence.

Let’s practice with another, this time a mini-passage.

In 1918, Ernest Hemingway enlisted as a volunteer in the Italian Red Cross to drive an ambulance. However, this stint was short-lived. About one month into the assignment, he was injured by mortar fire and spent some months recovering in a Milanese hospital.

Each of the following are common responses from students when we ask them to put together a simple story based upon that passage:

Hemingway

Hemingway’s life

Hemingway’s time in Italy

Hemingway’s work at the Italian Red Cross

Hemingway’s time at a hospital in Milan

Hemingway was injured by mortar fire.

Notice that all of these are just too broad, and that the truth of the matter is that none actually strike upon the true simple story, which is:

Hemingway’s Italian Red Cross work was short-lived because an injury required his hospitalization.

Notice that this simple story is not too broad – it accurately depicts the sentence.

So, and this will sound obvious, our simple stories must accurately reflect what we’ve read. When we create simple stories that are too broad, we lose much of what the author intended us to understand.

We’ll have ample opportunities to continue practicing this skill. Let’s now discuss why it’s important to rephrase and re-express the wording of the passage.

The Simple Story Always Rephrases and re-Expresses the Wording of the Passage.

A second mistake that people make when creating a simple story is to simply regurgitate (reuse) the exact words from the passage. When we reuse the exact wording from the passage, we’re not creating a simple story; we’re simply being parrots. We’re not thinking. Rather, we’re just pronouncing words. Don’t do this. As amazing as parrots are, they’re not great at creating simple stories, and pronouncing words without thinking won’t get us far in GMAT RC.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

When we create a simple story, we must take the words of the author and rephrase them into our own words.

Instead, when we create a simple story, we must take the words of the author and rephrase them into our own words. This rephrasing is important because doing so forces us to carefully process what the author has written and then re-explain his or her ideas using our own ideas and words, a process that cannot be completed without an understanding of the passage.

Consider the following passage, which is a bit longer than the previous short passage.

Ernest Hemingway’s interest in the reversal of traditional gender roles began early in his life, starting as a result of his mother Grace, who often pretended that Ernest and his sister Marcelline were identical twins, sometimes dressing the siblings as boys and sometimes as girls. Some days the siblings would have feminine haircuts – blunt bobs and bangs – and be encouraged to play with tea sets, an activity then seen as feminine, and other days would be encouraged to play with air rifles, an activity that, at the time, was seen as one fit for a man only.

Notice that each of the following attempts at making a simple story simply parrot (repeat) the words of the author, creating conceptualizations that are not helpful:

Ernest Hemingway’s interest in the reversal of traditional gender roles began early in his life, starting with his mother Grace.

Ernest Hemingway’s interest in the reversal of gender roles began with his mother Grace.

Some days the Hemingway siblings would have feminine haircuts and be encouraged to play with tea sets and other days they were encouraged to play with air rifles.

After all, to create these stories, we simply did a cut and paste from the passage. If you “cut and paste” from the passage on test day, you won’t be happy with the result.

Notice that following simple story is rephrased in our own words:

Because of his mother, Hemingway became interested in gender role reversal at an early age.

Notice that, to go from the words used by the author in the passage to that simple story, we had to have understood well the passage, and understanding the passage well is a major goal in Reading Comprehension. In addition, notice that the simple story is also appropriate in detail; it is not overly broad.

Let’s keep practicing with the simple story. Consider the following passage:

While recovering in a hospital in Milan from a mortar wound, Ernest Hemingway fell in love with Agnes von Kurowsky, an American Nurse, and in 1919 Hemingway left Milan, traveling back to the United States with the understanding that he and Agnes would marry. However, soon thereafter she wrote him to explain that she planned to marry someone else, causing him significant emotional anguish, which he put to work by writing his second novel, A Farewell to Arms, in which Lieutenant Henry, an American ambulance driver, falls in love with Catherine Barkley, an English nurse working in Italy.

We won’t make you suffer through reading “cut and pasted” sentences from the passage. You’re past that now. You know that any attempt to create a simple summary by simply regurgitating the words used by the author will create an ineffective simple story.

An effective simple story would be:

Hemingway put the pain caused by Agnes’s marriage rejection to use by writing his second novel.

Let’s stop for a second. Look at how long the passage is. It’s approximately 100 words. However, when all is said and done, the story that it communicates is simple!! So much of the passage is detail that does not impact the way we created the simple story.

For example, is 1919 important to the story? Well, all dates are important, but the date does not add anything to the simple story. If we needed that date to answer a question, we could refer back to the passage.

Is the fact that Hemingway was injured by a mortar important? Definitely, because it’s factual. However, notice that how he was injured doesn’t impact the simple story. If we need to know how exactly he was injured (and we didn’t remember from reading) we could refer back to the passage.

Is the name of the novel important? Yes and no. A Farewell to Arms is a famous American novel, but including that detail in the simple story is not useful. If we needed to know the name of the novel (and didn’t remember it) we could refer back to the passage.

So, remember: when creating a simple story, we must take the words of the authors and transform them – via our own understanding – into words of our own.

Let’s now discuss why the simple story is always concise.

The Simple Story is Always Concise

So far we’ve seen that the simple story must never be overly broad and that is must always be a re-expression of what the author has written. Additionally, the simple story must also be concise.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

The simple story of an RC passage must always be concise.

As we’ve mentioned, and as we’ll continue to see, even in the most lengthy Reading Comprehension passage, there is a simple story. Therefore, there’s no reason to complicate the “simple” story by making it lengthy.

The ability to generate a concise simple summary can come only from having a solid comprehension of the passage. So, by practicing generating concise simple stories, we’re also practicing to develop skill in reading in a way that creates solid understanding.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

By practicing generating concise simple stories, we’re also practicing to develop skill in reading in a way that creates solid understanding.

Mark Twain once said that “I didn’t have time to write a short letter, so I wrote a long one instead.” His quote rings true; it’s always going to be easier to write verbosely (using many words) but rambling on and being clear about what we’re writing about seldom go hand in hand, so we must strive to be concise.

Let’s now get some practice making our simple stories concise.

Consider the following mini-passage:

Great writers of fiction often struggle to separate the lives about which they write in their novels and the reality in which they live outside of their typewriters. For example, Ernest Hemingway was a notorious teller of stories. When he returned to his home in Oak Park in 1919 after participating in Word War I, Hemingway would give talks during which he emphasized his heroism during the war; he frequently told the story of how he once carried an injured soldier to safety before he collapsed from his efforts. Although he told the story as if it were truth, it was merely theatre, an extension of what was occurring in the lives of the characters in his fictional writing at that time.

This passage is about 120 words. However, notice that there’s a very simple story that we can create:

It’s hard for great fiction writers to separate their fiction from their realities.

That’s it! Notice that this passage talks a lot about Hemingway, but he’s not the central idea in the passage, which is about great writers of fiction in general. Notice that all of the details about Hemmingway serve to support the simple story.

Now that you have an effective recipe for creating a simple story, let’s consider a full Reading Comprehension passage. We’ll answer some questions about this passage shortly, but for now, we can just read this passage and seek to see the simple story in what the passage says.

In addition to what we’ve already learned, it will be helpful to ask the following questions as you read:

- Does the passage present any viewpoints?

- Does it provide support for any viewpoints or conclusions?

- Does it describe anything in detail?

- Does it explain how something works or worked?

- What does the passage accomplish?

- How could I explain the simple story to a five-year-old?

- How could we summarize what the passage says in a few sentences?

As you read, notice that, even though the passage includes numerous details, it makes just a few main points and conveys only one simple story.

Example 1

S1: In the mid-twentieth century, anthropomorphism – the attribution of human traits or purposes to non-human entities such as animals – had long been frowned upon by most members of the scientific community, who perceived there to be a clear dividing line between the psychology and intentions of humans and the consciousness and motivations of other animals. S2: A researcher’s engaging in any degree of anthropomorphism was considered an unacceptable flaw in methodology that inevitably results in loss of objectivity.

S3: However, as a scientific community outsider with no college degree and little training, Jane Goodall was unaffected by this view when she first entered the Tanzanian wilderness to study chimpanzees. S4: Consequently, she was unimpeded from making certain groundbreaking discoveries that would forever change the way non-human animals are perceived. S5: During her first period of field study, in 1960, having observed chimpanzee facial expressions and actions, such as their using touch to greet and comfort each other, she concluded that chimpanzees have unique personalities and human-like emotions. S6: Also, during this period, she observed chimpanzees fashioning simple tools that they then used to “fish” for termites. S7: Since, at the time, the common wisdom was that humans alone among all animals modify objects to create tools, this discovery stunned the scientific world. S8: Later, in 1970, her observation that chimpanzees seemed to express awe at the sight of a spectacular waterfall led her and others to believe that chimpanzees have experiences akin to human spirituality.

S9: Goodall’s work has been sufficient to convince many of her peers that human and animal mental, emotional, and spiritual characteristics lie on a continuum rather than on two sides of a dividing line – Harvard’s Stephen Jay Gould used the words “one of the great achievements of twentieth-century scholarship.” S10: Nevertheless, others have termed her work “anecdotal” or even “unbounded speculation” because, as diligent as it is, her conclusions are largely based upon a somewhat limited set of observations made by a single person. S11: However, more recently, teams of researchers using empirical methods involving large samples have produced evidence indicating that her views reflect reality.

PASSAGE-ANALYSIS
Showing:
Passage Analysis

That was a pretty sizeable passage - about 340 words. However, it’s so important to see that despite the length of the passage, it presents a simple story, which is that:

Jane Goodall was unimpeded from making groundbreaking discoveries that would forever change the way non-human animals are perceived because she was unaffected by the predominant scientific thoughts regarding anthropomorphism.

Notice that everything else in the passage, regardless of how interesting it may be, does not impact the simple story! If we needed any of the other information (and could not remember it from reading), all we’d need to do is return to the passage to find what we need.

Also notice, however, it would be hard to return to the passage to find the simple story because the simple story requires that we comprehend and then rephrase the passage. So, it’s important for us to be able to put together a simple story after one read of the passage. We’ll soon see that this theme of “get it right the first time” applies to all of the big picture tasks that RC requires of us.

Also notice that, if we were able to read that passage and distill into the simple story above, for sure we understood what we read, and understanding what we read is a major goal of our RC training!

Example 1

easy

S1: In the mid-twentieth century, anthropomorphism – the attribution of human traits or purposes to non-human entities such as animals – had long been frowned upon by most members of the scientific community, who perceived there to be a clear dividing line between the psychology and intentions of humans and the consciousness and motivations of other animals. S2: A researcher’s engaging in any degree of anthropomorphism was considered an unacceptable flaw in methodology that inevitably results in loss of objectivity.

S3: However, as a scientific community outsider with no college degree and little training, Jane Goodall was unaffected by this view when she first entered the Tanzanian wilderness to study chimpanzees. S4: Consequently, she was unimpeded from making certain groundbreaking discoveries that would forever change the way non-human animals are perceived. S5: During her first period of field study, in 1960, having observed chimpanzee facial expressions and actions, such as their using touch to greet and comfort each other, she concluded that chimpanzees have unique personalities and human-like emotions. S6: Also, during this period, she observed chimpanzees fashioning simple tools that they then used to “fish” for termites. S7: Since, at the time, the common wisdom was that humans alone among all animals modify objects to create tools, this discovery stunned the scientific world. S8: Later, in 1970, her observation that chimpanzees seemed to express awe at the sight of a spectacular waterfall led her and others to believe that chimpanzees have experiences akin to human spirituality.

S9: Goodall’s work has been sufficient to convince many of her peers that human and animal mental, emotional, and spiritual characteristics lie on a continuum rather than on two sides of a dividing line – Harvard’s Stephen Jay Gould used the words “one of the great achievements of twentieth-century scholarship.” S10: Nevertheless, others have termed her work “anecdotal” or even “unbounded speculation” because, as diligent as it is, her conclusions are largely based upon a somewhat limited set of observations made by a single person. S11: However, more recently, teams of researchers using empirical methods involving large samples have produced evidence indicating that her views reflect reality.

PASSAGE-ANALYSIS
Showing:
Passage Analysis

That was a pretty sizeable passage - about 340 words. However, it’s so important to see that despite the length of the passage, it presents a simple story, which is that:

Jane Goodall was unimpeded from making groundbreaking discoveries that would forever change the way non-human animals are perceived because she was unaffected by the predominant scientific thoughts regarding anthropomorphism.

Notice that everything else in the passage, regardless of how interesting it may be, does not impact the simple story! If we needed any of the other information (and could not remember it from reading), all we’d need to do is return to the passage to find what we need.

Also notice, however, it would be hard to return to the passage to find the simple story because the simple story requires that we comprehend and then rephrase the passage. So, it’s important for us to be able to put together a simple story after one read of the passage. We’ll soon see that this theme of “get it right the first time” applies to all of the big picture tasks that RC requires of us.

Also notice that, if we were able to read that passage and distill into the simple story above, for sure we understood what we read, and understanding what we read is a major goal of our RC training!

The good news is that without realizing it, you just learned a lot about how to find the main idea of a passage, because for all intents and purposes, the simple story of a passage is its main idea.

Finding the main idea of a passage is an important part of Reading Comprehension.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

For all intents and purposes, the simple story of a passage is its main idea. One of our primary tasks from this point forward is to determine the main idea (simple story) of each passage we read.

As this chapter continues, we’ll have plenty more opportunities to practice finding the simple story. Let’s now discuss a key aspect of reading an RC passage, one that is deeply connected to finding the simple story: identifying the primary purpose of the passage.
