topics.topicName: 2.5 Primary Purpose Questions
topics.content:
2. Primary Purpose, Structure, Tone and Specific Purpose

2.5 Primary Purpose Questions

For every Reading Comprehension passage, there will be a clear reason for why the author has taken the time to write the passage. This reason is called the “primary purpose” of the passage.

In other words, there is an intention behind each passage; with each passage the author is attempting to communicate something.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

The primary purpose of a passage is the reason why the author took the time to write the passage.

Most RC passages are accompanied by a Primary Purpose question, which is about the primary purpose of the passage. So, by identifying the primary purposes of passages, we prepare ourselves to correctly answer these Primary Purpose questions.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

Most RC passages are accompanied by Primary Purpose questions, which ask about the primary purpose of a passage.

Primary Purpose stems use predictable language to ask about the primary purpose of the passage, such as:

The primary purpose of the passage is to

The passage is primarily concerned with

The passage is primarily concerned with the

The main purpose of the passage is to

The author of the passage is primary concerned with

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

Learn to recognize the common and predictable language used by Primary Purpose questions.

Since most RC passages are accompanied by Primary Purpose questions, as we read a passage, we must actively seek out the author’s primary purpose for writing that passage. When we’re done reading the passage, we want to be able to say, “The reason the author wrote this passage is to ….”

Let’s talk more about this topic now.

topics.topicName: 2.6 Always Identify the Author’s Primary Purpose for Writing the Passage.
topics.content:
2. Primary Purpose, Structure, Tone and Specific Purpose

2.6 Always Identify the Author’s Primary Purpose for Writing the Passage.

The good news is that an author writes for one purpose – to express his or her main idea.

Let’s say that again - the author’s primary purpose for writing a passage is to express the main idea. As you know, the other good news is that the main idea of a passage is nothing more than the simple story of that passage, something that you already know a bunch about.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

The author’s primary purpose for writing a passage is to express the main idea, which is nothing more than the simple story of the passage.

We can therefore set ourselves up to understand an author’s primary purpose by understanding the passage’s main idea. But you already know about this; you’ve been practicing to find the simple story!!

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

We can set ourselves up to understand a passage’s primary purpose by understanding its main idea (simple story).

More good news is that, because you’re already aware that there is a simple story to each passage and because you know the types of ingredients that appear in RC passages, you’re already well on your way to understanding how to find a passage’s main idea and hence its primary purpose.

Going forward, whenever we think “primary purpose,” we should think “main idea,” because without knowing a passage’s main idea, we’ll struggle to determine the author’s primary purpose.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

Whenever we think “primary purpose,” we should think “main idea,” because without knowing a passage’s main idea, we’ll struggle to determine the author’s primary purpose, because he or she writes to express her main idea.

When identifying the primary purpose, or main idea, we want to look at the “big picture,” figuratively and literally.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

When identifying the primary purpose, or main idea, we want to look at the “big picture,” figuratively and literally.

Therefore, it will be helpful to ask some of the following questions as we read:

Why did the author take the time to write this passage?

What is the simple story in this passage?

What is the big picture of this passage?

What is the author’s main conclusion in this passage?

What is the main point of this passage?

What is the central idea of this passage?

How can I summarize this passage?

What is the author attempting to convey in this passage?

What is the primary purpose of this passage?

What is this passage primarily concerned with?

What is the author’s overall message?

What would be the most accurate title for this passage?

In addition, we can pay close attention to any cause-and-effect claims made, problems introduced and solutions offered, or opposing viewpoints or conflicting evidence discussed. The main idea of a passage is often centered on cause-and-effect claims, problems and solutions, and opposing viewpoints.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

The main idea of an RC passage is often centered on cause-and-effect claims, problems and solutions, and opposing viewpoints.

Always keep in mind that, generally, we will not identify the primary purpose of a passage by considering one sentence or paragraph of the passage. Rather, we’ll understand the primary purpose by comprehending the passage as a whole, holistically and in totality.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

We will not identify the primary purpose of a passage by considering one sentence or paragraph of the passage. Rather, we’ll understand the primary purpose by comprehending the passage as a whole, holistically and in totality.

Let’s again consider the passage we saw earlier, and this time we can seek to identify the primary purpose of the passage and answer a Primary Purpose question.

Example 2

S1: In the mid-twentieth century, anthropomorphism – the attribution of human traits or purposes to non-human entities such as animals – had long been frowned upon by most members of the scientific community, who perceived there to be a clear dividing line between the psychology and intentions of humans and the consciousness and motivations of other animals. S2: A researcher’s engaging in any degree of anthropomorphism was considered an unacceptable flaw in methodology that inevitably results in loss of objectivity.

S3: However, as a scientific community outsider with no college degree and little training, Jane Goodall was unaffected by this view when she first entered the Tanzanian wilderness to study chimpanzees. S4: Consequently, she was unimpeded from making certain groundbreaking discoveries that would forever change the way non-human animals are perceived. S5: During her first period of field study, in 1960, having observed chimpanzee facial expressions and actions, such as their using touch to greet and comfort each other, she concluded that chimpanzees have unique personalities and human-like emotions. S6: Also, during this period, she observed chimpanzees fashioning simple tools that they then used to “fish” for termites. S7: Since, at the time, the common wisdom was that humans alone among all animals modify objects to create tools, this discovery stunned the scientific world. S8: Later, in 1970, her observation that chimpanzees seemed to express awe at the sight of a spectacular waterfall led her and others to believe that chimpanzees have experiences akin to human spirituality.

S9: Goodall’s work has been sufficient to convince many of her peers that human and animal mental, emotional, and spiritual characteristics lie on a continuum rather than on two sides of a dividing line – Harvard’s Stephen Jay Gould used the words “one of the great achievements of twentieth-century scholarship.” S10: Nevertheless, others have termed her work “anecdotal” or even “unbounded speculation” because, as diligent as it is, her conclusions are largely based upon a somewhat limited set of observations made by a single person. S11: However, more recently, teams of researchers using empirical methods involving large samples have produced evidence indicating that her views reflect reality.

The primary purpose of the passage is to

present the advantages and disadvantages of two different research methodologies

explain why engaging in anthropomorphism has been frowned upon by the scientific community

discuss the effect a researcher’s work has had on scientific understanding

demonstrate that college education and training often impede researchers from making significant discoveries

describe a controversy over the work of an unorthodox researcher

Example 2 - Question 1

easy

S1: In the mid-twentieth century, anthropomorphism – the attribution of human traits or purposes to non-human entities such as animals – had long been frowned upon by most members of the scientific community, who perceived there to be a clear dividing line between the psychology and intentions of humans and the consciousness and motivations of other animals. S2: A researcher’s engaging in any degree of anthropomorphism was considered an unacceptable flaw in methodology that inevitably results in loss of objectivity.

S3: However, as a scientific community outsider with no college degree and little training, Jane Goodall was unaffected by this view when she first entered the Tanzanian wilderness to study chimpanzees. S4: Consequently, she was unimpeded from making certain groundbreaking discoveries that would forever change the way non-human animals are perceived. S5: During her first period of field study, in 1960, having observed chimpanzee facial expressions and actions, such as their using touch to greet and comfort each other, she concluded that chimpanzees have unique personalities and human-like emotions. S6: Also, during this period, she observed chimpanzees fashioning simple tools that they then used to “fish” for termites. S7: Since, at the time, the common wisdom was that humans alone among all animals modify objects to create tools, this discovery stunned the scientific world. S8: Later, in 1970, her observation that chimpanzees seemed to express awe at the sight of a spectacular waterfall led her and others to believe that chimpanzees have experiences akin to human spirituality.

S9: Goodall’s work has been sufficient to convince many of her peers that human and animal mental, emotional, and spiritual characteristics lie on a continuum rather than on two sides of a dividing line – Harvard’s Stephen Jay Gould used the words “one of the great achievements of twentieth-century scholarship.” S10: Nevertheless, others have termed her work “anecdotal” or even “unbounded speculation” because, as diligent as it is, her conclusions are largely based upon a somewhat limited set of observations made by a single person. S11: However, more recently, teams of researchers using empirical methods involving large samples have produced evidence indicating that her views reflect reality.

QUESTION
Showing:
Question

The primary purpose of the passage is to

present the advantages and disadvantages of two different research methodologies

explain why engaging in anthropomorphism has been frowned upon by the scientific community

discuss the effect a researcher’s work has had on scientific understanding

demonstrate that college education and training often impede researchers from making significant discoveries

describe a controversy over the work of an unorthodox researcher
Previous Confirm Finish
Show solution Hide solution
PRESENTED BY :
Scott Woodbury-Stewart Founder and Expert GMAT Instructor Scott Woodbury-Stewart Founder and Expert GMAT Instructor

Text Solution:

To identify the primary purpose of this passage, we can begin by considering the simple story of this passage. This time, we’ll break each paragraph down.

As we discussed earlier, we can summarize the passage in the following way:

- The 1st paragraph says that, in the mid-twentieth century, anthropomorphism – the attribution of human traits or purposes to non-human entities such as animals – had long been frowned upon.

- The 2nd paragraph says that Jane Goodall was not affected by “this view,” i.e., the view that attribution of human traits or purposes to non-human entities should be frowned upon, and that, as a result, she made “certain discoveries that would forever change the way non-human animals are perceived. Then the second paragraph lists some of these discoveries.

- The 3rd paragraph then says that Jane Goodall’s work has been sufficient to convince some of her peers (other scientists), though not all, that humans and other animals are more similar than had been previously believed. It also says that some recent research has provided confirmation for her views.

So, since we see the simple story to this passage, we can answer the question “What’s the big picture of this passage?”

The big picture of this passage is that it tells the story of Jane Goodall’s making some discoveries and changing people’s thinking about anthropomorphism and the attributes of non-human animals.

(A) present the advantages and disadvantages of two different research methodologies

Does the passage “present the advantages and disadvantages of two different research methodologies.” No.

In the third paragraph, the passage does mention that Jane Goodall’s conclusions are based on the observations of a single person and then mentions “teams of researchers using empirical methods involving large samples.” However, the passage does not discuss “advantages and disadvantages” of Jane Goodall’s methodology or of the methodologies of the teams of researchers.

Furthermore, we can see that those two approaches to researching are discussed only briefly in one paragraph of the passage. So, discussing those approaches is not the primary purpose of the passage as a whole.

(B) explain why engaging in anthropomorphism has been frowned upon by the scientific community

We can see that the passage briefly explains why engaging in anthropomorphism was frowned upon: members of the scientific community “perceived there to be a clear dividing line between the psychology and intentions of humans and the consciousness and motivations of other animals.”

However, as we discussed in the introduction to this explanation, there is more to the simple story of the passage than explaining why anthropomorphism was frowned upon. So, explaining why anthropomorphism was frowned upon is not the primary purpose of the passage as a whole.

CORRECT ANSWER(C) discuss the effect a researcher’s work has had on scientific understanding

Notice how well this choice matches our summary of the passage.

The passage starts off by saying that anthropomorphism was frowned upon because members of the scientific community perceived that there is “a clear dividing line between the psychology and intentions of humans and the consciousness and motivations of other animals.” Then it discusses Jane Goodall’s discoveries. Finally, it discusses the effect of those discoveries on Jane Goodall’s peers’ thinking regarding anthropomorphism and the characteristics of humans and other animals.

So, the passage accomplishes exactly what this choice says; it discusses the effect Jane Goodall’s work has had on scientific understanding of the characteristics of humans and other animals.

We can see that this choice accurately describes the primary purpose of the passage.

(D) demonstrate that college education and training often impede researchers from making significant discoveries

Notice that the passage mentions Jane Goodall’s lack of college education and training only in one sentence and only to help explain why she made certain discoveries. It does not proceed to demonstrate that college education and training “often” impede researchers from making significant discoveries. So, this choice does not match what the passage does.

(E) describe a controversy over the work of an unorthodox researcher

We can see that, in the third paragraph, the passage says that Jane Goodall’s work has been sufficient to convince many of her peers that human and animal characteristics lie on a continuum, while others have termed her work “anecdotal” or even “unbounded speculation.” So, perhaps we could claim that those two sentences of the passage “describe a controversy over the work of an unorthodox researcher.”

However, describing those two opinions of Jane Goodall’s work is just a small part of what the passage does. It’s not the primary purpose of the passage as a whole.

Correct answer: C
Frequently Asked Questions

You’re beginning to sharpen a powerful set of new tools for finding the main idea (simple story) and primary purpose of a passage. Let’s now continue by discussing leading sentences of paragraphs may state the passage’s important points.

topics.topicName: 2.7 Leading Sentences of Paragraphs May State the Passage’s Important Points
topics.content:
2. Primary Purpose, Structure, Tone and Specific Purpose

2.7 Leading Sentences of Paragraphs May State the Passage’s Important Points

We’re now going to discuss a number of helpful clues that we can leverage to identify the primary purpose of a passage. The primary purpose of a passage will be strongly connected to the important points of the passage. So, using patterns and passage clues to locate important points of a passage is a great way to bring the passage’s primary purpose into focus.

One pattern that can be very useful is that it’s common for the leading sentences of the paragraphs in a passage to state the important points of the passage.

In fact, in many cases, by considering the first one or two sentences of the first paragraph and the first sentences of any paragraphs that follow the first paragraph, we can bring the primary purpose of the passage into focus.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

In many cases, by considering the first one or two sentences of the first paragraph and the first sentences of any paragraphs that follow the first paragraph, we can bring the primary purpose of the passage into focus.

Just keep in mind that this strategy tends to work better with passages that have more than one paragraph than it does with passages that have just one paragraph.

When working through the following example, take care to notice how the leading sentences of the paragraphs not only clue us into the main idea of each paragraph but also bring the primary purpose of the passage into sharp focus.

Example 3

S1: Hypochondria, traditionally considered an abnormal anxiety about one’s health, especially involving an unwarranted fear that one has a serious illness, is commonly believed to be extremely rare. However, it is far more normal than most people realize. S2: For example, at any point in time in the United States, approximately five percent of the population, or about sixteen million people, suffer from the condition. S3: In addition, statistics compiled from primary care doctors show that as many as twenty percent of examined patients are found to suffer from symptoms of hypochondria.

S4: An examination of well-known literary works further demonstrates just how prevalent the condition has been in the human population over the centuries. S5: In Moliere’s final play, The Imaginary Invalid (1673), Argan, the main character, is a classic hypochondriac who spends significant amounts of money at the apothecary seeking to fix numerous bodily symptoms. S6: He even plots to have his daughter marry a physician so he can be guaranteed free health care. S7: Almost two hundred years later, in Edgar Allen Poe’s The Fall of the House of Usher (1840), Poe calls the main character, the downtrodden aristocrat Roderick Usher, who is bothered by just about anything that even has the slightest potential to cause illness, a hypochondriac. S8: In Thomas Mann’s The Magic Mountain (1927), when the novel’s hero, Hans Castorp, travels to Switzerland to care for his brother who is suffering from Tuberculosis, Hans becomes quickly drawn into the culture of hypochondria that exists there, where sickness – along with trips to the doctor and temperature checks – has almost become a privilege of the aristocracy.

The author of the passage is primarily concerned with

arguing that more resources should be directed toward the treatment of a common condition

correcting a common misconception about the prevalence of a certain condition

demonstrating that people have long been aware of the prevalence of a certain condition

explaining why most people do not realize how normal a certain condition is

contrasting the prevalence of a condition in the present with the prevalence of that condition in the past

Example 3 - Question 1

easy

S1: Hypochondria, traditionally considered an abnormal anxiety about one’s health, especially involving an unwarranted fear that one has a serious illness, is commonly believed to be extremely rare. However, it is far more normal than most people realize. S2: For example, at any point in time in the United States, approximately five percent of the population, or about sixteen million people, suffer from the condition. S3: In addition, statistics compiled from primary care doctors show that as many as twenty percent of examined patients are found to suffer from symptoms of hypochondria.

S4: An examination of well-known literary works further demonstrates just how prevalent the condition has been in the human population over the centuries. S5: In Moliere’s final play, The Imaginary Invalid (1673), Argan, the main character, is a classic hypochondriac who spends significant amounts of money at the apothecary seeking to fix numerous bodily symptoms. S6: He even plots to have his daughter marry a physician so he can be guaranteed free health care. S7: Almost two hundred years later, in Edgar Allen Poe’s The Fall of the House of Usher (1840), Poe calls the main character, the downtrodden aristocrat Roderick Usher, who is bothered by just about anything that even has the slightest potential to cause illness, a hypochondriac. S8: In Thomas Mann’s The Magic Mountain (1927), when the novel’s hero, Hans Castorp, travels to Switzerland to care for his brother who is suffering from Tuberculosis, Hans becomes quickly drawn into the culture of hypochondria that exists there, where sickness – along with trips to the doctor and temperature checks – has almost become a privilege of the aristocracy.

QUESTION
Showing:
Question

The author of the passage is primarily concerned with

arguing that more resources should be directed toward the treatment of a common condition

correcting a common misconception about the prevalence of a certain condition

demonstrating that people have long been aware of the prevalence of a certain condition

explaining why most people do not realize how normal a certain condition is

contrasting the prevalence of a condition in the present with the prevalence of that condition in the past
Previous Confirm Finish
Show solution Hide solution
PRESENTED BY :
Scott Woodbury-Stewart Founder and Expert GMAT Instructor Scott Woodbury-Stewart Founder and Expert GMAT Instructor

Text Solution:

As we now know, the important points of a passage are often found in the first one or two sentences of the first paragraph and in the first sentences of any paragraphs that follow. So, let’s review the leading sentences of the paragraphs of this passage to see what they indicate.

Reviewing the first two sentences of the 1st paragraph, we see that the first sentence communicates that “Hypochondria … is commonly believed to be extremely rare.” Then the second sentence presents a contrast with the first sentence, “However, it is far more normal than most people realize.”

Going by just what these two sentences say, we get the sense that the main idea of this paragraph is to discuss the idea that a common belief, that hypochondria is rare, is not correct because hypochondria is “far more normal than people realize.” Then scanning the rest of the paragraph, we see that the remaining sentences provide evidence to support the claim that hypochondria is “far more normal than most people realize.” Thus, these sentences provide confirmation that the main idea of the 1st paragraph is to discuss the fact that hypochondria is not as rare as people believe it to be.

Moving on to the first sentence of the 2nd paragraph, we see that it communicates that literature from the past confirms that hypochondria has been “prevalent,” meaning “common.” So, this paragraph continues the discussion of the idea presented by the 1st paragraph, that the belief that hypochondria is “extremely rare” is not correct because hypochondria is in fact “prevalent.”

So, we can see that the leading sentences of the paragraphs clearly indicate that the primary purpose of the passage is something along the lines of to show that the common belief that hypochondria is rare is not correct because hypochondria is not rare; it’s prevalent.

(A) arguing that more resources should be directed toward the treatment of a common condition

Notice that the only claim made by the author is that hypochondria is “more normal than most people realize. The author is not “arguing” anything about how “resources should be directed.”

CORRECT ANSWER(B) correcting a common misconception about the prevalence of a certain condition

As we discussed in the introduction to this explanation, the leading sentences of the paragraphs of the passage indicate that the primary purpose of the passage is to show that the common belief that hypochondria is rare is not correct because hypochondria is in fact prevalent.

Also, the other sentences of the paragraphs present statistics and examples that support the claims stated by the leading sentences.

Since “correcting a common misconception about the prevalence of a certain condition” matches “to show that the common belief that hypochondria is rare is not correct because hypochondria is in fact prevalent,” this choice accurately describes the primary purpose of the passage.

(C) demonstrating that people have long been aware of the prevalence of a certain condition

While the information presented by the second paragraph could be seen as “demonstrating” that at least some people have been aware of the prevalence of hypochondria, the main idea of the first paragraph is not that people have been aware of the prevalence of hypochondria. It’s that hypochondria is more normal than people realize.

So, this choice matches only the second paragraph, if anything, and does not describe the primary purpose of the passage as a whole.

(D) explaining why most people do not realize how normal a certain condition is

Notice that the passage is not “explaining why” most people do not realize how normal hypochondria is. Rather, it simply says that people do not realize how normal hypochondria is without explaining why they do not.

(E) contrasting the prevalence of a condition in the present with the prevalence of that condition in the past

While the passage indicates that hypochondria is prevalent in the present and that hypochondria was prevalent in the past, this choice is incorrect because the passage does not “contrast” the past and present prevalence of hypochondria. In other words, the passage does not show that the prevalence of hypochondria has been different during different time periods.

Correct answer: B
Frequently Asked Questions

In addition to identifying the main point of a passage by using the leading sentences of paragraphs as clues, we can use other clues to find the main point. Let’s discuss those clues now.

topics.topicName: 2.8 Seek Out Opinions to find the Important Points of a Passage
topics.content:
2. Primary Purpose, Structure, Tone and Specific Purpose

2.8 Seek Out Opinions to find the Important Points of a Passage

Since opinions of the author or of others mentioned by a passage are generally strongly connected to important points of the passage, we can often identify main points by finding opinions.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

Since opinions of the author or of others mentioned by the passage are generally strongly connected to main points of a passage, we can often identify main points by finding opinions.

One way we can find opinions in a passage is to look for statements that include opinion markers. We’ll discuss opinion markers in more detail shortly, but for now, here’s a list of common opinion markers:

argue that, assert, believe, claim, contend, opinion, propose, clearly, should

It’s easy to see why these words are called opinion markers. After all, when, for instance, someone argues or asserts something or says what should be, that person is stating an opinion.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

One way we can find opinions in a passage is to look for statements that include opinion markers.

For example, a passage could say the following:

Clearly, the bulk of the evidence shows that leaders did not truly seek to avoid the predictable conflict.

The above sentence uses the opinion marker “clearly” and strongly states the author’s opinion regarding what the bulk of the evidence shows. When we see a statement like that one in a passage, we have likely found a main point of the passage.

Here’s another example:

His incremental approach has often been criticized. However, many commentators of his time contended that he was a reformer who was taking practical steps to improve the situation.

This example uses the opinion marker “contended” in presenting the opinion “that he was a reformer who was taking practical steps ….” Now, even though that opinion is the opinion of “commentators of his time” rather than the opinion of the author, if the above sentences were within a passage, that opinion of the “commentators” would likely be connected to a main point of the passage, because opinions of people mentioned by passages are generally connected to passage main points.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

Opinions of people mentioned by passages are generally connected to passage main points.

For the purpose of identifying main points, it’s also helpful to note that many passages will involve some kind of contrast between different ideas or opinions.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

For the purpose of identifying main points, it’s helpful to note that many passages will involve some kind of contrast between different ideas or opinions.

So, pay close attention to contrast markers, such as “however,” “although, or “but.” These contrast markers often indicate opinions and, thus, indicate important points that we should pay close attention to.

Consider the following example:

Example 4

S1: Among most scholars, it is settled that Albert Einstein was a masterful physicist who deserves credit for work that forms the foundation of contemporary physics. S2: However, in her book In the Shadow of Albert Einstein: The Tragic Life of Mileva Einstein-Maric, Desanka Trbuhovic-Gjuric contends that this view is not accurate and that much of the credit should go to Mileva Einstein-Maric, the first wife of Albert Einstein. S3: Describing Einstein-Maric as an accomplished mathematician and physicist, Trbuhovic-Gjuric makes the case that Einstein and Einstein-Maric collaborated and that Einstein-Maric co-authored Einstein’s famous paper on relativity. S4: As evidence for these claims, Trbuhovic-Gjuric cites historical events and statements made by Einstein and Einstein-Maric, such as “I need my wife. S5: She solves for me all my mathematical problems.”

S6: Having examined the evidence cited by Trbuhovic-Gjuric and others who share Trbuhovic-Gjuric’s view, Galina Weinstein of Boston University asserts that the idea that Einstein-Maric made a significant unrecognized contribution to the field of physics exaggerates Einstein-Maric’s role. S7: For instance, Weinstein points out that, in correspondence cited as evidence that Einstein and Einstein-Maric collaborated, all ideas about physics discussed are Einstein’s. S8: Clearly, the more convincing case is Weinstein’s. S9: Her painstaking review of the evidence reveals that there is little support for the claim that Einstein-Maric played a major role in the creation of Einstein’s work. S10: Thus, while Mileva Einstein-Maric’s story is interesting in many ways, it is not the story of a forgotten contributor that some have made it out to be.

The passage is primary concerned with

evaluating contradictory positions on an individual’s contributions

contrasting the research methods used by two historians

explaining why an individual’s contributions have been forgotten

presenting the evidence for and against a certain conclusion

showing that historians often make claims without sufficient evidence

Example 4 - Question 1

easy

S1: Among most scholars, it is settled that Albert Einstein was a masterful physicist who deserves credit for work that forms the foundation of contemporary physics. S2: However, in her book In the Shadow of Albert Einstein: The Tragic Life of Mileva Einstein-Maric, Desanka Trbuhovic-Gjuric contends that this view is not accurate and that much of the credit should go to Mileva Einstein-Maric, the first wife of Albert Einstein. S3: Describing Einstein-Maric as an accomplished mathematician and physicist, Trbuhovic-Gjuric makes the case that Einstein and Einstein-Maric collaborated and that Einstein-Maric co-authored Einstein’s famous paper on relativity. S4: As evidence for these claims, Trbuhovic-Gjuric cites historical events and statements made by Einstein and Einstein-Maric, such as “I need my wife. S5: She solves for me all my mathematical problems.”

S6: Having examined the evidence cited by Trbuhovic-Gjuric and others who share Trbuhovic-Gjuric’s view, Galina Weinstein of Boston University asserts that the idea that Einstein-Maric made a significant unrecognized contribution to the field of physics exaggerates Einstein-Maric’s role. S7: For instance, Weinstein points out that, in correspondence cited as evidence that Einstein and Einstein-Maric collaborated, all ideas about physics discussed are Einstein’s. S8: Clearly, the more convincing case is Weinstein’s. S9: Her painstaking review of the evidence reveals that there is little support for the claim that Einstein-Maric played a major role in the creation of Einstein’s work. S10: Thus, while Mileva Einstein-Maric’s story is interesting in many ways, it is not the story of a forgotten contributor that some have made it out to be.

QUESTION
Showing:
Question

The passage is primary concerned with

evaluating contradictory positions on an individual’s contributions

contrasting the research methods used by two historians

explaining why an individual’s contributions have been forgotten

presenting the evidence for and against a certain conclusion

showing that historians often make claims without sufficient evidence
Previous Confirm Finish
Show solution Hide solution
PRESENTED BY :
Scott Woodbury-Stewart Founder and Expert GMAT Instructor Scott Woodbury-Stewart Founder and Expert GMAT Instructor

Text Solution:

Reading this passage, we quickly see that it mentions some opinions. So, for the purpose of identifying the primary purpose of the passage, we can home in on those opinions because, as we know, opinions mentioned or expressed in a passage are generally closely connected to the primary purpose.

In the first paragraph, we see that S2 includes the opinion marker “contends” in “Desanka Trbuhovic-Gjuric contends that this view is not accurate and that much of the credit should go to Mileva Einstein-Maric.”

Since “this view” in S2 must refer to the view that “Albert Einstein was a masterful physicist who deserves credit for work …,” we can see that Trbuhovic-Gjuric’s opinion is that Einstein-Maric deserves “much of the credit” given to Einstein.

The next important point we come to is indicated by the opinion marker “asserts” in S5, which says, “Galina Weinstein of Boston University asserts that the idea that Einstein-Maric made a significant unrecognized contribution to the field of physics exaggerates Einstein-Maric’s role.”

We can see that the passage is saying that Weinstein disagrees with Trbuhovic-Gjuric regarding the contribution of Einstein-Maric.

Notice that, so far, the author has not expressed an opinion of her own.

The final important point in the passage is indicated by the opinion marker “clearly” in S7, which says, “Clearly, the more convincing case is Weinstein’s.” In this case, the opinion expressed is that of the author, who has come down on the side of the idea that Einstein-Maric did not play “a major role in the creation of Einstein’s work.”

Having found and reviewed these important points, we now have a clear sense of the purpose of this passage, which appears to be something along the lines of to evaluate two contrasting opinions about the contributions of Mileva Einstein-Maric.

CORRECT ANSWER(A) evaluating contradictory positions on an individual’s contributions

In considering the important points of this passage in the introduction to this explanation, we saw that two important points involve the opinions of Trbuhovic-Gjuric and Weinstein, which are contrasting, or “contradictory” opinions on Mileva Einstein-Maric’s contributions. So, “contradictory positions on an individual’s contributions” in this choice matches the passage.

The third important point we discussed is the author’s own opinion, S7, “Clearly, the more convincing case is Weinstein’s.”

We can see that S7 indicates that the author has evaluated the opinions of Trbuhovic-Gjuric and Weinstein and decided that Weinstein’s is the more valid one.

So, this choice accurately describes what the author does, in other words, it describes the primary purpose of the passage.

(B) contrasting the research methods used by two historians

This choice starts off correctly, because the passage does present a contrast, the contrast between the opinions of Trbuhovic-Gjuric and Weinstein.

However, this choice goes wrong partway through, because the passage does not contrast “research methods.”

(C) explaining why an individual’s contributions have been forgotten

Notice that this choice contradicts the passage. The last sentence of the passage says that Mileva Einstein-Maric’s story “is not the story of a forgotten contributor.” So, the passage does not explain why “an individual’s contributions have been forgotten.” Rather it implies that the contributions were not made.

(D) presenting the evidence for and against a certain conclusion

As we can see by considering the passage’s important points discussed in the introduction to this explanation, the passage is focused on evaluating two opinions about Mileva Einstein-Maric, not on presenting the evidence on which those opinions are based.

The passage does mention a little evidence, but presenting evidence is not the primary purpose.

(E) showing that historians often make claims without sufficient evidence

As we can see by considering the passage’s important points discussed in the introduction to this explanation, the passage is focused on evaluating two opinions about Mileva Einstein-Maric, not on “showing that historians often make claims without sufficient evidence.”

In particular, notice that the author’s own opinion, S7, is “Clearly, the more convincing case is Weinstein’s.” We can see that the author is not asserting anything about “sufficient evidence.” Rather, the author has decided that one opinion is “more convincing.”

Correct answer: A
Frequently Asked Questions

Let’s now discuss how strong language often serves as a clue to what the main idea of a passage is.

topics.topicName: 2.9 Strong Language Often Indicates a Main Point of a Passage.
topics.content:
2. Primary Purpose, Structure, Tone and Specific Purpose

2.9 Strong Language Often Indicates a Main Point of a Passage.

We must always be on the lookout for the use of strong language because the use of strong language will provide us with valuable clues as to what the main point of a passage is.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

We must always be on the lookout for the use of strong language because the use of strong language will provide us with valuables clues as to what the main point of a passage is.

For example, when an author says, “A more convincing explanation is that …,” we must pay close attention to what that “more convincing explanation” is. “More” is a comparison marker, and “convincing” means “believable.” So, when the author says, “a more convincing explanation,” the author is making the strong statement that he believes that his explanation is better than the explanation proposed by someone else. That explanation would likely be a strong clue to help us determine the primary purpose of the passage.

Consider the following example.

Example 5

S1: One theme common to authoritarian regimes is the silencing of dissenting voices. S2: Such governments typically vigorously employ various means, including restrictive laws, surveillance, and brute force, to prevent both individuals and organizations from expressing opinions that do not match the narratives the regimes seek to promote. S3: Ironically, it is rather easy for any observer of political matters to understand how success in silencing dissenting voices can lead to the collapse of the very regime that sought to achieve that success.

S4: In suppressing speech, a regime reduces the flow of not only information that threatens the stability of the regime but also information necessary for the functioning of the regime or of the society over which the regime wields power—often, these two types of information are either difficult to distinguish or one and the same. S5: As a result, both the regime and the society can become deprived of critical information. S6: Initially, it may appear that the regime can survive the lack of such information, and some repressive authoritarian regimes do remain in power for long periods of time. S7: However, in a large proportion of cases, a regime operating without sufficient information will make major missteps as a result, causing itself or the society over which it wields power to experience extreme instability or deterioration that leads to the, sometimes dramatic, downfall of the regime.

The passage is primarily concerned with

identifying reasons why it is impossible for an authoritarian regime to remain in power long-term

advocating for allowing individuals and organizations to express their opinions freely

explaining why a governmental practice often has unintended effects

presenting a characteristic that all authoritarian regimes have in common

comparing the effects of different forms of government on societies

Example 5 - Question 1

easy

S1: One theme common to authoritarian regimes is the silencing of dissenting voices. S2: Such governments typically vigorously employ various means, including restrictive laws, surveillance, and brute force, to prevent both individuals and organizations from expressing opinions that do not match the narratives the regimes seek to promote. S3: Ironically, it is rather easy for any observer of political matters to understand how success in silencing dissenting voices can lead to the collapse of the very regime that sought to achieve that success.

S4: In suppressing speech, a regime reduces the flow of not only information that threatens the stability of the regime but also information necessary for the functioning of the regime or of the society over which the regime wields power—often, these two types of information are either difficult to distinguish or one and the same. S5: As a result, both the regime and the society can become deprived of critical information. S6: Initially, it may appear that the regime can survive the lack of such information, and some repressive authoritarian regimes do remain in power for long periods of time. S7: However, in a large proportion of cases, a regime operating without sufficient information will make major missteps as a result, causing itself or the society over which it wields power to experience extreme instability or deterioration that leads to the, sometimes dramatic, downfall of the regime.

QUESTION
Showing:
Question

The passage is primarily concerned with

identifying reasons why it is impossible for an authoritarian regime to remain in power long-term

advocating for allowing individuals and organizations to express their opinions freely

explaining why a governmental practice often has unintended effects

presenting a characteristic that all authoritarian regimes have in common

comparing the effects of different forms of government on societies
Previous Confirm Finish
Show solution Hide solution
PRESENTED BY :
Scott Woodbury-Stewart Founder and Expert GMAT Instructor Scott Woodbury-Stewart Founder and Expert GMAT Instructor

Text Solution:

Let’s see how strong language helps us to determine what the primary purpose of this passage is.

Notice that the first two sentence of the passages are descriptive. They describe what authoritarian regimes do, and they don’t directly state any opinion of the author’s.

Then, boom, S3 hits the reader with a strong opinion.

S3 starts off with an opinionated word, “ironically.” This word is used to make a point, the point that, while authoritarian regimes “vigorously employ various means … to prevent both individuals and organizations from expressing opinions,” there is something ironic about the situation.

S3 then continues by making a strong statement, “it is rather easy for any observer of political matters to understand ….” We can see that the author is communicating that what he’s saying is not only ironic but also “rather easy … to understand.”

Finally, we see that in S3 the author uses emphatic language, “the collapse of the very regime that sought to achieve that success.”

So, given how strong a statement S3 is, it’s likely that S3 is a clue indicating what the primary purpose of the passage is.

Since S3 discusses the idea of “how success in silencing dissenting voices can lead to the collapse of the very regime that sought to achieve that success,” the primary purpose of the passage is likely connected to that idea.

In fact, as we may have expected after reading S3, the 2nd paragraph outlines exactly how “success in silencing dissenting voices can lead to the collapse of the very regime that sought to achieve that success.”

So, we can see that the primary purpose of the passage is something along the lines of to explain how “success in silencing dissenting voices can lead to the collapse of the very regime that sought to achieve that success.”

(A) identifying reasons why it is impossible for an authoritarian regime to remain in power long-term

This choice starts off somewhat correctly, because the passage does discuss reasons why suppressing speech can cause an authoritarian regime to go out of power. However, notice that the passage is not focused on “identifying reasons.” Rather it is focused on explaining why one practice, “silencing dissenting voices,” can lead to the collapse of regimes.

Also, this choice conflicts with what the passage says. After all, rather than say, “it is impossible for an authoritarian regime to remain in power long-term,” S6 says, “some repressive authoritarian regimes do remain in power for long periods of time.”

(B) advocating for allowing individuals and organizations to express their opinions freely

This choice could be tempting because “advocating for allowing …” means “arguing in favor of allowing …,” and what the author says about the consequences of preventing “both individuals and organizations from expressing opinions” does indicate that allowing individuals and organizations to express their opinions freely is a good idea.

Notice, however, that the author does not argue in favor of anything. Rather, he explains why silencing dissent can lead to the collapse of a regime.

CORRECT ANSWER(C) explaining why a governmental practice often has unintended effects

In the introduction to this explanation, we decided that the primary purpose of the passage is something along the lines of to explain how “success in silencing dissenting voices can lead to the collapse of the very regime that sought to achieve that success.”

We can see that this choice matches quite well with what we came up with. After all, “explaining why” matches “to explain how,” “a governmental practice” matches “silencing dissenting voices,” and “often has unintended effects” matches “can lead to the collapse of the very regime that sought to achieve that success.”

So, this choice accurately describes the primary purpose of the passage.

(D) presenting a characteristic that all authoritarian regimes have in common

If you picked this choice, you may have noticed that S1 presents “silencing of dissenting voices” as “a theme common to authoritarian regimes,” and that S2 further discusses this characteristic of authoritarian regimes.

However, the correct answer to a primary purpose of the passage must capture the purpose of the passage as a whole, and we see from the strong language of S3 and the explanation presented in the 2nd paragraph that the passage does much more than present “silencing of dissenting voices” as a characteristic of authoritarian regimes.

So, this choice describes a small part of the passage, not the primary purpose of the passage as a whole.

(E) comparing the effects of different forms of government on societies

Notice that this choice mentions “different forms of government,” whereas the passage is about only one form of government, authoritarian government.

Also, the passage is not “comparing the effects” of multiple things. Rather it explains the effects of one thing, “silencing dissenting voices.”

Correct answer: C
Frequently Asked Questions

Let’s now discuss how conclusions stated by a passage are always connected to the primary purpose.

topics.topicName: 2.10 Conclusions Stated by a Passage are Always Connected to the Primary Purpose
topics.content:
2. Primary Purpose, Structure, Tone and Specific Purpose

2.10 Conclusions Stated by a Passage are Always Connected to the Primary Purpose

In reading an RC passage, we should always pay attention to conclusions stated by the author because these conclusions are always clues alerting us to the primary purpose of the passage.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

In reading an RC passage, we should always pay attention to conclusions stated by the author because these conclusions are always clues alerting us to the primary purpose of the passage.

For example, a passage could say “Thus, the cycle of poverty is actually reinforced by heavy-handed minimum wage policies.”

“Thus” is a conclusion marker. If this sentence were found in a passage, the conclusion it expresses would certainly be center stage in the author’s main idea.

We’ll discuss conclusion markers in more depth shortly, but for now, here’s a list of common conclusion markers:

therefore, thus, in summary, in conclusion, in closing, in essence, in short, in any event, all things considered, all in all, by and large, for this reason

Keep an eye peeled for these, and any other, conclusion markers as they’ll help us identify conclusions and home in on a passage’s primary purpose.

Consider the following example.

Example 6

S1: As use of social media has become widespread, organizations have increasingly engaged in the practice of checking out job applicants’ social media profiles as part of their hiring processes. S2: However, much of the information that can be gathered from social media profiles, such as relationship status or political views, is not directly relevant to employment yet can influence the hiring decisions of managers, who are swayed by this information because of personal biases or because they mistakenly believe it to be indicative of future job performance. S3: Therefore, a thorough assessment of the value of “social media mining” appears to be in order. S4: In fact, recently, a study was undertaken for the purpose of determining whether the use of social media mining during the hiring process truly benefits employers. S5: The researchers conducting the study first obtained supervisors’ ratings for 81 employees and then had recruiters seek to predict the job performance of those 81 employees by reviewing the employees’ social media profiles. S6: Despite the fact that the recruiters had been advised of best practices for using social media for candidate evaluation, the recruiters’ predictions of job performance did not match the actual performance of the employees who participated in the study. S7: For this reason and others, such as the questionable legality of using certain types of information found on social media profiles in making hiring decisions, companies considering using social media mining should proceed with caution until its net impacts are better understood.

The author of the passage is primarily concerned with

recommending best practices for using social media for candidate evaluation

questioning the legality of using information from social media profiles in making hiring decisions

presenting the advantages and disadvantages of social media mining

suggesting further evaluation of social media mining

explaining why social media mining is increasingly used by organizations

Example 6 - Question 1

easy

S1: As use of social media has become widespread, organizations have increasingly engaged in the practice of checking out job applicants’ social media profiles as part of their hiring processes. S2: However, much of the information that can be gathered from social media profiles, such as relationship status or political views, is not directly relevant to employment yet can influence the hiring decisions of managers, who are swayed by this information because of personal biases or because they mistakenly believe it to be indicative of future job performance. S3: Therefore, a thorough assessment of the value of “social media mining” appears to be in order. S4: In fact, recently, a study was undertaken for the purpose of determining whether the use of social media mining during the hiring process truly benefits employers. S5: The researchers conducting the study first obtained supervisors’ ratings for 81 employees and then had recruiters seek to predict the job performance of those 81 employees by reviewing the employees’ social media profiles. S6: Despite the fact that the recruiters had been advised of best practices for using social media for candidate evaluation, the recruiters’ predictions of job performance did not match the actual performance of the employees who participated in the study. S7: For this reason and others, such as the questionable legality of using certain types of information found on social media profiles in making hiring decisions, companies considering using social media mining should proceed with caution until its net impacts are better understood.

QUESTION
Showing:
Question

The author of the passage is primarily concerned with

recommending best practices for using social media for candidate evaluation

questioning the legality of using information from social media profiles in making hiring decisions

presenting the advantages and disadvantages of social media mining

suggesting further evaluation of social media mining

explaining why social media mining is increasingly used by organizations
Previous Confirm Finish
Show solution Hide solution
PRESENTED BY :
Scott Woodbury-Stewart Founder and Expert GMAT Instructor Scott Woodbury-Stewart Founder and Expert GMAT Instructor

Text Solution:

As we know, conclusions stated in a passage are clues alerting us to the primary purpose of the passage.

In reading this passage we see two conclusions.

S3 begins with the conclusion marker “therefore” and states the conclusion “a thorough assessment of the value of “social media mining” appears to be in order.”

S7 begins with the conclusion marker “For this reason and others” and states the conclusion “companies considering using social media mining should proceed with caution until its net impacts are better understood.”

Now, notice that, in this context, “net impacts” in S7 has a meaning similar to “value” in S3. After all, the “net impacts” of social media mining represent its “value” to organizations.

Also, the two conclusions “a thorough assessment of the value … appears to be in order” and “companies … should proceed with caution” are basically a proposal and a recommendation.

So, just by considering those two conclusions, we get the sense the theme of this passage is proposing or recommending assessment of the “value” of social media mining.

Meanwhile, most of the rest of the passage, such as “much of the information … is not directly relevant to employment,” and the information about the study, supports those two conclusions. So, the purpose of the entire passage appears to be to state and support those two conclusions.

So, the primary purpose of this passage appears to be something along the lines of to propose or recommend assessment of the value of social media mining.

(A) recommending best practices for using social media for candidate evaluation

This choice starts off correctly, because the passage does make a recommendation in S7 when it says, “companies considering using social media mining should ….”

However, it does not recommend “best practices for using social media.” It recommends that companies “proceed with caution until its net impacts are better understood.”

(B) questioning the legality of using information from social media profiles in making hiring decisions

The passage does mention “the questionable legality of using … information found on social media profiles.”

However, neither of the two conclusions stated in the passage is about “the legality of using information from social media profiles,” and this topic is mentioned only briefly at the end of the passage.

So, this choice does not capture the primary purpose of the passage as a whole.

(C) presenting the advantages and disadvantages of social media mining

Notice that the passage presents no “advantages” of social media mining. So, this choice mentions something the passage simply does not do.

CORRECT ANSWER(D) suggesting further evaluation of social media mining

As we discussed in the introduction to this explanation, the theme of the two conclusions stated in the passage is proposing or recommending assessment of the value of social media mining. Also, most of the rest of the passage provides support for those two conclusions.

Thus, since, “suggesting further evaluation of social media mining” means about the same thing as “proposing or recommending assessment of the value of social media mining,” this choice accurately describes the primary purpose of the passage.

(E) explaining why social media mining is increasingly used by organizations

S1, “As use of social media has become widespread, organizations have increasingly engaged in the practice …,” could perhaps be described as “explaining why social media mining is increasingly used.”

However, neither of the two conclusions stated in the passage involves explaining why social media mining is increasingly used, and no other part of the passage explains why social media mining is used.

So, this choice does not describe the primary purpose of the passage as a whole.

Correct answer: D
Frequently Asked Questions

Let’s now discuss how a conclusion stated by a passage’s last sentence may be the passage’s main point.

topics.topicName: 2.11 A Conclusion Stated by a Passage’s Last Sentence May Be its Main Point
topics.content:
2. Primary Purpose, Structure, Tone and Specific Purpose

2.11 A Conclusion Stated by a Passage’s Last Sentence May Be its Main Point

Sometimes, the last sentence of a passage will state a conclusion of the author’s. In such a case, we have found a great clue because, generally, a conclusion stated by the last sentence of a passage will either be the main point of the entire passage or be strongly connected to the primary purpose of the passage.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

Generally, a conclusion stated by the last sentence of a passage will either be the main point of the entire passage or be strongly connected to the primary purpose of the passage.

The reason why a conclusion stated by the last sentence of a passage is such a great clue is that, often, when an author argues in favor of a specific point, he or she captures his or her main idea in the final sentence of the passage.

When working through the following example, take care to notice how the last sentence of the passage brings the primary purpose of the passage into sharp focus.

Example 7

S1: In the early 20th century, Leslie County, Kentucky had very few physicians and poor roads, and thus it was extremely difficult for people living there to access medical care. S2: To address this issue, Mary Breckenridge, a certified nurse midwife, founded in 1925 the Frontier Nursing Service (FNS), which employed nurse midwives and grew to include several clinics. S3: While nurse midwives were not licensed to prescribe medicine, the FNS worked with an advisory group of physicians who set up guidelines for the nurses to follow in situations in which a physician was not present. S4: Under this framework, the nurses were able to legally provide treatment and medication to patients who would not otherwise have received them, with the result that, according to multiple measures, average health outcomes in Leslie County were better than those in the U.S. as a whole.

S5: The success of the FNS is just one example of what can be achieved when nurses are able to work to the full extent of their training. S6: Nevertheless, in the current regulatory environment, nurses are restricted from providing many of the types of services that the nurses of the FNS provided. S7: Meanwhile, in many ways, the current strains on the healthcare system resemble the reasons why the FNS was created. S8: Therefore, a review and adjustment of regulations that constrain nursing should be undertaken to make it possible for nurses to play a greater role in healthcare and meet needs that are currently going unmet.

The primary purpose of the passage is to

demonstrate that a regulatory change would result in a beneficial outcome

correct a common misconception about the role of nurses in healthcare

present various alternatives to the treatment of patients by physicians

outline the achievements of a unique organization

address concerns about allowing non-physicians to provide treatment and medication

Example 7 - Question 1

easy

S1: In the early 20th century, Leslie County, Kentucky had very few physicians and poor roads, and thus it was extremely difficult for people living there to access medical care. S2: To address this issue, Mary Breckenridge, a certified nurse midwife, founded in 1925 the Frontier Nursing Service (FNS), which employed nurse midwives and grew to include several clinics. S3: While nurse midwives were not licensed to prescribe medicine, the FNS worked with an advisory group of physicians who set up guidelines for the nurses to follow in situations in which a physician was not present. S4: Under this framework, the nurses were able to legally provide treatment and medication to patients who would not otherwise have received them, with the result that, according to multiple measures, average health outcomes in Leslie County were better than those in the U.S. as a whole.

S5: The success of the FNS is just one example of what can be achieved when nurses are able to work to the full extent of their training. S6: Nevertheless, in the current regulatory environment, nurses are restricted from providing many of the types of services that the nurses of the FNS provided. S7: Meanwhile, in many ways, the current strains on the healthcare system resemble the reasons why the FNS was created. S8: Therefore, a review and adjustment of regulations that constrain nursing should be undertaken to make it possible for nurses to play a greater role in healthcare and meet needs that are currently going unmet.

QUESTION
Showing:
Question

The primary purpose of the passage is to

demonstrate that a regulatory change would result in a beneficial outcome

correct a common misconception about the role of nurses in healthcare

present various alternatives to the treatment of patients by physicians

outline the achievements of a unique organization

address concerns about allowing non-physicians to provide treatment and medication
Previous Confirm Finish
Show solution Hide solution
PRESENTED BY :
Scott Woodbury-Stewart Founder and Expert GMAT Instructor Scott Woodbury-Stewart Founder and Expert GMAT Instructor

Text Solution:

As we have discussed, problems and solutions discussed in passages are often connected to the primary purposes of the passages. So, the fact that this passage begins by presenting a problem, “it was extremely difficult for people living there to access medical care,” and a solution, “the Frontier Nursing service,” is a clue indicating that the primary purpose of the passage likely has something to do with solving a problem.

Next the passage presents a contrast in S3, “While nurse midwives were not licensed to prescribe medicine, the FNS worked with an advisory group of physicians who set up guidelines for the nurses to follow.” Contrasts presented by passages are often clues indicating what the primary purpose is, and notice that, like the earlier sentences of the passage, S3 presents a problem, “nurse midwives were not licensed to prescribe medicine,” and a solution, “guidelines for the nurses to follow.”

The 1st paragraph concludes by indicating that a problem was indeed solved: “health outcomes in Leslie County were better than those in the U.S. as a whole.”

The 2nd paragraph starts by saying that the problem and solution presented in the first paragraph are “just one example of what can be achieved when nurses are able to work to the full extent of their training.”

Then the 2nd paragraph goes on to communicate that this type of problem solving is hindered in the “current regulatory environment” yet needed because of “strains on the healthcare system.”

Finally, the passage concludes with a strong opinion of the author’s, “a review and adjustment of regulations that constrain nursing should be undertaken.”

Interestingly, this last sentence of the passage makes the primary purpose of the passage clear. The author presented the example of the FNS and discussed “the current regulatory environment” and “strains on the healthcare system” all for the purpose of supporting the point stated by the last sentence of the passage about what “should” be done with regards to “regulations that constrain nursing.”

So, we can see that the last sentence of the passage states the main point of the passage and that the primary purpose of the passage is to present and support the main point stated by the last sentence of the passage.

CORRECT ANSWER(A) demonstrate that a regulatory change would result in a beneficial outcome

As we discussed in the introduction to this explanation, the purpose of the passage is to present and support the main point stated by the last sentence of the passage, “a review and adjustment of regulations that constrain nursing should be undertaken.”

We see that “regulatory change” in this choice matches the primary purpose of the passage. So, does the entire choice correctly describe the primary purpose?

Notice that, by presenting the achievements of the FNS and mentioning “the current regulatory environment” and “strains on the healthcare system,” the passage supports the point stated by the last sentence by demonstrating that “adjustment of regulations that constrain nursing” would result in the beneficial outcome associated with allowing nurses “to work to the full extent of their training.”

So, this choice perfectly describes the primary purpose of the passage.

(B) correct a common misconception about the role of nurses in healthcare

The passage does not mention any “misconception about the role of nurses in healthcare.” So, while it’s possible that what the passage says would correct such a misconception, correcting a misconception is not the purpose of the passage.

(C) present various alternatives to the treatment of patients by physicians

The first sign that this choice is incorrect is that it uses the plural “various alternatives,” whereas the passage is about one alternative to treatment of patients by physicians, the treatment of patients by nurses.

Also, the passage discusses not only treatment of patients by nurses but also the “current regulatory environment” and “strains on the healthcare system,” and states the opinion that “a review and adjustment of regulations … should the undertaken.”

So, this choice captures only part of what the passage does, not the primary purpose of the passage as a whole.

(D) outline the achievements of a unique organization

The first sign that this choice is incorrect is that it describes the FNS as a “unique organization,” whereas the passage does not say that FNS is “unique.”

Also, the passage discusses not only the achievements of the FNA but also the “current regulatory environment” and “strains on the healthcare system,” and states the opinion that “a review and adjustment of regulations … should the undertaken.”

So, this choice captures only part of what the passage does, not the primary purpose of the passage as a whole.

(E) address concerns about allowing non-physicians to provide treatment and medication

Notice that the passage does not really address any concerns. It simply states that the nurses of the FNS provided treatment and medication without mentioning or addressing any concerns about their doing so.

Correct answer: A
Frequently Asked Questions

Let’s now discuss causes and effects and how any discussion of them is usually linked to the primary purpose of the passage in which such discussions are found.

topics.topicName: 2.12 Discussions of Causes and Effects are Generally Connected to the Primary Purpose of a Passage
topics.content:
2. Primary Purpose, Structure, Tone and Specific Purpose

2.12 Discussions of Causes and Effects are Generally Connected to the Primary Purpose of a Passage

Authors, in addition to people mentioned in passages, often discuss cause-and-effect relationships. In other words, they often seek to explain why something has happened or will happen, and often, these cause-and-effect relationships take center stage in the passage’s primary purpose.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

Cause-and-effect relationships often take center stage in the primary purpose of a passage.

The reason cause-and-effect relationships discussed in a passage are typically connected to a passage’s primary purpose is that authors generally mention cause-and-effect relationships to make important points. Therefore, by noticing discussions of causes and effects, we can identify important points of a passage and thus provide ourselves with strong clues about the primary purpose of a passage.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

By noticing discussions of causes and effects, we can identify important points of a passage and thus provide ourselves with strong clues about the primary purpose of a passage.

For noticing cause and effect, it’s helpful to pay close attention to causation markers. We’ll discuss causation markers in more detail shortly, but for now, here’s a list of common causation markers:

caused by, because, due to, attributed to, explanation, explained by, resulted from, as a result of, consequently, reason, thus

For example, an author may say, “this event was caused by multiple factors” or “the reason for this pattern is clear.” In each case, by noticing the causation marker, we can tell that the author is discussing a cause-and-effect relationship that’s probably related to an important point of the passage.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

Causation markers signal that a passage is discussing a cause-and-effect relationship that’s probably related to an important point of the passage.

In considering the following example, notice how paying attention to discussion of cause and effect helps with identifying the primary purpose.

Example 8

S1: During the Great Recession that began in 2008, major financial markets lost more than 30 percent of their value in one of the most horrific market crashes ever seen. S2: However, the origins of the crash can be attributed to events that began almost a decade earlier. S3: Beginning in 1999, mortgage borrowers referred to as “subprime borrowers,” who had low credit scores and a high risk of defaulting on their loans, were allowed to take out mortgages that started out with low monthly payments that quickly became larger after a few years. S4: By fall of 2008, these borrowers, unable to pay the higher monthly payments, were defaulting on their loans in large numbers, causing chaos in the financial markets, a stock market collapse, and a global Great Recession.

The primary purpose of the passage is to

compare one market crash with others

suggest ways of preventing recessions

explain why many subprime borrowers defaulted on loans in 2008

advocate for increased regulation of financial markets

point out the factors that led to an economic debacle

Example 8 - Question 1

easy

S1: During the Great Recession that began in 2008, major financial markets lost more than 30 percent of their value in one of the most horrific market crashes ever seen. S2: However, the origins of the crash can be attributed to events that began almost a decade earlier. S3: Beginning in 1999, mortgage borrowers referred to as “subprime borrowers,” who had low credit scores and a high risk of defaulting on their loans, were allowed to take out mortgages that started out with low monthly payments that quickly became larger after a few years. S4: By fall of 2008, these borrowers, unable to pay the higher monthly payments, were defaulting on their loans in large numbers, causing chaos in the financial markets, a stock market collapse, and a global Great Recession.

QUESTION
Showing:
Question

The primary purpose of the passage is to

compare one market crash with others

suggest ways of preventing recessions

explain why many subprime borrowers defaulted on loans in 2008

advocate for increased regulation of financial markets

point out the factors that led to an economic debacle
Previous Confirm Finish
Show solution Hide solution
PRESENTED BY :
Scott Woodbury-Stewart Founder and Expert GMAT Instructor Scott Woodbury-Stewart Founder and Expert GMAT Instructor

Text Solution:

In reading this passage, we quickly notice that S2 uses the causation marker “attributed to” in discussing a cause-and-effect relationship. Simply put, “the origins of the crash can be attributed to events that began almost a decade earlier” means that “events that began almost a decade earlier” caused “the crash.”

Since S2 is the second sentence of the passage, and since it presents a cause-and-effect relationship, S2 is likely closely connected to the primary purpose of the passage.

Continuing to read the passage, we see that it goes on to discuss some events involving mortgage borrowers and then, in the last sentence, uses the causation marker “causing” to express that the mortgage borrowers’ “defaulting” caused “chaos in the financial markets, a stock market collapse, and a global Great Recession.”

Since, the passage makes a general statement early on about “events” that caused the crash and then closes with a more specific statement that borrowers’ “defaulting” caused the crash, the primary purpose of the passage appears to be something along the lines of to say what caused a certain market crash.

(A) compare one market crash with others

S1 does in a way compare the market crash discussed in this passage with other crashes by saying that it was “one of the most horrific market crashes ever seen.”

However, comparing the crash with others is not the primary purpose of the passage as a whole.

(B) suggest ways of preventing recessions

Notice that the passage does not “suggest” any “ways” to do anything. After reading the passage, we might have some ideas for preventing recessions, but any such ideas we would get by coming up with them on our own, not by reading about them in the passage.

(C) explain why many subprime borrowers defaulted on loans in 2008

The passage does “explain why many subprime borrowers defaulted on loans in 2008.”

However, as we can see by noticing the two mentions of what caused the crash, the passage does more than explain why borrowers defaulted. In other words, explaining why borrowers defaulted is just a part of the passage’s discussion of what caused the crash of 2008.

So, this choice captures only part of what the passage does, not the primary purpose of the passage as a whole.

(D) advocate for increased regulation of financial markets

While the facts presented by the passage could be considered reasons for increased regulation of the financial markets, the passage does not “advocate for (recommend) increased regulation.”

Rather the passage simply outlines the causes of the market crash and the recession that followed it without mentioning regulation or advocating for anything.

CORRECT ANSWER(E) point out the factors that led to an economic debacle

As we discussed in the introduction to this explanation, the statements about cause-and-effect relationships in the passage indicate that the purpose of the passage is to say what caused a certain market crash.

Since “point out” means basically “say” and “the factors that led to an economic debacle” matches “what caused a certain market crash,” we can see that this choice accurately describes the primary purpose of the passage.

Correct answer: E
Frequently Asked Questions

Let’s now discuss rhetorical questions and how they are used by authors to communicate their main ideas to us.
