topics.topicName: 2.25 Using Structural Markers to Enhance Understanding
topics.content:
2. Primary Purpose, Structure, Tone and Specific Purpose

2.25 Using Structural Markers to Enhance Understanding

Certain words serve as guideposts and help us understand the logic of a passage, the function of different elements of the passage, the relationships between ideas and facts, and the intention or viewpoint of the author.

These words are like little flags marking key points throughout a passage. So, it’s important to recognize the roles they play. These words are generally referred to as “structural keywords,” or just “keywords.” In this course, we’ll refer to them as “structural markers,” or just “markers.”

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

Structural markers can help us understand the logic of a passage, the function of different elements of the passage, the relationships between ideas and facts, and the intention or viewpoint of the author.

Markers can help us to navigate and understand both simple and complicated Reading Comprehension passages because these words directly tell us what the author is writing, why she’s writing it, what her major opinions are, and where she’s headed next.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

Markers can help us to navigate and understand both simple and complicated Reading Comprehension passages.

The most important types of markers to look out for are the following:

- Contrast Markers

- Agreement Markers

- Opinion Markers

- Conclusion Markers

- Support Markers

- Additional Point Markers

- Look Above Markers

- Causation Markers

- Rhetorical Question Markers

- Myth Markers

- Extreme Markers

- Qualifier Markers

Let’s now cover each of these types of markers.

Contrast Marker (indicates a contrast or disagreement):

however, but, although, yet, conversely, regardless, despite, in contrast, on the other hand, on the contrary, then again, nevertheless, instead

Notice that the contrast markers in the following examples are used to indicate a contrast or to show disagreement:

Tomatoes contain many important nutrients. However, not all nutritionists recommend eating them.

Georgia has mild winters. On the other hand, the summers are unbearably hot.

I choose to live in Georgia despite the ridiculously hot summers.

I may go see “Zoolander 2” tonight at the movie theater. Then again, I may wait for the rental.

I despise yard work. Conversely, I am proud of how the yard looks from the street when I’m done.

The guest list includes many annoying people. Regardless, I will attend to spend time with the host.

She isn’t a fan of heavy regulation. On the contrary, she is a libertarian.

Contrast markers can be useful to us because, typically, when authors use contrast markers, the authors are stating main points. So, we can use contrast markers as clues when we are seeking to determine what the primary purpose of a passage is.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

We can use contrast markers as clues when we are seeking to determine what the primary purpose of a passage is.

Also, since contrast markers often mark transitions between views or ideas, contrast markers are often extremely useful when we’re seeking to analyze the structure of a passage. For instance, as we will see many times in our study of RC, a passage may be structured to present different positions on a topic, and contrast markers may mark the points in the passage where the passage completes its discussion of one position and begins its discussion of another one.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

Since contrast markers often mark transitions between views or ideas, contrast markers are often extremely useful when we’re seeking to analyze the structure of a passage.

Agreement Marker (indicates agreement):

similarly, likewise, not only … but also, in fact

Notice that the markers in each of the following sentences are used to indicate agreement:

Some members of the team were skeptical. Similarly, the coach remained unconvinced.

Many theatergoers said that they had enjoyed the show. Likewise, critics have been enthusiastic.

Not only scientists, but also philosophers have adopted that view.

The opera did better than predicted. In fact, it was a huge success.

Opinion Marker (indicates that an opinion of the author or someone else is being presented):

argue that, assert, believe, claim, contend, opinion, propose, clearly, should

RC passages often express the opinions of the authors or mention opinions of other people. Since opinions are often important parts of RC passages, noticing that opinions are being expressed or mentioned can help us to understand a passage and identify its primary purpose.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

Since opinions are often important parts of RC passages, noticing that opinions are being expressed or mentioned can help us to understand a passage and identify its primary purpose.

In many cases, it’s easy to tell that an opinion is being presented because the opinion will be preceded by an opinion marker.

Consider the following examples in which opinion markers indicate that opinions are being expressed or mentioned:

Some historians have argued that few people expected the policies to be implemented.

While the preponderance of the data indicate that Earth is round, there are still individuals who claim that it is flat.

Dean Ornish proposed that dietary changes would solve the problem.

Her supporters have contended that the tone of her letters indicates otherwise.

Clearly, it is likely that the use of such an approach will have some benefits.

Before taking such measures, management should assess their likely effects on morale.

Conclusion Marker (introduces a conclusion):

therefore, thus, in summary, in conclusion, in closing, in essence, in short, in any event, all things considered, all in all, by and large, for this reason, clearly

Like opinions, conclusions are important parts of passages. So, since conclusion markers introduce conclusions, noticing conclusion markers can be very helpful to us as we seek to understand a passage, its primary purpose, and its structure.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

Conclusions are important parts of passages. So, since conclusion markers introduce conclusions, noticing conclusion markers can be very helpful to us as we seek to understand a passage, its primary purpose, and its structure.

Notice that the conclusion markers in the following sentences are used to introduce conclusions:

Therefore, all such sources can be considered reliable.

In summary, she needs to study more and socialize less.

In essence, Leonidas was the main proponent of the new approach.

All things considered, the campaign went well.

In any event, it is clear that he preferred to write short stories.

By and large, the team is playing well this season.

Support Marker (introduces evidence or an example):

for instance, in particular, in fact, for example, from the fact that, after all, because, since, as indicated by, due to, for the reason that, given that, this can be seen from, we know this by, the reason is that, as evidenced by, justified by, assuming

Support markers can be useful to us because, by noticing the use of support markers, we can discern relationships between sentences. After all, a sentence that uses a support marker will generally provide support for or expand upon a something stated by another sentence that appears before or after the sentence that uses a support marker.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

Support markers can be useful to us because, by noticing the use of support markers, we can discern relationships between sentences. After all, a sentence that uses a support marker will generally provide support for or expand upon something stated by another sentence that appears before or after the sentence that uses a support marker.

Notice that the support markers in the following sentences are used to introduce evidence or examples:

For instance, the glove did not fit on the hand of the defendant.

For example, they have often encountered wolves without incident.

In particular, this type of fungus cannot live in arid climates.

In fact, King Cobras almost never attack humans.

Given that the water is extremely hot, it is almost certainly sterile.

After all, this area of the continent remains forested.

His health was improving, as evidenced by the fact that he was writing again.

Additional Point Marker (indicates that the purpose of a sentence is to support a conclusion stated by a sentence probably located more than one sentence above):

furthermore, additionally, in addition, likewise, moreover, as well, also, similarly

As we have discussed, often, in a Reading Comprehension passage, an opinion or conclusion will be followed by supporting evidence or examples. Of course, in some cases, evidence or examples that support an opinion or conclusion will be presented in more than one sentence.

Often, the later sentences that support an opinion or conclusion begin with support markers of a particular type that we can call “additional point markers.” In other words, the second, third, or fourth sentence that provides support for an opinion or conclusion may begin with an additional point marker.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

Often, the later sentences that support an opinion or conclusion begin with additional point markers. In other words, the second, third, or fourth sentence that provides support for an opinion or conclusion may begin with an additional point marker.

To see an additional point marker in action, consider the following example:

The conclusion that animals enjoy music is well supported. For instance, monkeys given the ability to turn on or off a radio that played music turned the radio on frequently. Additionally, cats have been observed to move toward speakers and to purr when music composed for cats is played.

The above example begins with an opinion, “The conclusion that animals enjoy music is well supported.” That opinion is followed by two sentences that present supporting information. At the beginning of the second sentence that presents supporting information, we see the additional point marker “additionally.”

So, if this example were part of a passage, the presence of “additionally” would be a signal that the sentence “Additionally, cats were observed …” provides support for an opinion or conclusion stated by a sentence more than one sentence above “additionally.”

Let’s consider another example.

However, the trend toward the use of synthetic diamonds is not without drawbacks. After all, it results in redirection of resources away from developing countries. Furthermore, the production of a synthetic diamond requires a huge amount of energy.

This example begins with a conclusion about the trend toward use of synthetic diamonds. The sentences that follow the conclusion present examples that support the conclusion. At the beginning of the second sentence that presents an example, we see the additional point marker “furthermore.”

So, if this example were part of a passage, the presence of “furthermore” would be a signal that the sentence “Furthermore, the production …” provides support for an opinion or conclusion stated more than one sentence above “furthermore.”

Like other support markers, additional point markers can be very useful to us when we are looking for information within a passage because they indicate how sentences are connected.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

Like other support markers, additional point markers can be very useful to us when we are looking for information within a passage because they indicate how sentences are connected.

Let’s now do some Targeted Practice involving the markers that we have discussed so far.

Targeted Practice

Identify the type of the marker in boldface in each passage segment.

Question
1 of 6
0%
accuracy

While Mount Etna has not erupted recently, it is likely to continue to erupt regularly since it has been active for around 500,000 years and has not changed significantly since its first recorded eruption, which occurred in 390 BCE.

Explanation:

“Since” introduces information that provides support for the assertion that Mount Etna is likely to continue to erupt regularly. So, “since” is a support marker.

Correct answer: B
Next
Question
2 of 6
0%
accuracy

The two historians disagree regarding the purpose of the stone artifact and its age. However, they both agree that it was likely created within 100 miles of where it was found.

Explanation:

“However” is used to indicate that a contrast is being expressed. In this case, the fact that the historians agree regarding where the stone artifact was created is in contrast with the fact that they disagree regarding the purpose of the stone artifact and its age. So, “however” is a contrast marker.

Correct answer: A
Next
Question
3 of 6
0%
accuracy

Donovan’s actions were approved by local authorities. Furthermore, he has asserted that, even without such approval, they would have been legal.

Explanation:

In this context, “asserted” means “expressed the opinion.” So, “asserted” is an opinion marker.

Correct answer: A
Next
Question
4 of 6
0%
accuracy

Interestingly, the number of trees in the county has been increasing. In fact, because property owners have become more aware of the benefits of trees, in some areas of the county, the number of trees per acre of land has almost doubled.

Explanation:

In this context, “in fact” connects two sentences that state two facts that are in agreement: that the number of trees in the county has been increasing and that, in some areas of the county, the number of trees per acre of land has almost doubled. So, “in fact” is an agreement marker.

Correct answer: B
Next
Question
5 of 6
0%
accuracy

Clearly, the school did achieve at least some of what it was created to achieve. Students who attended it for as little as two years achieved significant improvements in all skill areas. Moreover, its students performed better on average than the students at any of the city’s other schools.

Explanation:

In this context, “moreover” introduces the second sentence that provides support for the conclusion “the school did achieve at least some of what it was created to achieve.” Support for that conclusion is also provided by the first sentence that follows the conclusion, “Students who attended it for a little as two years achieved ….” So, “moreover” is an additional point marker.

Correct answer: B
Next
Question
6 of 6
0%
accuracy

Not only do the economist’s writings include no mention of her dispute with French but also she did not bother to publicly refute any of the assertions he had made. Thus, it seems likely that she considered the matter unworthy of her attention.

Explanation:

In this context, “thus” introduces a conclusion that follows from the facts stated in the previous sentence. So, “thus” is a conclusion marker.

Correct answer: A
Finish

Let’s now consider the rest of the markers in our list.

Look Above Marker (indicates that a sentence is referring to something mentioned previously in the passage):

this X, these X, those X, such X, for example, for instance, also

As we know, the sentences in a Reading Comprehension passage never exist in isolation; each sentence has a connection to the sentences that precede it and to those that follow it. Therefore, we must maintain situational awareness at all times.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

The sentences in a Reading Comprehension passage never exist in isolation; each sentence has a connection to the sentences that precede it and to those that follow it.

Often, a RC question will ask us – either directly or indirectly – about something mentioned in a certain sentence in the passage, which we can refer to as the target sentence. Of course, to find the information we need for answering such a question, we’ll home in on the target sentence.

However, having located the target sentence in the passage, we may not yet have located the information we need for answering the question, because that information may lie not in the target sentence but in a sentence that precedes the target sentence. Therefore, to correctly answer RC questions, we’ll often need to “look above” the target sentence and reread the sentence or sentences that precede it.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

Often, to correctly answer RC questions, we’ll need to “look above” the target sentence and reread the sentence or sentences that precede it.

In fact, the need to “look above” the target sentence occurs so often that it’s worth memorizing some commonly used keywords that we’ll refer to as “look above markers.” These markers alert us to the fact that we are dealing with a situation such that it will likely be helpful for us to refer to the sentences preceding a target sentence.

The most common “look above markers” are the following:

this X, these X, those X, such X, for example, also

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

The most common “look above markers”:

this X, these X, those X, such X, for example, also

To see how look above markers work, consider the following example:

Prior to the end of the 19th century, physicists were of the belief that light demonstrated wave behavior only. However, by the beginning of the 20th century, scientific research had indicated that, in fact, light behaves not only as a wave but also as a particle. This discovery paved the way for further research in the fields of electromagnetism and quantum mechanics, which ultimately led to innovations in technology that are still widely used today.

When we notice the look above marker “this discovery,” we ask ourselves, “What discovery exactly?” Of course, the answer to that question can be found through “looking above” to the two sentences preceding “this discovery.” When we “look above,” we see that “this discovery” refers to the following:

by the beginning of the 20th century, scientific research had indicated that, in fact, light behaves not only as a wave but also as a particle.

It’s important to see that, had we not “looked above” to the two sentences preceding the look above marker “this discovery,” we quite possibly would have had an incomplete understanding of exact what the discovery was.

Let’s consider another example:

While sleeping, many species of animals, including humans, enter rapid eye movement sleep – or REM sleep – which is a phase of deep sleep during which random rapid eye movements occur. Spending sufficient time each night in this phase is essential to a person’s health and well-being. Although in humans, the conscious mind is asleep during REM sleep, we are able to breathe because our respiratory systems have evolved to be under both voluntary and involuntary control.

When we notice that look above marker “this phase,” we ask ourselves, “What phase exactly?” Of course, the answer to that question can be found be “looking above” to the two sentences preceding “this discovery.” We see that “this phase” refers to the following:

rapid eye movement sleep – or REM sleep – which is a phase of deep sleep during which random rapid eye movements occur

So, we can see how important it is to understand the relationship between a look above marker and the sentences that precede the look above marker.

Causation Marker (indicates that a cause-and-effect relationship is being discussed or mentioned):

caused by, because, due to, attributed to, explanation, explained by, resulted from, as a result of, consequently, reason, thus

Often, to correctly answer RC questions, we have to clearly understand cause-and-effect relationships discussed or mentioned in passages: we have to understand what is, and what is not, said to cause something else. Therefore, it’s useful to notice causation markers because, often, the fact that a cause-and-effect relationship is being discussed or mentioned will be indicated by the presence of a causation marker in a passage or answer choice.

Notice how causation markers indicate that causes and effects are discussed or mentioned in the following examples:

However, whether the eruption caused the tsunami is a matter of dispute.

Often, such declines are attributable to sudden increases in interest rates.

Many researchers have sought to identify the reason for the pattern.

Each of the authors has proposed a different explanation for the company’s success.

Rhetorical Question Marker (indicates that a rhetorical question has been asked):

?

Often, in a Reading Comprehension passage, the author will ask a question. Generally, in such a case, the question won’t be one that the author expects the reader to answer. Rather the question will be a “rhetorical question.” In other words, the question will be one that the author plans to answer herself or himself in the sentences or paragraphs that follow the question.

Of course, it’s easy to tell that an author has asked a rhetorical question, because a rhetorical question will always end with a question mark, “?.” Thus, in most cases, a question mark in a passage is a rhetorical question marker.

A rhetorical question marker is a very useful clue because, almost always, when an author poses a rhetorical question, the answer that follows the question in the passage will be a key point that is strongly connected to the primary purpose of the passage. So, when we see a rhetorical question marker, we know that the part of the passage that follows the marker is likely going to be an important part of the passage that we can use to understand what the author is seeking to express and to arrive at correct answers to questions about the passage.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

A rhetorical question marker is a very useful clue because, almost always, when an author poses a rhetorical question, the answer that follows the question in the passage will be a key point that is strongly connected to the primary purpose of the passage.

To see a rhetorical question marker in action, consider the following example:

Many of the participants in the study had gotten the impression that the meditation approach was working. Had the researchers finally found a way to achieve the desired results?

Formal testing of the participants indicated that they had experienced increases in both energy levels and attention span. Additionally, the participants’ answers on a detailed questionnaire indicated that their abilities to perform various tasks had improved. The only reasonable conclusion is that the approach was indeed effective.

Notice how, in the above example, the rhetorical question “Had the researchers finally found a way to achieve the desired results?” sets the stage for what follows. Also, notice that what follows the rhetorical question is evidence and then a conclusion stated by the author, “The only reasonable conclusion is that ….” We can see that, if the above example were part of a passage, the rhetorical question would introduce a main point made by the author.

Let’s consider another example:

Each of the historians makes a convincing argument, but has either of them truly identified the cause of the society’s collapse?

It seems likely that both historians have missed something important. In fact, there are many societies that were similarly flawed yet survived.

Here once again, a rhetorical question is used to introduce a point, the point that “It seems likely that both historians have missed something important.” We can see that, if the above example were part of a passage, the rhetorical question would be followed by an important point and then some evidence to support that point.

Myth Marker (introduces a widely held view that will be discussed, called into question, or disputed):

widely held view, common belief, common perception, prevalent perception, many believe

Often, a Reading Comprehension passage will introduce an idea by first mentioning a common belief that contrasts with the idea to be introduced. When a passage works in this way, the common belief will often be preceded by a myth marker. So, a myth marker can be a useful clue, because the presence of a myth marker often indicates that one of the main ideas of the passage will soon be presented.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

A myth marker can be a useful clue, because the presence of a myth marker often indicates that one of the main ideas of the passage will soon be presented.

Typically, a myth marker will be used in a structure that is essentially “Many people believe X. However, Y.”

To see a myth marker in action, consider the following example:

Many people believe that some people are incapable improving their behavior. However, research conducted by Edward Latessa indicates otherwise. In fact, a review of his work reveals many reasons for optimism.

We can see that the above example uses the myth marker “many people believe” in the structure “Many people believe X. However, Y.”

Now, notice that the main point of the paragraph is not what the first sentence says, “Many people believe that some people are incapable of improving their behavior.” Rather, the main point is stated in the second and third sentences. “However, research conducted by Edward Latessa indicates otherwise. In fact, a review of his work reveals many reasons for optimism.”

So, the function of the sentence that begins with the myth marker “many people believe” is to introduce the main idea stated in the next two sentences.

OK, let’s consider another myth marker example:

There is a common perception that American football is not a thinking person’s game. However, this view is inaccurate; the truth is that cognitive skills are quite valuable to all players on a football field. Author Chris Brown explains why.

Notice how, in the above example, the myth marker “common perception” signals what’s going on in the paragraph. We can see that the point of mentioning “a common perception that American football is not a thinking person’s game” is to introduce what follows, which is the assertion “this view is inaccurate.”

So, if the above example were part of an RC passage, the myth marker “common perception” would be a signal that a common perception serves to introduce one of the main ideas of the passage, “this view is inaccurate.”

Extreme Marker (indicates that an extreme statement is being made):

all, every, only, none, always, never, most, least, best, worst, impossible

In Reading Comprehension, both passages and questions can include what are often called “extreme” statements.

For example, the following statement could be considered an extreme statement:

The best of the paintings is the artist’s latest work.

The word “best” in the above example can be termed an extreme marker because the presence of “best” indicates that the speaker is making the extreme statement that the artist’s latest work is not just a painting or just a good painting but the best of the paintings.

Let’s consider another example of an extreme statement:

It is never possible for a capuchin monkey to sing as well as Ethel Merman.

The word “never” in the above example can be termed an extreme marker because the presence of “never” indicates that the speaker is making the extreme statement that a capuchin monkey singing as well as Ethel Merman is not just unlikely but, rather, never possible.

It’s useful to notice extreme markers, because statements that include extreme markers express specific meanings. For instance, a statement that uses “always” expresses the specific meaning that something is true or occurs in every case. Similarly, a statement that uses “none” may express that absolutely zero examples of a thing exist.

One reason why noticing that statements express extreme meanings is useful in Reading Comprehension is that noticing that statements express extreme meanings can help us to determine whether RC answer choices match what passages say.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

One reason why noticing that statements express extreme meanings is useful in Reading Comprehension is that noticing that statements express extreme meanings can help us to determine whether RC answer choices match what passages say.

For instance, a passage could say the following:

White sharks are clearly dangerous. They are fast and strong and grow much larger than the 200-kilogram seals upon which they often prey. However, it is not common for these animals to attack humans.

Then, a question about the passage could read as follows:

The passage suggests that which of the following is true of white sharks?

(A) Even full-grown white sharks never harm humans.

(B) A white shark that weighs less than 200 kilograms is not full grown.

A key thing that we can notice about the above question is that choice (A) uses the extreme marker “never.”

Since the question asks, “The passage suggests that which of the following is true …?” once we see the extreme marker “never” in choice (A), we can return to the passage and compare what the answer choice says with what the passage says.

We see that the passage says, “it is not common for these animals to attack humans.” Since “it is not common for these animals to attack” in the passage does not match the extreme idea “full-grown white sharks never harm” in the answer choice, we can eliminate choice (A).

Choice (B), on the other hand, does follow from what the passage says. After all, what the passage says, that white sharks “grow much larger than the 200-kilogram seals,” implies what choice (B) says, that “A white shark that weighs less than 200 kilograms is not full grown.”

So, we can see how valuable it can be to notice an extreme marker.

Qualifier Marker (qualifies a fact stated in a passage):

may, can, could, possibly, probably, likely, some, sometimes, typically, generally, normally, usually, often, perhaps

Another type of word that a passage can use to express a specific meaning is a qualifier marker. Qualifier markers are words that qualify what a sentence conveys.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

Qualifier markers are words that qualify what a sentence conveys.

Consider the following pairs of sentences:

The dancers that participate in such ceremonies wear masks.

The dancers that participate in such ceremonies sometimes wear masks.

 

Hummingbirds fly backwards.

Hummingbird can fly backwards.

 

Visitors to that area see humpback whales.

Visitors to that area may see humpback whales.

We can see that, in each case, the addition of a qualifier marker to the second version of the sentence in the pair qualifies the meaning conveyed.

For example, the first version of the sentence about the dancers does not indicate how frequently the dancers wear masks. Then the second version of the sentence uses the qualifier marker “sometimes” to make clear that the dancers sometimes, but not always, wear masks.

The first version of the sentence about hummingbirds seems to convey that hummingbirds generally fly backwards. With the addition of the qualifier marker “can,” the second version conveys a different meaning, that hummingbirds have the ability to fly backwards but may not always fly backwards.

Finally, we see that the addition of the qualifier marker “may” causes the second version of the sentence about humpback whales to convey that it is possible, though not certain, that visitors to the area will see humpback whales.

So, like the use of an extreme marker, the use of a qualifier marker causes a sentence to express a specific meaning. Therefore, noticing qualifier markers can help us to choose RC correct answers.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

Since the use of a qualifier marker causes a sentence to express a specific meaning, noticing qualifier markers can help us to choose RC correct answers.

For instance, a passage could say the following:

While many people not familiar with the genre perceive the great jazz musicians of the past to be self-taught improvisers without formal training, the truth is that some of them attended music school. For instance, Miles Davis attended Juilliard, and John Coltrane the Granoff School of Music.

Then, a question about the passage could read as follows:

According to the passage, which is the following is true of jazz musicians of the past?

(A) All of the great ones attended music schools such as Juilliard or Granoff.

(B) Not all of them were self-taught improvisers without formal training.

A key thing that we can notice about the above question is that choice (A) uses the extreme marker “all,” whereas the passage segment uses the qualifier marker “some” in “some of them attended music school.” Since “All of the great ones attended music schools” in choice (A) does not match “some of them attended music school” in the passage, we can see that choice (A) is incorrect.

Choice (B), on the other hand, conveys a meaning that matches what the passage says, since “Not all of them were self-taught improvisers” conveys a meaning that is essentially equivalent to “some of them attended music school.”

So, we can see how valuable it can be to notice a qualifier marker.

Let’s now do some Targeted Practice involving the markers that we just discussed.

Targeted Practice

Identify the type of the marker in boldface in each passage segment.

Question
1 of 6
0%
accuracy

There is a widely held view that extremely vivid memories cannot be false. However, Neisser has called this view into question.

Explanation:

“There is a widely held view that X. However, Y,” is a version of the myth structure “Many believe X. However, Y.” So, “widely held view” is a myth marker.”

Correct answer: B
Next
Question
2 of 6
0%
accuracy

The physiology of the fish is such that they can survive in brackish water. However, normally, they are found in freshwater rivers and streams.

Explanation:

“Normally” is used to qualify the statement “they are found in freshwater rivers and streams,” indicating the frequency with which “the fish” are found in freshwater rivers and streams. So, “normally” is a qualifier marker.

Correct answer: B
Next
Question
3 of 6
0%
accuracy

Inevitably, the law was changed. The ongoing protests and the damage to the image of the administration that they were causing were more than enough to cause such a response. However, did the changing of the law represent a true victory for the movement?

Explanation:

In the context of a Reading Comprehension passage, a question mark usually indicates that a rhetorical question is being asked. So, in this context, “?” is a rhetorical question marker.

Correct answer: B
Next

4 of 6

Over time, it became increasingly clear to the public that the phenomenon was occurring as predicted by the models. At the same time, the reasons for this phenomenon remained in dispute, not only among members of the public but also among members of the meteorological community.

Explanation:

In this context, “reasons for this phenomenon” is synonymous with “causes of this phenomenon.” So, this sentence is about a cause-and-effect relationship, and thus “reasons” is a causation marker.

Correct answer: B
Next

As time went on, wind power became increasingly important in the surrounding countryside: windmills were used to pump water, grind grain, and saw wood. However, by the turn of the century, all of the windmills in the area had fallen into disuse.

Explanation:

In this context, the author uses “all” to convey the “extreme” fact that every single windmill in the area had fallen into disuse. So, “all” is an extreme marker.

Correct answer: A

Koalas require the help of certain specialized bacteria in order to effectively process the leaves they eat. However, when born, koalas have none of these bacteria in their digestive systems.

Explanation:

To understand what “these bacteria” refers to, we have to look in the sentence above to see that it must refer to “certain specialized bacteria.” So, “these bacteria” is a look above marker.

Correct answer: B
Finish

Let’s now review the general purpose of noticing markers in a passage.

The purpose of noticing markers is to use them to aid our understanding of a passage and how it is structured.

Of course, we don’t have to memorize where markers lie in a passage. The move is simply to notice them as we read and understand the function they’re performing. Furthermore, we have to be sure always to consider markers in the broader context of the passage, because some markers or keywords can be used in multiple ways. For instance, “in fact” may introduce a conclusion or indicate agreement, “thus” may indicate a cause-and-effect relationship or introduce a conclusion, and “in addition” can introduce information of a variety of types. In other words, once we notice a marker, we have to develop understanding of what’s going on around the marker.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

We must make sure to consider markers in the broader context of the passage, because some markers or keywords can be used in multiple ways. In other words, once we notice a marker, we have to develop understanding of what’s going on around the marker.

Let’s now consider a passage. As you go through this passage, use your knowledge of markers to identify structural markers in the passage and consider how they are used.

Example 20

S1: Among many citizens and elected officials, there is a perception that great benefits would result from legislation that imposes high taxes on long-term capital gains - profits earned on the sale of assets, such as real estate, securities, and businesses, that are held for more than one year before they are sold. S2: These people have argued that the revenues collected would help to reduce income inequality by redirecting profits earned by wealthy taxpayers to lower-income families in the form of subsidized food and housing, no-cost health insurance, and low-cost college tuition. S3: However, what is the truth of the matter?

S4: Such taxes would actually reduce, not improve, the economic wellbeing of all citizens because they would cause a reduction in the number of new businesses formed by entrepreneurs by lowering the expected rate of return that these entrepreneurs receive from risk-taking, innovation, and new business development. S5: Additionally, high long-term capital gains taxes serve to disincentivize the creation of strong, profitable businesses, which are most often the ones that effectively produce solutions to some of society’s most pressing problems, problems often experienced disproportionately by lower-income families. S6: In fact, high long-term capital gains taxes discourage the reallocation of capital from older, less profitable assets to newer assets that could generate higher rates of return, a process essential to long-term increases in productivity, wages, and wealth.

The passage is primarily concerned with

comparing different approaches to improving the economic wellbeing of citizens

describing a perception held by many citizens and elected officials

explaining how the creation of strong, profitable businesses benefits lower-income families

proving that legislation that imposes taxes is always detrimental to all citizens

discussing reasons why the use of a proposed strategy would not have the desired effects

Example 20 - Question 1

easy

S1: Among many citizens and elected officials, there is a perception that great benefits would result from legislation that imposes high taxes on long-term capital gains - profits earned on the sale of assets, such as real estate, securities, and businesses, that are held for more than one year before they are sold. S2: These people have argued that the revenues collected would help to reduce income inequality by redirecting profits earned by wealthy taxpayers to lower-income families in the form of subsidized food and housing, no-cost health insurance, and low-cost college tuition. S3: However, what is the truth of the matter?

S4: Such taxes would actually reduce, not improve, the economic wellbeing of all citizens because they would cause a reduction in the number of new businesses formed by entrepreneurs by lowering the expected rate of return that these entrepreneurs receive from risk-taking, innovation, and new business development. S5: Additionally, high long-term capital gains taxes serve to disincentivize the creation of strong, profitable businesses, which are most often the ones that effectively produce solutions to some of society’s most pressing problems, problems often experienced disproportionately by lower-income families. S6: In fact, high long-term capital gains taxes discourage the reallocation of capital from older, less profitable assets to newer assets that could generate higher rates of return, a process essential to long-term increases in productivity, wages, and wealth.

QUESTION
Showing:
Question

The passage is primarily concerned with

comparing different approaches to improving the economic wellbeing of citizens

describing a perception held by many citizens and elected officials

explaining how the creation of strong, profitable businesses benefits lower-income families

proving that legislation that imposes taxes is always detrimental to all citizens

discussing reasons why the use of a proposed strategy would not have the desired effects
Previous Confirm Finish
Show solution Hide solution

Text Solution:

By considering structural markers, we can readily identify the simple story to this passage and set ourselves up to answer this Primary Purpose question.

The first sentence of the passage uses the myth marker “Among many citizens and elected officials, there is a perception.” Seeing this clue, we can tell that the passage is likely to present a main point that contrasts with the perception that the myth marker introduces. That perception is that “great benefits would result from legislation that imposes high taxes on long-term capital gains.”

Then the second sentence begins with the look above marker “THESE people” and provides more information the perception of “these people,” who are the citizens and elected officials mentioned in the first sentence.

So far, the passage has simply discussed the common perception.

Then at the end of the first paragraph, we see a rhetorical question marker and the rhetorical question, “However, what is the truth of the matter?” That rhetorical question is a clue indicating that a key main point of the passage will follow.

The next sentence, the first sentence of the 2nd paragraph starts with the look above marker “SUCH taxes,” which indicates that this sentence continues the discussion of the taxes mentioned in the first paragraph, and this sentence states an opinion of the author, that “Such taxes would actually reduce, not improve, the economic wellbeing of all citizens.”

Notice that the point stated by the first sentence of the 2nd paragraph represents the second part of a “Many people believe X. However, Y,” myth structure. The first part of this myth structure was the first sentence of the first paragraph, “Among many citizens and elected officials, there is the perception that great benefits would result …,” and now, the point stated by the first sentence of the 2nd paragraph contrasts with “the perception” presented by the first sentence of the 1st paragraph.

We then see statements that begin with the support marker “because,” the additional point marker “additionally,” and the agreement marker “in fact.” These statements all support the opinion of the author stated by the first sentence of the 2nd paragraph.

So, what’s the simple story of the passage?

The passage first says, essentially, that many people perceive that great benefits would result from high long-term capital gains taxes, then presents the author’s opinion that that perception is inaccurate, and then presents some facts to support the authors opinion.

That’s it.

(A) comparing different approaches to improving the economic wellbeing of citizens

Notice that, in our simple story, only one approach to improving the economic wellbeing of citizens is mentioned, the use of legislation that imposes high long-term capital gains taxes. No other approach is compared with that approach.

It is true that the benefits of “the creation of strong profitable businesses” and “the reallocation of capital” are mentioned. However, these processes are not discussed as “approaches to improving the economic wellbeing of citizens” and are not “compared” with the approach of imposing high long-term capital gains taxes.

So, this choice does not accurately describe what the passage does.

(B) describing a perception held by many citizens and elected officials

This choice does describe something that the passage does. As we saw in our analysis of the passage, the passage does describe a perception held by citizens and elected officials.

However, this choice does not accurately describe the primary purpose of the passage, because what this choice says is too narrow. Describing that perception is just a part of what the passage accomplishes. The passage goes on to say much more.

So, this choice does not accurately describe what the passage accomplishes.

(C) explaining how the creation of strong, profitable businesses benefits lower-income families

While the passage does mention that “strong, profitable businesses … produce solutions to … problems often experienced disproportionately by lower-income families,” mentioning that fact is just one small part of what the passage does.

So, this choice is too narrow; it does not capture the primary purpose of the entire passage.

(D) proving that legislation that imposes taxes is always detrimental to all citizens

Notice that, whereas the passage is about taxes on long-term capital gains, this choice mentions legislation that imposes taxes in general, not just taxes on long-term capital gains.

Also, this choice uses the extreme marker “always.”

In using “taxes” rather than “taxes on long-term capital gains” and in using the extreme marker “always,” this choice says something more extreme than anything said by the passage, which does not go as far as saying that any legislation that imposes taxes is always detrimental to all citizens.

CORRECT ANSWER(E) discussing reasons why the use of a proposed strategy would not have the desired effects

In our analysis of the passage, we saw that the passage first presents the viewpoint that great benefits would result from legislation that imposes high taxes on long-term capital gains and then presents reasons why the use of that strategy would actually reduce, not improve, the economic wellbeing of all citizens.

So, essentially, the passage mentions a “proposed strategy” and then discusses reasons why the use of that proposed strategy would not have the desired effects, accomplishing essentially what this choice describes.

Correct answer: E
Frequently Asked Questions

Let’s now continue our mastery of GMAT Reading Comprehension by discussing Structure questions.

topics.topicName: 2.26 Structure Questions
topics.content:
2. Primary Purpose, Structure, Tone and Specific Purpose

2.26 Structure Questions

Some Reading Comprehension questions, called Structure questions, ask about the structure, or organization, of a passage or a paragraph, or about the logical connection between two paragraphs. These questions are similar in function to the Method of Reasoning questions that we learned about in the Critical Reasoning chapters.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

RC Structure questions, ask about the structure, or organization, of a passage, a paragraph, or about the logical connection between two paragraphs.

Structure questions stems use predictable language to ask about the structure, organization, or relationships between parts of the passage, such as:

Which of the following best describes the organization of the passage?

Which of the following best describes the structure of the passage?

Which of the following best describes the relationship between the second and third paragraphs of the passage?

Which of the following best describes the relation between the first and second paragraphs of the passage?

Which of the following best describes the organization of the first paragraph of the passage?

The second paragraph of the passage proceeds in which of the following ways?

Be sure that you’re ready to quickly recognize a Structure question.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

Learn to recognize the common and predictable language used by Structure RC questions.

The good news is that every RC passage we encounter will have a defined structure to it. In other words, each RC passage will have a certain organization decided upon by its author that will become clear once we read it.

For example, one common passage structure presents a common view (myth) and then challenges, questions, or discusses that common view.

Such a passage structure may look as follows:

Paragraph One: A common myth is presented.

Paragraph Two: The myth is challenged.

Paragraph Three: A better explanation is presented.

It’s important to see that when we say, “passage structure,” we’re simply referring to the way in which an author has organized and developed his or her essay.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

When we say “passage structure,” we’re simply referring to the way in which an author has organized and developed his or her essay.

Because there are a limited number of common passage structures used in RC passages, it’s advantageous for us to familiarize ourselves with these ways in by RC passages proceed.

They are:

- The passage presents multiple views on a topic and compares and contrasts the views, reconciles the views, or presents the author’s own view.

- The passage presents a common view (myth) and then challenges, questions, or discusses that common view.

- The passage presents multiple methods or strategies and then states one or more conclusions about those methods or strategies.

- The passage outlines an experiment, presents the results of the experiment, and discusses the results or states a conclusion based on the results.

- The passage presents a question and then explores information that helps with answering that question.

- The passage presents a set of historical developments and states a view of the author’s about those developments.

- The passage presents one or more innovations, products, or phenomena and then describes effects, events, or consequences associated with what it has presented.

By familiarizing ourselves with these common ways in which RC passages proceed, we can set ourselves up to readily recognize the structure of a passage. In each passage that you read, be sure to consider how it’s structured; look for the common passage structures we listed above.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

Familiarize yourself with the common ways in which RC passages proceed to set yourself up to readily recognize the structure of a passage.

As you’ve already learned, one of our goals is to be able to read a passage one time and from that reading understand the big picture concepts, such as the primary purpose and main idea (simple story). In that reading of the passage, another of our goals will be to clearly understand the way it is structured.

In other words, after we’re done reading a passage, we should have a strong understanding of the main idea (the simple story), the author’s primary purpose for writing it, and the way in which the passage is structured.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

After we’re done reading a passage, we should have a strong understanding of the main idea (the simple story), the author’s primary purpose for writing it, and the way in which the passage is structured.

Let’s now take some time to begin developing some new skills that will definitely help us to better understand how passages are structured.

topics.topicName: 2.27 A Map for Understanding the Structure of a Passage
topics.content:
2. Primary Purpose, Structure, Tone and Specific Purpose

2.27 A Map for Understanding the Structure of a Passage

There’s a simple way to understand the structure (organization) of a passage. The way we do this is by evaluating each sentence and each paragraph and determining what role each plays in the passage. In other words, we can determine what each sentence and paragraph is doing in the passage and why the author has decided to include them.

In fact, it’s often a game-changer to ask, “Why has the author taken the time to include this sentence or this paragraph?” By putting ourselves in the shoes of the author, it often becomes clearer what the goal of the author is in including elements of the passage.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

When seeking to understand the organization of a passage or paragraph, it’s often a game-changer to ask, “Why has the author taken the time to include this sentence or this paragraph?”

The reason that this sentence-by-sentence analysis is so important is that the organization of a passage is defined by the purposes of the sentences and paragraphs that compose it. Similarly, the structure of a paragraph is defined by the purposes of the sentences that it contains.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

The organization of a passage is defined by the purposes of the sentences and paragraphs that compose it. Similarly, the structure of a paragraph is defined by the purposes of the sentences that it contains.

In other words, we can tell what the structure of a passage or paragraph is by determining what each sentence and paragraph does.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

We can tell what the structure of a passage or paragraph is by determining what each sentence and paragraph does.

This might seem tedious, but with practice you’ll soon complete this process almost without thinking about doing it; the process will be second nature. In addition, if you never master doing the sentence-by-sentence analysis you’ll find it harder to perform well on GMAT Reading Comprehension.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

We can understand a passage’s structure by evaluating each sentence and each paragraph and determining what role each sentence or paragraph plays in the passage.

As we read, we can ask the following array of questions to help us develop our understanding of the passage structure:

- What does this first sentence really mean? Why is this first sentence here? What is the role of the first sentence? What are its implications?

- What does this second sentence really mean? Why is this second sentence here? What is the role of the second sentence? What are its implications? How does this sentence interact with the first sentence?

- What does this third sentence really mean? Why is this third sentence here? What is the role of this sentence? What are its implications? How does this sentence interact with the first and second sentences?

This process of sentence analysis must continue with each sentence until the end of the passage.

We must also consider the paragraphs:

- What is the point of this first paragraph? Why is it in the passage? What role does it play? What is the main idea presented in this paragraph?

- What is the point of this second paragraph? Why is it in the passage? What role does it play? What is the main idea presented in this paragraph? How does the second paragraph fit with the first paragraph?

- What is the relationship between the first paragraph and the second paragraph?

This process of paragraph analysis must continue until the end of the passage.

Of course, this analysis occurs at the same time as our analysis of the author’s primary purpose. The following questions, although focused on the main idea, will also help us to better understand the passage structure (and vice versa).

- Why has the author written this passage? For what purpose? What is the main idea, so far, of what I’ve read?

- What’s the simple story so far?

- If the author is making an argument, how strong is the author’s conviction in her argument?

- Is anything surprising about what I’ve read? Was the author surprised by anything? If so, what, and why?

- If there are multiple people mentioned in the passage, do they share the same beliefs, opinions, and conclusions or are those beliefs, opinions, and conclusions in opposition?

- What conclusions has the author drawn, if any? Does she present a main conclusion?

- What evidence does the author use to support her point(s)? How compelling is this evidence? Does the evidence strengthen or weaken the author’s point(s)? Does the evidence strengthen or weaken someone else’s point(s)?

Structural Markers Will Help us to Determine A Passage’s Structure

Since defining the purposes of sentences and paragraphs in a passage is the path to determining what the organization of the passage is, the structural markers that we discussed previously, especially contrast markers, opinion markers, conclusion markers, support markers, rhetorical question markers, and myth markers can help us to identify the organization of the passage by helping us to identify the purposes of sentences and paragraphs.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

Structural markers, especially contrast markers, opinion markers, conclusion markers, support markers, rhetorical question markers, and myth markers can help us to identify the purposes of sentences and paragraphs and, thus, the organization of the passage.

Let’s now work through the following passage. In addition to determining its main idea and the author’s tone, our new objective is now also to understand how the passage is structured.

Example 21

S1: There is a groupthink prevalent among lawmakers that prohibition is an effective tool for controlling the manufacture, sale, and consumption of illicit drugs. S2: These lawmakers argue that prohibition works as intended by reducing the supply of illicit drugs, regardless of the demand for them, and they offer a number of tactics in pursuit of prohibition. S3: For example, they hold tight to the belief that they can sharply decrease quantities of illicit drugs reaching potential consumers by deploying throughout much of the world a vast array of agencies and personnel tasked with the discovery, interdiction, and destruction of illicit drugs. S4: In addition, they argue that, by increasing funding for law enforcement agencies responsible for arresting those involved with illicit drugs, they can further reduce the available supply. S5: However, despite what these lawmakers believe, market economics nearly ensure that prohibition will never be an effective tool for combating the distribution of illicit drugs.

S6: Take cocaine as an example. S7: In Colombia alone, coca plants are grown on a vast 450,000 acres of remote farmland, and even after large-scale efforts to locate and eradicate these crops, farmers will harvest and process enough coca leaves for the production of thousands of tons of cocaine. S8: In addition, because drug cartels are the only wholesale buyers of cocaine, they are able to unilaterality dictate the price that they pay for each kilogram of refined cocaine. S9: As a result, over the past four decades, the street value of cocaine has remained remarkably stable, at about $150,000 per kilogram, a price that allows for enormous profits from the sale of cocaine. S10: With such a large profit potential, not even the harshest of prison sentences can keep dealers at bay; there will always be people willing to bear the risks in pursuit of such profits.

The primary purpose of the passage is to

explain why the street value of cocaine has remained fairly constant

advocate for more effective methods for controlling the manufacture, sale, and consumption of illicit drugs

demonstrate that lawmakers seeking to combat the production and distribution of illicit drugs should focus on Colombia

present economic justification for the conclusion that prohibition is a poor strategy in the fight against illicit drugs

underscore that illicit drug production and consumption is a problem that is impossible to solve

Example 21 - Question 1

easy

S1: There is a groupthink prevalent among lawmakers that prohibition is an effective tool for controlling the manufacture, sale, and consumption of illicit drugs. S2: These lawmakers argue that prohibition works as intended by reducing the supply of illicit drugs, regardless of the demand for them, and they offer a number of tactics in pursuit of prohibition. S3: For example, they hold tight to the belief that they can sharply decrease quantities of illicit drugs reaching potential consumers by deploying throughout much of the world a vast array of agencies and personnel tasked with the discovery, interdiction, and destruction of illicit drugs. S4: In addition, they argue that, by increasing funding for law enforcement agencies responsible for arresting those involved with illicit drugs, they can further reduce the available supply. S5: However, despite what these lawmakers believe, market economics nearly ensure that prohibition will never be an effective tool for combating the distribution of illicit drugs.

S6: Take cocaine as an example. S7: In Colombia alone, coca plants are grown on a vast 450,000 acres of remote farmland, and even after large-scale efforts to locate and eradicate these crops, farmers will harvest and process enough coca leaves for the production of thousands of tons of cocaine. S8: In addition, because drug cartels are the only wholesale buyers of cocaine, they are able to unilaterality dictate the price that they pay for each kilogram of refined cocaine. S9: As a result, over the past four decades, the street value of cocaine has remained remarkably stable, at about $150,000 per kilogram, a price that allows for enormous profits from the sale of cocaine. S10: With such a large profit potential, not even the harshest of prison sentences can keep dealers at bay; there will always be people willing to bear the risks in pursuit of such profits.

QUESTION PASSAGE-ANALYSIS
Showing:
Question Passage Analysis

The primary purpose of the passage is to

explain why the street value of cocaine has remained fairly constant

advocate for more effective methods for controlling the manufacture, sale, and consumption of illicit drugs

demonstrate that lawmakers seeking to combat the production and distribution of illicit drugs should focus on Colombia

present economic justification for the conclusion that prohibition is a poor strategy in the fight against illicit drugs

underscore that illicit drug production and consumption is a problem that is impossible to solve
Previous Confirm Next
Show solution Hide solution
PRESENTED BY :
Scott Woodbury-Stewart Founder and Expert GMAT Instructor Scott Woodbury-Stewart Founder and Expert GMAT Instructor

Text Solution:

To answer this Primary Purpose question, let’s consider what we discussed in our analysis of the passage. (We can reach the analysis of the passage by clicking on the tab above this question.)

We see that the passage first discusses the strategy “prohibition.”

Then, it goes on to present the opinion that “market economics nearly ensure that prohibition will never be an effective tool for combating the distribution of illicit drugs” and present evidence in support of that opinion.

So, the primary purpose is something along the lines of to present a strategy and demonstrate why that strategy will likely never work.

(A) explain why the street value of cocaine has remained fairly constant

What this choice says does match something that the passage does; in the second paragraph, the passage does explain why the street value of cocaine has remained fairly constant.

However, this choice does not describe the primary purpose of the passage, because this choice describes one small part of the passage, not the passage as a whole. In other words, what this choice is about is too narrow to be the primary purpose of the entire passage.

(B) advocate for more effective methods for controlling the manufacture, sale, and consumption of illicit drugs

While this choice is related to the topic of the passage, this choice does not accurately describe the primary purpose of the passage.

Notice that the author of the passage does not “advocate for” any methods. Rather, the first paragraph discusses some beliefs and some methods that some lawmakers advocate, and then the second paragraph presents evidence against the use of those methods.

(C) demonstrate that lawmakers seeking to combat the production and distribution of illicit drugs should focus on Colombia

While the passage does describe some aspects of cocaine production in Colombia, the primary purpose of the passage is not to demonstrate that lawmakers should focus on Colombia.

We can see from our analysis of the passage that the purpose of presenting the example of Colombia in the 2nd paragraph is to provide evidence in support of the view that market economics nearly ensure that prohibition will never be an effective tool for combating the distribution of illicit drugs, not to demonstrate that lawmakers should focus on Colombia.

CORRECT ANSWER(D) present economic justification for the conclusion that prohibition is a poor strategy in the fight against illicit drugs

As we discussed in our passage analysis, the passage first presents the strategy of prohibition, then states the opinion that prohibition “will never be an effective tool,” and finally presents evidence in support of that opinion.

Since what the passage accomplishes matches this choice, this choice accurately describes the primary purpose of the passage.

(E) underscore that illicit drug production and consumption is a problem that is impossible to solve

This choice is a little tricky, because what the passage says does indicate that people have been seeking to solve the problem of illicit drug production and consumption without success.

However, is the primary of the passage to underscore that this problem is “impossible to solve?”

Notice that the passage is focused on a particular strategy, prohibition, and the reasons why that strategy has not worked and likely will never work rather than on demonstrating why the problem of illicit drug consumption and distribution is “impossible to solve.” After all, the purpose of the 2nd paragraph is to support the assertion made at the end of the 1st paragraph, that market economics nearly ensure that “prohibition will never be an effective tool.”

Also, the passage never says or indicates that the problem is “impossible to solve.”

So, this choice fails to capture the primary purpose of the passage.

Correct answer: D

S1: This sentence uses the myth marker “There is a groupthink prevalent among lawmakers” to introduce a common belief, the belief that “prohibition is an effective tool for controlling the manufacture, sale, and consumption of illicit drugs. So, it seems likely that the passage will involve a version of the myth structure “Many people believe X. However, Y,” and that the passage will present a point that contrasts with the “groupthink prevalent among lawmakers” and challenge that groupthink.

Simplification: Many lawmakers believe that prohibition is an effective way to control the supply and use of illicit drugs.

S2: This sentence begins with the look above marker “These lawmakers.” So, we can see that this sentence expands on what S1 says about the lawmakers.

We also see that this sentence uses the opinion marker “argue” in presenting the opinion of the lawmakers that “prohibition works as intended by reducing the supply of illicit drugs, regardless of the demand for them.”

Then this sentence continues by saying “they offer a number of tactics in pursuit of prohibition” and, thus, sets the passage up to present examples of the tactics the lawmakers offer.

Simplification: The lawmakers mentioned in S1 believe that prohibition works by reducing supply of illicit drugs and offer a number of tactics for accomplishing prohibition.

S3: This sentence begins with the support marker “for example” and presents an example of one of the “tactics” mentioned in S2, “deploying throughout much of the world a vast array of agencies and personnel tasked with the discovery, interdiction, and destruction of illicit drugs.”

S4: This sentence begins with the additional point marker “in addition” and then presents another example to support what S2 says about tactics that the lawmakers offer.

S5: Before this sentence, the passage presents the “groupthink prevalent among lawmakers” and some details related to the lawmakers’ opinion. Notice that, up until this sentence, the passage has presented only descriptive information on the opinion of the lawmakers and has not presented any opinion of the author of the passage.

Now, this sentence begins with the contrast marker “however,” signaling that what follows will contrast with what has been presented so far. Notice that this sentence turns out to be the “However Y,” part of the myth structure “Many people believe X. However, Y,” that we expected to see when we saw in S1 the myth marker “There is a groupthink prevalent among lawmakers.”

So, what’s the contrasting idea that the passage will now present? In reading this sentence, we see that the idea that contrasts with what the passage has said so far is that “market economics nearly ensure that prohibition will never be an effective tool for combating the distribution of illicit drugs.”

Notice that this contrasting idea is the author’s own opinion.

Simplification: However, in the opinion of the author of the passage, the lawmakers’ opinion is incorrect.

1st paragraph summary: This paragraph presents a common belief among lawmakers, that prohibition is an effective approach for controlling the supply and demand of illicit drugs, presents some examples of tactics for accomplishing prohibition offered by these lawmakers, and then presents the author’s contrasting view that prohibition does not work.

The role of the 1st paragraph is to present a common belief that the passage, or author, will go on to challenge.

S6: Notice the support marker “example.” The role of this sentence is to introduce the example of “cocaine,” the purpose of which is to support the author’s opinion stated at the end of the 1st paragraph, that “market economics nearly ensure that prohibition will never be an effective tool for combating the distribution of illicit drugs.”

S7: This sentence presents some information on the example of cocaine introduced by S6 and provides some support for the opinion stated at the end of the 1st paragraph by showing that the “tactics” offered by lawmakers don’t prevent farmers from producing cocaine.

Simplification: Large scale efforts do not stop farmers from producing “thousands of tons of cocaine.”

S8: This sentence begins with the additional point marker “in addition” and provides more information on the example of cocaine introduced in S6, the fact that cartels “are able to unilaterally dictate the price that they pay for each kilogram of refined cocaine.”

S9: This sentence begins with the causation marker “as a result” and describes the result of what S8 says about the cartels’ being able to dictate the price that they pay for cocaine: “the street value of cocaine has remained remarkably stable, at … a price that allows for enormous profits.”

S10: This sentence wraps up the example of cocaine introduced by S6 by showing how this example is connected to and supports the opinion stated by the last sentence of the 1st paragraph, that prohibition “will never be an effective tool for combating the distribution of illicit drugs.”

In other words, the fact that “there will always be people willing to bear the risks in pursuit of generating profits that few legal enterprises generate” is the main point that this paragraph has been working toward, which main point supports the opinion stated at the end of the 1st paragraph.

2nd paragraph summary: This paragraph supports the opinion stated at the end of the 1st paragraph, “However, … market economics nearly ensure that prohibition will never be an effective tool for combating the distribution of illicit drugs,” by presenting the example of cocaine.

Passage summary: The passage first presents a belief common among lawmakers and some details related to that belief. It then presents the author’s own opinion, which is that the belief of the lawmakers is incorrect, and supports that opinion by presenting an example in detail.

Notice that, although the passage has a lot to say, its structure is simple!

Also, notice that the main idea of the passage is also simple:

Despite what some lawmakers think, prohibition is not an effective tool for controlling the manufacture, sale, and consumption of illicit drugs.

That’s it! That’s the simple story!!

Frequently Asked Questions

Now that we well understand how to analyze the structure of a passage, let’s move on to discussing structure trap 1: an answer choice that uses the wrong verb .
