topics.topicName: 3.3 How to Handle Details When Reading a Passage
topics.content:
3. Detail, Inference, Application, Assumption, Weaken and Strengthen

3.3 How to Handle Details When Reading a Passage

Reading comprehension is not testing whether we have a photographic memory for detail. If it were, then the passage wouldn’t remain on the screen when it came time to answer the questions.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

Reading comprehension is not testing whether we have a photographic memory for detail.

So, when we read a passage, there’s no need to seek to memorize the details of the passage. In fact, seeking to memorize details is a score eroding mistake. Here’s why:

- First, any given passage could contain more specific details than we’d realistically be able to process and remember.

- Second, the questions will focus on only some details of the passage, and there’s no practical way to determine which details those will be. So, attempting to memorize details is a waste of valuable time and energy.

- Third, and arguably most importantly, reading to memorize specific details will erode our ability to understand bigger picture – and more valuable - aspects of the passage, such as the primary purpose, author’s tone, and passage structure, and general nature of what’s discussed.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

Do not attempt to memorize specific details in a passage as you read it. Keep your focus on the big picture of the passage.

So then, what do we do with the details we encounter?

Instead of seeking to memorize specific details, we do the following two things with the details we encounter as we read:

- We use the specific details provided to understand the passage.

- We notice where in the passage details lie to prepare ourselves to find them again as necessary in order to answer questions.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

When we encounter details in a passage, we (1) use the specific details provided to understand the passage and (2) notice where in the passage details lie to prepare ourselves to find them again as necessary in order to answer questions.

For example, if a passage mentioned that the League of Nations was founded in January of 1920, our goal would not be to memorize this date. Instead, our goal would be to understand why this specific detail has been presented. What purpose does it serve? How does this specific detail fit into the passage as a whole? Why does the author want us to know this fact?

In addition, we would mentally note where in the passage the founding of the League of Nations is mentioned, so that, if a question were to ask about something related to the founding of the League of Nations, we could readily find the information we need in order to answer the question.

Similarly, if an author mentioned that gamma radiation will penetrate up to two inches of lead, but alpha radiation will be stopped by thick construction paper, our goal would not be to memorize these facts of particle physics. In other words, in reading the passage, we wouldn’t go to the trouble to memorize which type of radiation can penetrate lead and which will be stopped by paper. Rather, our goal would be to use these facts to enhance our comprehension of the passage. We would ask, “Why did the author include these facts about gamma and alpha radiation?”

In addition, we would mentally note where in the passage gamma and alpha radiation are mentioned, so that, if a question were to ask about one or both of them, we could readily find the information we need to answer the question.

Another thing to realize is that some passages will actually attempt to distract us with jargon or dense, complicated detail. If we encounter such a passage, we never get into the weeds by seeking to fully understand or process every one of those details. Rather, our job is simply to understand what role the information plays in the passage -- why is it there? What function does it perform? We’ll let the specific details help us to better understand the passage.

When we see specific details as vehicles that can aid us in our understanding of a passage, they are no longer random, burdensome thorns to prune. Instead, they become helpful clues left for us by the author.

Always remember that, in RC, our goal is “comprehension, not memorization.”

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

In RC, our goal is comprehension, not memorization.

Although, we’ll have a lot more to say about Detail Questions, let’s use what we know so far to read the following passage and then answer the Detail question that accompanies it.

Consider the following example.

Example 1

S1: It is well documented that people of above average intelligence, as measured by traditional intelligence (IQ) tests, often think and act irrationally. S2: Cognitive psychologists have been puzzled by this peculiar phenomenon because it had long been dogma in psychology that there should be a positive correlation between a person’s IQ and his or her ability to think and act rationally. S3: Recently, Keith Stanovich, professor of applied psychology, has proposed an explanation for this phenomenon. S4: He argues that IQ tests miss some of the most important aspects of how people make decisions in the real world, and that it is possible to test high in intelligence yet suffer from a cognitive defect called dysrationalia, which he describes as the inability to think and behave rationally despite having adequate intelligence.

S5: Research points to two reasons for dysrationalia. S6: The first is a processing issue related to the structure of the human brain, which has available to it a number of different mechanisms by which to make decisions. S7: Some of these mechanisms process information in a way such that, in using them, people are apt to think and act rationally, but people often tend to avoid using these “higher-fidelity” mechanisms because using them not only requires significant concentration and energy expenditure but also interferes with other cognitive processes, causing people to feel uncomfortable. S8: As a result, people often opt instead to use processing mechanisms that are significantly more comfortable to employ and require far less processing power yet are not well suited for thinking and acting rationally; using these “lower-fidelity” mechanisms is not optimal for decision-making. S9: In fact, psychologists Susan Fiske and Shelly Taylor have coined the term “cognitive miser” to describe a person who uses the cognitive path of least resistance in processing information and thus often makes poor decisions.

S10: The second source of dysrationalia, explains Stanovich, is an issue involving content. S11: He says that, in order to think and act rationally, people must acquire specific knowledge – rules, data, procedures, strategies, and other tools of cognition that cognitive scientist David Perkins calls “mindware” and that, when people are missing the mindware necessary for making rational decisions or solving problems appropriately, there exists a mindware gap. S12: According to this view, the larger a person’s mindware gap, the more apt he or she is to suffer from dysrationalia. S13: For example, a person without training in statistics will struggle to think and act rationally when faced with even basic decisions that require an understanding of probability.

According to the passage, which of the following is true of “lower-fidelity” mechanisms for processing information?

The use of such mechanisms is less uncomfortable than the use of some other mechanisms for processing information.

People who could be termed “cognitive misers” avoid the use of such mechanisms.

The use of such mechanisms causes people to score low on tests of intelligence.

These mechanisms were first discovered by psychologists Susan Fiske and Shelly Taylor.

The use of such mechanisms always results in poor decisions.

Example 1 - Question 1

easy

S1: It is well documented that people of above average intelligence, as measured by traditional intelligence (IQ) tests, often think and act irrationally. S2: Cognitive psychologists have been puzzled by this peculiar phenomenon because it had long been dogma in psychology that there should be a positive correlation between a person’s IQ and his or her ability to think and act rationally. S3: Recently, Keith Stanovich, professor of applied psychology, has proposed an explanation for this phenomenon. S4: He argues that IQ tests miss some of the most important aspects of how people make decisions in the real world, and that it is possible to test high in intelligence yet suffer from a cognitive defect called dysrationalia, which he describes as the inability to think and behave rationally despite having adequate intelligence.

S5: Research points to two reasons for dysrationalia. S6: The first is a processing issue related to the structure of the human brain, which has available to it a number of different mechanisms by which to make decisions. S7: Some of these mechanisms process information in a way such that, in using them, people are apt to think and act rationally, but people often tend to avoid using these “higher-fidelity” mechanisms because using them not only requires significant concentration and energy expenditure but also interferes with other cognitive processes, causing people to feel uncomfortable. S8: As a result, people often opt instead to use processing mechanisms that are significantly more comfortable to employ and require far less processing power yet are not well suited for thinking and acting rationally; using these “lower-fidelity” mechanisms is not optimal for decision-making. S9: In fact, psychologists Susan Fiske and Shelly Taylor have coined the term “cognitive miser” to describe a person who uses the cognitive path of least resistance in processing information and thus often makes poor decisions.

S10: The second source of dysrationalia, explains Stanovich, is an issue involving content. S11: He says that, in order to think and act rationally, people must acquire specific knowledge – rules, data, procedures, strategies, and other tools of cognition that cognitive scientist David Perkins calls “mindware” and that, when people are missing the mindware necessary for making rational decisions or solving problems appropriately, there exists a mindware gap. S12: According to this view, the larger a person’s mindware gap, the more apt he or she is to suffer from dysrationalia. S13: For example, a person without training in statistics will struggle to think and act rationally when faced with even basic decisions that require an understanding of probability.

QUESTION
Showing:
Question

According to the passage, which of the following is true of “lower-fidelity” mechanisms for processing information?

The use of such mechanisms is less uncomfortable than the use of some other mechanisms for processing information.

People who could be termed “cognitive misers” avoid the use of such mechanisms.

The use of such mechanisms causes people to score low on tests of intelligence.

These mechanisms were first discovered by psychologists Susan Fiske and Shelly Taylor.

The use of such mechanisms always results in poor decisions.
Previous Confirm Finish
Show solution Hide solution

Text Solution:

We can see that the focus of the question is on “lower-fidelity” mechanisms for processing information.

So, to find the information we need to answer the question, we home in on the area of the passage where we saw ‘“lower-fidelity” mechanisms’ mentioned when we were reading the passage, which is the 2nd paragraph.

Then, we can go through the answer choices and carefully compare each with what the 2nd paragraph says about “lower-fidelity” mechanisms until we have eliminated the choices that are not supported by the passage and found one that is.

CORRECT ANSWER(A) The use of such mechanisms is less uncomfortable than the use of some other mechanisms for processing information.

Finding ‘“lower-fidelity” mechanisms’ in the passage, we see that “lower-fidelity” appears in the following context:

using these “lower-fidelity” mechanisms is not optimal for decision-making

Since ‘THESE “lower-fidelity” mechanisms’ is a look above marker, we can look in the sentence above to see what ‘these “lower-fidelity” mechanisms’ refers to.

We see the following:

processing mechanisms that are significantly more comfortable to employ

So, the passage says that “lower-fidelity” mechanisms are “mechanism that are … more comfortable to employ.”

Since, “more comfortable to employ” in the passage has essentially the same meaning as “the use of such mechanisms is less uncomfortable” in this choice, the passage supports this choice.

(B) People who could be termed “cognitive misers” avoid the use of such mechanisms.

Going to where “cognitive miser” is discussed in the passage, we see that “cognitive miser” appears in the following:

In fact, psychologists Susan Fiske and Shelly Taylor have coined the term “cognitive miser” to describe a person who uses the cognitive path of least resistance in processing information and thus often makes poor decisions.

The agreement marker “in fact” indicates that this statement from the passage agrees with the statement that precedes it which is the following:

using these “lower-fidelity” mechanisms is not optimal for decision-making.

So, we can see that the passage implies that cognitive misers DO use ‘these “lower-fidelity” mechanisms,” which is the opposite of what this choice says.

(C) The use of such mechanisms causes people to score low on tests of intelligence.

This choice is not supported by the passage, which does not connect “lower-fidelity” mechanism to scores on tests on intelligence tests. The passage mentions “lower-fidelity” mechanisms only in the context of thinking and acting rationally and decision-making.

In answering RC questions, we have to be careful to stick to what’s supported by the passage. In this case, while it’s possible that the use of “lower-fidelity” mechanisms causes people to score low on tests of intelligence, that speculation is not supported by the passage.

(D) These mechanisms were first discovered by psychologists Susan Fiske and Shelly Taylor.

Notice that, while the passage mentions Susan Fiske and Shelly Taylor in connection with “lower-fidelity” mechanisms, it does not say that they discovered such mechanisms.

(E) The use of such mechanisms always results in poor decisions.

Notice that this choice uses the extreme marker “always.” So, we should compare this choice with the passage to see whether what the passage says is as extreme as what this choice says.

We see that the passage says, “using these “lower-fidelity” mechanisms is not optimal for decision-making,” and that a “cognitive miser” “often makes poor decisions.”

Notice that “not optimal for decision-making” and “often makes poor decisions” are not as extreme as what this choice says, “The use of such mechanisms always results in poor decisions.”

So, this choice does not match what the passage says.

Correct answer: A
Frequently Asked Questions

Keep in mind that reading comprehension is an open book test. So, when we’re asked about specific details of the passage, we can and should refer back to the passage to find the exact information we need to arrive at the correct answer.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

Keep in mind that reading comprehension is an open book test. So, when we’re asked about specific details of the passage, we can and should refer back to the passage to find the exact information we need to arrive at the correct answer.

Let’s now discuss the process of finding information in an RC passage, one of the most important RC skills.

topics.topicName: 3.4 Information Finding, One of the Most Important RC Skills
topics.content:
3. Detail, Inference, Application, Assumption, Weaken and Strengthen

3.4 Information Finding, One of the Most Important RC Skills

Finding the right information in the passage is critical to arriving at the correct answer to a Detail question. In fact, developing skill in finding the right information in a RC passage is one of the most important aspects of RC mastery.

This point cannot be overemphasized.

As we discussed earlier, in a sense, Reading Comprehension success comes down to four things:

- understanding passages

- understanding questions

- finding in passages the right information for answering questions

- telling trap choices from correct answers

So, we can see that developing skill in finding the right information in passages is going to be a key aspect of our RC success, and this fact is not surprising. After all, all the information we need for answering RC questions is right there in the passage!

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

Developing skill in finding the right information in passages is going to be a key aspect of our RC success, and this fact is not surprising. After all, all the information we need for answering RC questions is right there in the passage.

So, let’s now discuss a strategy for finding information in RC passages, starting with the first step, finding the focus of the question.

The first RC information-finding step is to find the focus of the question.

Every Reading Comprehension question involving details of what a passage says will have a focus, such as an event, a person, a period of time, a phenomenon, or a type of physical entity. So, our first information-finding step is to find the focus of the question in the question stem.

Consider the following example question stem:

According to the passage, which of the following is true of Asian elephants?

We can see that the focus of the above question stem is Asian elephants.

Here’s another:

The passage suggests that mitochondria serve which of the following purposes?

We can see that the focus of the above question is the purposes of mitochondria.

Let’s consider one more stem:

According to the author of the passage, an astronomer gets the clearest images when which of the following occurs?

We see that the stem mentions “an astronomer” and “the clearest images.” So, which is the focus?

In this case, what we have to notice is that the right information in the passage will be something related to both “an astronomer” and “the clearest images.” The passage could say many things about “an astronomer” or many things about “the clearest images” but only information directly related to both “an astronomer” and getting “the clearest images” will help us to answer the question.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

The first RC information-finding step is to find the focus of the question in the question stem.

The second RC information-finding step is to choose keywords to look for.

Once we have found the focus of the question, we can set ourselves up to find the right information in the passage by choosing keywords to look for in the passage. Normally we’ll find these keywords in the question stem, but sometimes we’ll have to use keywords in an answer choice.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

The second RC information-finding step is to find keywords to look for in the question stem or, in some cases, in an answer choice.

The best keywords to look for in the passage are ones that are relatively specific to the focus of the question because those keywords are the ones most likely to lead us to the correct information.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

The best keywords to look for in the passage are ones that are relatively specific to the focus of the question because those keywords are the ones most likely to lead us to the correct information.

Consider the following question stem:

The passage suggests that Barbara Brennan’s opinion regarding chi is different from that of the other healers mentioned in which of the following ways?

We can see that the focus of this question is the difference between Barbara Brennan’s opinion regarding chi and the opinion of other healers. So, some possible keywords in the stem that we could look for in the passage are “Barbara Brennan,” “opinion,” “medication,” and “healers.” To choose a keyword to look for, we would consider which of those keywords is the most specific to this topic.

“Opinion” would not be a good keyword to look for since, apparently, the passage discusses multiple opinions, at least those of Barbara Brennan and “the other healers mentioned.” So, opinion may not be specific to the focus of this question. In other words, if we look for “opinion” in the passage, or for opinions, we may find opinions in multiple parts of the passage rather than in the one spot in the passage where the information we need is.

Similarly, it may be that neither “healers” nor “chi” is unique to what this question is about since the passage may say multiple things about healers or chi.

So, the best keyword to look for in this case is likely “Barbara Brennan,” because that name is the keyword most likely to indicate the information we need on Barbara Brennan’s opinion.

Notice also that, since “Barbara Brennan” is capitalized, finding “Barbara Brennan” in the passage should be relatively easy. Words that are capitalized in question stems are often good keywords to use for finding information because capitalized keywords are relatively easy to find in a passage.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

Words that are capitalized in question stems are often good keywords to use for finding information because capitalized keywords are relatively easy to find in a passage.

Let’s consider another stem:

According to the passage, which of the following was true of economic thought in 1929?

In this stem, we see the keywords “economic,” “thought,” and “1929.” In this case, it’s likely that the best keyword to use would be the date “1929” because, by finding “1929,” we’d be sure to find information specific to that year, rather than information on something “economic” or on “thought” that doesn’t apply to 1929.

Also, dates in question stems are often good keywords to use for finding information because they are specific and relatively easy to find in a passage.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

Dates in question stems are often good keywords to use for finding information because they are specific and relatively easy to find in a passage.

Technical words that appear in question stems or answer choices can also be good keywords to use for finding information, because technical words are often used in discussing one specific idea and, thus, can lead us to the exact information we need in a passage.

Consider the following answer choice:

(A) The impairment of the function of ribosomes is likely to result in anemia.

If we were to see the above answer choice, it’s likely that searching for the technical word “ribosomes” would be our best way to find the information we need in the passage.

Here’s a question stem that includes a technical word.

The author would be most likely to agree with which of the following about the effects of surface topography on earthquake impact?

In this case, the stem includes the technical term “surface topography.” So, it’s likely that we’d find the exact information we need by scanning for “topography” or “surface topography.”

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

Technical words that appear in question stems or answer choices can be good keywords to use for finding information, because technical words are often used in discussing one specific idea and, thus, can lead us to the exact right information we need in a passage.

The third RC information-finding step is to locate the information we need in the passage.

Once we have found the focus of the question and identified some keywords in the stem or an answer choice, we go to the passage and scan for the keywords and use what we recall about the locations of details in the passage to locate the information we need in the passage.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

Once we have found the focus of the question and some keywords in the stem, we go to the passage and scan for the keywords and use what we recall about the locations of details in the passage to find the information we need in the passage.

Consider the following example.

Example 2

S1: In the mid-twentieth century, anthropomorphism – the attribution of human traits or purposes to non-human entities such as animals – had long been frowned upon by most members of the scientific community, who perceived there to be a clear dividing line between the psychology and intentions of humans and the consciousness and motivations of other animals. S2: A researcher’s engaging in any degree of anthropomorphism was considered an unacceptable flaw in methodology that inevitably results in loss of objectivity.

S3: However, as a scientific community outsider with no college degree and little training, Jane Goodall was unaffected by this view when she first entered the Tanzanian wilderness to study chimpanzees. S4: Consequently, she was unimpeded from making certain groundbreaking discoveries that would forever change the way non-human animals are perceived. S5: During her first period of field study, in 1960, having observed chimpanzee facial expressions and actions, such as their using touch to greet and comfort each other, she concluded that chimpanzees have unique personalities and human-like emotions. S6: Also, during this period, she observed chimpanzees fashioning simple tools that they then used to “fish” for termites. S7: Since, at the time, the common wisdom was that humans alone among all animals modify objects to create tools, this discovery stunned the scientific world. S8: Later, in 1970, her observation that chimpanzees seemed to express awe at the sight of a spectacular waterfall led her and others to believe that chimpanzees have experiences akin to human spirituality.

S9: Goodall’s work has been sufficient to convince many of her peers that human and animal mental, emotional, and spiritual characteristics lie on a continuum rather than on two sides of a dividing line – Harvard’s Stephen Jay Gould used the words “one of the great achievements of twentieth-century scholarship.” S10: Nevertheless, others have termed her work “anecdotal” or even “unbounded speculation” because, as diligent as it is, her conclusions are largely based upon a somewhat limited set of observations made by a single person. S11: However, more recently, teams of researchers using empirical methods involving large samples have produced evidence indicating that her views reflect reality.

According to the passage, Jane Goodall’s observation that chimpanzees fashion simple tools

was made while she was engaging in field study in 1970

showed for the first time that termites are an important component of the diet of chimpanzees

was disputed by most members of the scientific world

showed a certain widely held conception to be false

confirmed in a stunning manner what many of her peers had long suspected

Example 2 - Question 1

easy

S1: In the mid-twentieth century, anthropomorphism – the attribution of human traits or purposes to non-human entities such as animals – had long been frowned upon by most members of the scientific community, who perceived there to be a clear dividing line between the psychology and intentions of humans and the consciousness and motivations of other animals. S2: A researcher’s engaging in any degree of anthropomorphism was considered an unacceptable flaw in methodology that inevitably results in loss of objectivity.

S3: However, as a scientific community outsider with no college degree and little training, Jane Goodall was unaffected by this view when she first entered the Tanzanian wilderness to study chimpanzees. S4: Consequently, she was unimpeded from making certain groundbreaking discoveries that would forever change the way non-human animals are perceived. S5: During her first period of field study, in 1960, having observed chimpanzee facial expressions and actions, such as their using touch to greet and comfort each other, she concluded that chimpanzees have unique personalities and human-like emotions. S6: Also, during this period, she observed chimpanzees fashioning simple tools that they then used to “fish” for termites. S7: Since, at the time, the common wisdom was that humans alone among all animals modify objects to create tools, this discovery stunned the scientific world. S8: Later, in 1970, her observation that chimpanzees seemed to express awe at the sight of a spectacular waterfall led her and others to believe that chimpanzees have experiences akin to human spirituality.

S9: Goodall’s work has been sufficient to convince many of her peers that human and animal mental, emotional, and spiritual characteristics lie on a continuum rather than on two sides of a dividing line – Harvard’s Stephen Jay Gould used the words “one of the great achievements of twentieth-century scholarship.” S10: Nevertheless, others have termed her work “anecdotal” or even “unbounded speculation” because, as diligent as it is, her conclusions are largely based upon a somewhat limited set of observations made by a single person. S11: However, more recently, teams of researchers using empirical methods involving large samples have produced evidence indicating that her views reflect reality.

QUESTION
Showing:
Question

According to the passage, Jane Goodall’s observation that chimpanzees fashion simple tools

was made while she was engaging in field study in 1970

showed for the first time that termites are an important component of the diet of chimpanzees

was disputed by most members of the scientific world

showed a certain widely held conception to be false

confirmed in a stunning manner what many of her peers had long suspected
Previous Confirm Finish
Show solution Hide solution
PRESENTED BY :
Scott Woodbury-Stewart Founder and Expert GMAT Instructor Scott Woodbury-Stewart Founder and Expert GMAT Instructor

Text Solution:

Our first information finding step in answering this question is to find its focus, which is “Jane Goodall’s observation that chimpanzees fashion simple tools.”

Our second step is to find in the stem some keywords to use to find in the passage the information we need for answering the question. Since Jane Goodall and chimpanzees are mentioned throughout the passage, the keywords in the stem that are most unique to this question are “fashion simple tools.”

Scanning the passage for those keywords and using what we recall about where the passage mentions chimpanzees fashioning simple tools, we find that S6 says, “Also, during this period, she observed chimpanzees fashioning simple tools that they then used to “fish” for termites.”

So, the information we need for answering this question will likely come from S6 or from sentences located near to S6 in the passage.

(A) was made while she was engaging in field study in 1970

The easiest way to confirm whether this choice is correct is to scan the passage for “1970” and see whether, according to the passage, 1970 is the year when Jane Goodall observed chimpanzees fashioning simple tools.

We find “1970” in S8, which begins by saying “Later, in 1970 ….” Since, S8 indicates that 1970 was “later” than when Jane Goodall observed chimpanzees fashioning tools, this choice appears to be incorrect.

Just to be sure, we can look earlier in the 2nd paragraph to see whether there’s additional information on the time sequence, and indeed there is. S5 says, “During her first period of field study, in 1960 …,” and then, S6 says, “Also, during this period, she observed chimpanzees fashioning simple tools. So, we can see that, according to the passage, Jane Goodall observed chimpanzees fashioning tools in 1960, not, as this choice says, in 1970.

(B) showed for the first time that termites are an important component of the diet of chimpanzees

To see whether this choice is correct, we can scan the part of the passage about “fashioning simple tools” for the keyword “termites.”

Doing so, we find “termites” in the following context:

she observed chimpanzees fashioning simple tools that they then used to “fish” for termites. Since, at the time, the common wisdom was that humans alone among all animals modify objects to create tools, this discovery stunned the scientific world.

We see that the passage does not say or imply that Goodall’s observation “showed for the first timethat termites are an important component of the diet of chimpanzees.”

So, this choice is not supported by the passage.

(C) was disputed by most members of the scientific world

To see whether this choice is correct, we can scan the part of the passage about “fashioning simple tools” for the keywords “scientific world.” Doing so, we see that S7 says, “this discovery stunned the scientific world.” Since the fact that “this discovery stunned the scientific world” does not mean that the observation “was disputed by most members of the scientific world,” this choice is not supported.

CORRECT ANSWER(D) showed a certain widely held conception to be false

Scanning the area of the passage near the sentence that says, “she observed chimpanzees fashioning simple tools,” S6, we see that S7 says, “Since, at the time, the common wisdom was that humans alone among all animals modify objects to create tools, this discovery stunned the scientific world.”

Notice that “common wisdom” is a synonym for “widely held conception.”

So, we can see that the discovery that chimpanzees fashion simple tools “showed a certain widely held conception,” the conception “that humans alone among all animals modify objects to create tools,” to be false.

Thus, this choice is supported by the passage.

(E) confirmed in a stunning manner what many of her peers had long suspected

Scanning the area of the passage near the sentence that says, “she observed chimpanzees fashioning simple tools,” we see that S7 says, “Since, at the time, the common wisdom was that humans alone among all animals modify objects to create tools, this discovery stunned the scientific world.”

So, according to the passage, Jane Goodall’s observation that chimpanzees fashion simple tools did not “confirm what many of her peers had long suspected.” Rather, it showed that common wisdom was incorrect.

Correct answer: D
Frequently Asked Questions

Let’s now discuss we may have to find information in sentences other than the sentences that include keywords.

topics.topicName: 3.5 We may have to find information in sentences other than the sentences that include keywords
topics.content:
3. Detail, Inference, Application, Assumption, Weaken and Strengthen

3.5 We may have to find information in sentences other than the sentences that include keywords

A sentence that includes keywords from the question stem or answer choice won’t always provide the information we need to answer the question. So, often, once we have located a keyword in the passage, we have to look in sentences above or below the keyword in order to find the information we need to answer the question.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

Often, once we have located a keyword in the passage, we have to look in sentences above or below the keyword in order to find the information we need to answer the question.

For instance, a question stem could read as follows:

According to the passage, the career path of Rudolph Nureyev could be described in which of the following ways?

The focus of the question is “the career path of Rudolph Nureyev,” and to find the information we need in order to answer the question, we could look in the passage for “Rudolph Nureyev” or “career path.

In doing so, we might arrive at the following area of the passage:

However, many dancers are able to successfully make the transition from dancer to choreographer and, thus, extend their participation in dance for decades. The career of Rudolph Nureyev followed such a path.

We see the keywords “career,” “path,” and “Rudolph Nureyev” in the second sentence of the above passage segment. However, that sentence does not provide us with the information we need to answer the question; it doesn’t indicate how his career path “could be described.”

Our move in this case is to notice the look above marker “SUCH a path” and look above the sentence in which the keywords are found to locate the information we need for answering the question. In doing so, we see “many dancers are able to successfully make the transition from dancer to choreographer.” Notice that, now, we have the information we need for answering the question. We see that Nureyev’s career path must have progressed from dancing to choreographing.

Notice that, in this case, we used a combination of keywords and a look above marker, “SUCH a path,” to work our way to the information we needed for answering the question. Often, we can work our way to the information we need for answering a question by using a combination of keywords and a look above marker.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

Often, we can work our way to the information we need for answering a question by using a combination of keywords and a look above marker.

topics.topicName: 3.6 Handling Synonymic Shifts When Finding Information in Passages
topics.content:
3. Detail, Inference, Application, Assumption, Weaken and Strengthen

3.6 Handling Synonymic Shifts When Finding Information in Passages

Sometimes the GMAT uses synonyms or related words, rather than the same words, in a question and in the passage.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

Sometimes the GMAT uses synonyms or related words, rather than the same words, in a question and in the passage.

For instance, a question could ask about “participation in elections” when the passage uses “voting,” or a question could mention “research” when the passage discusses “experiments.”

So, sometimes, when we look for information in the passage, we have to consider words with the same meaning as words in the question stem or answer choice.

For example, consider the following question stem:

The author of the passage would be most likely to agree that which of the following is a common reason why children have difficulty focusing?

After reading that stem, we could find the following in the passage:

Stressful life circumstances can have many detrimental effects on children’s development. For example, a recent study has shown that stressful life circumstances often result in children’s having difficulty concentrating.

We can see that, whereas the question stem uses the word “focusing,” the passage uses the word “concentrating.” Of course, since these words mean the same thing in the contexts in which they appear in this example, we can use the information on “difficulty concentrating” to correctly answer the question about “difficulty focusing.”

Let’s consider an answer choice:

(A) The observed acceleration of the comet can be attributed to Jupiter’s gravity.

After reading that answer choice, we might see the following in the passage:

This information on the positions of the comet and the planets makes clear what occurred. Jupiter’s gravity caused the increase in the speed at which the comet was traveling.

In this case, “acceleration of the comet” means the same thing as “increase in the speed at which the comet was traveling.” OK, that match is pretty easy to see.

At the same time, this example includes another twist. The answer choice uses the wording “can be attributed to,” whereas the passage uses “caused.” So, in this case, what we have to notice is that, even though “can be attributed to” and “caused” don’t mean exactly the same thing, both indicate a cause-and-effect relationship between two things. In other words, their meanings in context are about the same.

So, we can clearly see that the information in the passage is the information we would need to determine whether that answer choice answers the question.

Consider the following example.

Example 3

S1: There is a groupthink prevalent among lawmakers that prohibition is an effective tool for controlling the manufacture, sale, and consumption of illicit drugs. S2: These lawmakers argue that prohibition works as intended by reducing the supply of illicit drugs, regardless of the demand for them, and they offer a number of tactics in pursuit of prohibition. S3: For example, they hold tight to the belief that they can sharply decrease quantities of illicit drugs reaching potential consumers by deploying throughout much of the world a vast array of agencies and personnel tasked with the discovery, interdiction, and destruction of illicit drugs. S4: In addition, they argue that, by increasing funding for law enforcement agencies responsible for arresting those involved with illicit drugs, they can further reduce the available supply. S5: However, despite what these lawmakers believe, market economics nearly ensure that prohibition will never be an effective tool for combating the distribution of illicit drugs.

S6: Take cocaine as an example. S7: In Colombia alone, coca plants are grown on a vast 450,000 acres of remote farmland, and even after large-scale efforts to locate and eradicate these crops, farmers will harvest and process enough coca leaves for the production of thousands of tons of cocaine. S8: In addition, because drug cartels are the only wholesale buyers of cocaine, they are able to unilaterality dictate the price that they pay for each kilogram of refined cocaine. S9: As a result, over the past four decades, the street value of cocaine has remained remarkably stable, at about $150,000 per kilogram, a price that allows for enormous profits from the sale of cocaine. S10: With such a large profit potential, not even the harshest of prison sentences can keep dealers at bay; there will always be people willing to bear the risks in pursuit of such profits.

According to the passage, which of the following is true of the large profit potential associated with cocaine?

Its magnitude has varied sharply from decade to decade.

It results from the high street value of cocaine.

It is not large enough to motivate people to enter the drug trade.

Harsh prison sentences have a tendency to reduce it.

Coca farmers in South America have a large impact on it.

Example 3 - Question 1

easy

S1: There is a groupthink prevalent among lawmakers that prohibition is an effective tool for controlling the manufacture, sale, and consumption of illicit drugs. S2: These lawmakers argue that prohibition works as intended by reducing the supply of illicit drugs, regardless of the demand for them, and they offer a number of tactics in pursuit of prohibition. S3: For example, they hold tight to the belief that they can sharply decrease quantities of illicit drugs reaching potential consumers by deploying throughout much of the world a vast array of agencies and personnel tasked with the discovery, interdiction, and destruction of illicit drugs. S4: In addition, they argue that, by increasing funding for law enforcement agencies responsible for arresting those involved with illicit drugs, they can further reduce the available supply. S5: However, despite what these lawmakers believe, market economics nearly ensure that prohibition will never be an effective tool for combating the distribution of illicit drugs.

S6: Take cocaine as an example. S7: In Colombia alone, coca plants are grown on a vast 450,000 acres of remote farmland, and even after large-scale efforts to locate and eradicate these crops, farmers will harvest and process enough coca leaves for the production of thousands of tons of cocaine. S8: In addition, because drug cartels are the only wholesale buyers of cocaine, they are able to unilaterality dictate the price that they pay for each kilogram of refined cocaine. S9: As a result, over the past four decades, the street value of cocaine has remained remarkably stable, at about $150,000 per kilogram, a price that allows for enormous profits from the sale of cocaine. S10: With such a large profit potential, not even the harshest of prison sentences can keep dealers at bay; there will always be people willing to bear the risks in pursuit of such profits.

QUESTION
Showing:
Question

According to the passage, which of the following is true of the large profit potential associated with cocaine?

Its magnitude has varied sharply from decade to decade.

It results from the high street value of cocaine.

It is not large enough to motivate people to enter the drug trade.

Harsh prison sentences have a tendency to reduce it.

Coca farmers in South America have a large impact on it.
Previous Confirm Finish
Show solution Hide solution
PRESENTED BY :
Scott Woodbury-Stewart Founder and Expert GMAT Instructor Scott Woodbury-Stewart Founder and Expert GMAT Instructor

Text Solution:

Our first move in answering this question is to identify the focus of the question. Reading the question stem, we see that the focus is “the large profit potential associated with cocaine.”

Next, we identify keywords to look for. Since “cocaine” is mentioned throughout the third paragraph, we’ll likely get the best results by looking for “large profit potential” in the 3rd paragraph.

Scanning the 2nd paragraph, we see that “large profit potential” is mentioned in S10, the last sentence of the passage. So, the information we need for answering the question will likely be located in or close to S10.

Then, we can go through the answer choices and carefully compare each with what the second paragraph says about the large profit potential associated with cocaine until we have eliminated the choices that are not supported by the passage and found one that is.

(A) Its magnitude has varied sharply from decade to decade.

By looking in the passage just above the sentence that mentions “the large profit potential,” we see the following:

over the past four decades, the street value of cocaine has remained remarkably stable, at about $150,000 per kilogram, a price that allows for enormous profits from the sale of cocaine

The information that the street value “has remained … stable” tends to conflict what this choice says about the magnitude of the profits varying, and it certainly does not support it.

CORRECT ANSWER(B) It results from the high street value of cocaine.

Homing in on the part of the passage that mentions “the large profit potential associated with cocaine,” we see that S10 says the following:

With such a large profit potential, not even the harshest of prison sentences can keep dealers at bay; there will always be people willing to bear the risks in pursuit of such profits.

So, S10 says does not mention what this choice is about, “the high street value of cocaine.”

At the same time, notice that “such” in “such a large profit potential” is a look above marker that indicates that the “large profit potential” was discussed also in a sentence above S10. So, we should check the sentences above S10 to see what they say about the large profit potential.

Checking S9, we see that it says the following:

the street value of cocaine has remained remarkably stable, at about $150,000 per kilogram, a price that allows for enormous profits from the sale of cocaine

So, S9 says essentially what this choice says, that “enormous profits,” in other words, “the large profit potential,” results from the high street value of cocaine.

Thus, this choice says what’s true according to the passage.

(C) It is not large enough to motivate people to enter the drug trade.

This choice says the opposite of what the passage says, which is that “With such a large profit potential, not even the harshest of prison sentences can keep dealers at bay; there will always be people willing to bear the risks ….”

(D) Harsh prison sentences have a tendency to reduce it.

The passage says nothing that supports what this choice says.

In answering RC questions, we have to be careful to stick to what’s supported by the passage. In this case, while it’s possible that harsh prison sentences have a tendency to reduce the profit potential associated with cocaine, that speculation is not supported by the passage.

(E) Coca farmers in South America have a large impact on it.

By looking in the passage for information on coca farmers, we find the following:

farmers will harvest and process enough coca leaves for the production of thousands of tons of cocaine. In addition, because drug cartels are the only wholesale buyers of cocaine, they are able to unilaterality dictate the price that they pay for each kilogram of refined cocaine

The fact that drug cartels “are able to unilaterality dictate the price that they pay for … cocaine” tends to conflict with and certainly does not support this choice.

So, this choice is not supported by the passage.

Correct answer: B
Frequently Asked Questions

Let’s now discuss correct answers in Detail questions so that we’ll be ready to recognize them.

topics.topicName: 3.7 Correct Answers in Detail RC Questions
topics.content:
3. Detail, Inference, Application, Assumption, Weaken and Strengthen

3.7 Correct Answers in Detail RC Questions

While the correct answer to a Detail question will be about a specific detail of the passage, correct answers to Detail questions generally will not say what the passage says in the exact same way the passage says it. So, to prepare ourselves to recognize Detail correct answers when we see them, let’s discuss the two main types of correct answers to Detail questions. They are:

- Detail correct answers based on one thing said in the passage

- Detail correct answers based on multiple statements in the passage

Let’s now discuss the first of these.

topics.topicName: 3.8 Detail Correct Answers Based on One Thing Said in the Passage
topics.content:
3. Detail, Inference, Application, Assumption, Weaken and Strengthen

3.8 Detail Correct Answers Based on One Thing Said in the Passage

In many cases, the correct answer to a Detail question is based on one thing said in the passage.

For instance, some correct answers to Detail questions will simply restate something from the passage in almost the same way the passage says it.

For example, let’s say that a passage says the following:

Dylan Thomas began to write the poem while in Italy.

A correct answer to a Detail question about that passage could be:

(Correct Answer) Dylan Thomas began composing this poem while in Italy.

We can see that the above correct answer restates what the passage says almost word for word.

Such a correct answer will be easy to recognize as long as we locate the right information in the passage.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

Some Detail correct answers restate something in the passage almost word for word.

However, not all Detail correct answers will use wording so close to the wording in the passage. In fact, some Detail correct answers based on one thing said in the passage will use synonyms to say the same thing the passage says in a whole new way.

For example, let’s say that a passage says the following:

Because its performances fit the consciousness of the times, the dance company quickly became popular.

A correct answer to a Detail question about that passage could be:

(Correct Answer) The dance company’s rapid rise in popularity resulted from the fact that its productions were well suited to the mindset of the public.

Notice that, in this case, the correct answer uses different wording to say the same thing the passage says in a new way.

We can see that “rapid rise in popularity” in the correct answer matches “quickly became popular” in the passage, and that “resulted from the fact that its productions were well suited to the mindset of the public” matches “because its performances fit the consciousness of the times.”

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

Some Detail correct answers restate something in the passage in a whole new way.

Alternatively, a Detail correct answer can be a rearranged version of a statement in the passage. In such a case, the correct answer may say something slightly different from what the statement in the passage says.

For example, let’s say that a passage says the following:

For people currently living in the centuries-old cave homes of the Loire valley, brushing rock dust off their clothing is a routine task.

The correct answer to a Detail question about that passage could be:

(Correct Answer) Even though they must routinely brush rock dust off their clothing, some people live in cave homes created long ago.

Notice that the correct answer is mostly a rearrangement of the statement from the passage.

Also, the correct answer is based on the statement in the passage but says something a little different.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

A Detail correct answer can be a rearranged version of a statement in the passage and say something based on, though not exactly the same as, what the passage says.

So, we can see that the correct answer to a Detail question will be a choice that says something the passage says but perhaps not in the same way.

In fact, sometimes, the correct answer to a Detail question is the choice among of the five choices whose wording is the most different from the wording of the passage. So, in looking for the correct answer to a Detail question, we have to go beyond word matching. We have to carefully find a choice that actually says something the passage says and answers the question asked.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

Sometimes, the correct answer to a Detail question is the choice among the five choices whose wording is the most different from the wording of the passage.

To develop skill in identifying Detail correct answers that are based on one thing said in the passage, let’s do some Targeted Practice.

Targeted Practice

For each set of sentences, choose the choice that most accurately reflects what the original sentence says.

Question
1 of 5
0%
accuracy

Once the turtles hatch, they immediately crawl to the ocean and swim away.

Explanation:

We can see that “After hatching” in (A) matches “Once the turtles hatch” in the original sentence, and that “the turtles quickly make their way to the ocean and begin swimming” in (A) conveys a meaning similar to that of “they immediately crawl to the ocean and swim away” in the original sentence.

On the other hand, “the turtles hatch in the ocean” in (B) contradicts what the original sentence says, since turtles would not have to “crawl to the ocean” if they were to “hatch in the ocean.”

Correct answer: A
Next
Question
2 of 5
0%
accuracy

The anthropologists based their conclusions on studies of traditional Chinese medicine and Native American healing techniques.

Explanation:

Notice that (A) is wrong for two reasons. One is that (A) says, “conclusions about different cultures.” The original sentence says only “conclusions” and does not say that those conclusions were “about different cultures.” The second reason that (A) is wrong is that (A) says the anthropologists used “traditional research methods,” whereas the original sentence does not say that the anthropologists used “traditional methods.”

On the other hand, in (B) “The anthropologists’ conclusions were supported by research” matches “The anthropologists based their conclusions on studies” in the original sentence,” and “different cultures’ methods” in (B) is a shorter way of saying “traditional Chinese medicine and Native American healing techniques.”

Correct answer: B
Next
Question
3 of 5
0%
accuracy

Because lords needed the support of their tenants in order to maintain their wealth, serfs were not completely without power.

Explanation:

Choice (A) says essentially what the original sentence says. Notice that “serfs had some power” in (A) means the same thing as “serfs were not completely without power” in the original sentence, and that “serfs were an important source of income for lords” means basically the same the same thing as “lords needed the support of serfs in order to maintain their wealth.”

On the other hand, (B) contradicts what the original sentence says. After all, “serfs were completely without power” in (B) is the opposite of “serfs were not completely without power” in the original sentence.

Correct answer: A
Next
Question
4 of 5
0%
accuracy

As a result of its immunity to cobra venom, the honey badger is one of the few mammals that can survive being bitten by a cobra multiple times.

Explanation:

Notice that (A) is basically a rearranged version of the original sentence. “There is a mammal called the honey badger” in (A) basically matches “the honey badger is one of the few mammals” in the original sentence. Also, “because it is immune to cobra venom” in (A) means the same thing as “as a result of its immunity to cobra venom” in the original sentence.

On the other hand, (B) is incorrect because “most mammals … can survive” in (B) means that the majority of mammals can survive, whereas “one of the few mammals that can survive” in the original sentence implies that only a few mammals can survive cobra bites, and that the majority cannot.

Correct answer: A
Next
Question
5 of 5
0%
accuracy

Believing an educated populace to be necessary for the success of the new nation, the founders gave the establishment of a school system high priority.

Explanation:

Notice that, even though (A) uses wording similar to that of the original sentence, such as “nation’s founders,” “established a school system,” and “populace,” (A) does not match the original sentence. After all, the original sentence does not say anything about “demands made by the populace.” It says that the founders believed “an educated populace to be necessary.”

On the other hand, (B) says something similar to what the original sentence says. After all, “emphasized the creation of an educational system” in (B) has a meaning similar to “gave the establishment of a school system high priority” in the original sentence, and “a positive outcome” is a less specific way of saying “the success of the new nation.”

Correct answer: B
Finish

Consider the following example.

Example 4

S1: Some psychologists believe that fairness is a concept exclusive to humans. S2: However, recently conducted research shows that fairness can evolve in not only human societies but also animal societies. S3: In studying the behavior of seven groups of banded mongooses in Uganda, zoologist Harry Marshall determined that, within a group of these small, cat-like animals, there exists a remarkable birth synchrony; most of the expectant females give birth to their pups on the same night, creating what zoologists call a “veil of ignorance” — because all of the pups have almost identical looks, smells, and vocal frequencies, parents are unable to determine which pups belong to which parents and therefore cannot choose to provide them with extra care on that basis alone. S4: Therefore, whereas, in most of the natural world, parents favor their own offspring, these mongoose parents care for all of the pups equitably, giving the litter a better chance of survival than they would otherwise have. S5: For example, by providing extra care to pups born with low birth weights, including allowing these pups the opportunity to suckle greater amounts of milk than heavier pups, female mongooses are able to provide a fairness calibration, with the result that within a few weeks after birth, any disparities in weight among pups have been greatly reduced.

According to the author, banded mongoose parents do not favor their own offspring because of which of the following?

They believe that it is fairer to provide equitable care.

They are not able to see, smell, or hear pups in the litter.

They cannot distinguish their own pups from other pups.

They want to give the litter a better chance of survival.

They provide extra care to pups born with low birth weights.

Example 4 - Question 1

easy

S1: Some psychologists believe that fairness is a concept exclusive to humans. S2: However, recently conducted research shows that fairness can evolve in not only human societies but also animal societies. S3: In studying the behavior of seven groups of banded mongooses in Uganda, zoologist Harry Marshall determined that, within a group of these small, cat-like animals, there exists a remarkable birth synchrony; most of the expectant females give birth to their pups on the same night, creating what zoologists call a “veil of ignorance” — because all of the pups have almost identical looks, smells, and vocal frequencies, parents are unable to determine which pups belong to which parents and therefore cannot choose to provide them with extra care on that basis alone. S4: Therefore, whereas, in most of the natural world, parents favor their own offspring, these mongoose parents care for all of the pups equitably, giving the litter a better chance of survival than they would otherwise have. S5: For example, by providing extra care to pups born with low birth weights, including allowing these pups the opportunity to suckle greater amounts of milk than heavier pups, female mongooses are able to provide a fairness calibration, with the result that within a few weeks after birth, any disparities in weight among pups have been greatly reduced.

QUESTION
Showing:
Question

According to the author, banded mongoose parents do not favor their own offspring because of which of the following?

They believe that it is fairer to provide equitable care.

They are not able to see, smell, or hear pups in the litter.

They cannot distinguish their own pups from other pups.

They want to give the litter a better chance of survival.

They provide extra care to pups born with low birth weights.
Previous Confirm Finish
Show solution Hide solution
PRESENTED BY :
Scott Woodbury-Stewart Founder and Expert GMAT Instructor Scott Woodbury-Stewart Founder and Expert GMAT Instructor

Text Solution:

Reading the stem, we can see that the focus of this question is “banded mongoose parents do not favor their own offspring.” So, to find the information we need for answering the question, we can look in the passage for the keywords “favor their own offspring,” or for synonyms of “favor their own offspring.”

Scanning the passage, we find “parents favor their own offspring” in S4, which says, “Therefore, whereas, in most of the natural world, parents favor their own offspring, these mongoose parents care for all of the pups equitably, giving the litter a better chance of survival than they would otherwise have.”

There are two key things to notice about S4. One is that it implies that “these mongoose parents” differ from other parents in the natural world in that “these mongoose parents” do not favor their own offspring. The other thing to notice is that S4 begins with the causation marker “therefore.” So, reason why the mongoose parents do not favor their own offspring will be found in the sentence that precedes “therefore.”

Reviewing the sentence that precedes “therefore,” S3, we see that it says, “parents are unable to determine which pups belong to which parents and therefore cannot choose to provide them with extra care on that basis alone.”

So, it appears that banded mongoose parents do not favor their own offspring because they are unable to determine which pups belong to which parents.

(A) They believe that it is fairer to provide equitable care.

The wording of this choice is similar to wording found in S4, “these mongoose parents care for all of the pups equitably.”

Notice, however, that the passage does not say that the mongoose parents “believe that it is fairer to provide equitable care.” The passage says nothing about what they “believe.”

So, this choice is not supported by the passage.

(B) They are not able to see, smell, or hear pups in the litter.

This choice distorts what the passage says.

The passage says, “because all of the pups have almost identical looks, smells, and vocal frequencies, parents are unable to determine which pups belong to which parents,” and this choice twists what the passage says into the idea that the parents “are not able to see, smell, or hear pups.”

Notice “not able to see, smell, or hear pups” means that the parents cannot sense the pups at all, whereas the passage implies that the parents can see, hear, and smell the pups yet “are unable to determine” which pups are theirs.

So, this choice is not supported by the passage.

CORRECT ANSWER(C) They cannot distinguish their own pups from other pups.

As we discussed in the introduction to this explanation, the passage presents in S3 the reason why the mongoose parents do not favor their own offspring: “parents are unable to determine which pups belong to which parents and therefore cannot choose to provide them with extra care on that basis alone.”

Notice that this choice says what S3 says in a new way. After all, “They cannot distinguish their own pups from other pups,” means basically the same thing as “parents are unable to determine which pups belong to which parents.”

So, this choice says what’s true according to the author.

(D) They want to give the litter a better chance of survival.

Scanning the passage for “better chance of survival,” we see that S4 says, “these mongoose parents care for all of the pups equitably, giving the litter a better chance of survival than they would otherwise have.” So, the wording of this choice, “give the litter a better chance of survival,” matches some wording of the passage.

Notice, however, that this choice is incorrect, because the passage does not say that the mongoose parents don’t favor their own pups because “They want to give the litter a better chance of survival.” The passage does not say anything about what the mongooses “want.”

While it’s possible that the mongoose parents want to give the litter a better chance of survival, the correct answer to a Detail question has to be based on what the passage says, not on what’s possible.

(E) They provide extra care to pups born with low birth weights.

This choice could be tempting, because it matches what the passage says in S5, “by providing extra care to pups born with low birth weights.”

However, we have to choose a choice that not only says what the passage says but also answers the question asked.

In this case, the correct answer must be the reason why the mongoose parents don’t favor their own offspring. Thus, since the fact that mongoose parents provide extra care to pups born with low birth weights is not the reason why mongoose parents do not favor their own offspring, this choice is not the correct answer.

Correct answer: C
Frequently Asked Questions

Let’s now discuss Detail correct answers based on multiple statements in the passage.
