topics.topicName: 3.21 Correct Answers in Inference RC Questions
topics.content:
3. Detail, Inference, Application, Assumption, Weaken and Strengthen

3.21 Correct Answers in Inference RC Questions

The correct answer to an Inference RC question will state a conclusion supported by the passage, and there are three main ways in which Inference correct answers work. They are:

- State a conclusion supported by a single statement in the passage.

- Reverse something the passage says to state the logical equivalent of what the passage says.

- State a conclusion supported by two or more statements in the passage.

Let’s discuss each of these.

Inference Correct Answers that State a Conclusion Supported by a Single Statement in the Passage

Many Inference correct answers state a conclusion based a single statement in the passage.

For example, let’s say that a passage says the following:

Politicians in the city got voters to vote for them by promising to make changes that had in fact already been made.

A correct answer to an Inference question about the passage could be the following:

(Correct Answer) Voters in the city voted for candidates whose promises were worthless.

We can see that the correct answer follows directly from the statement in the passage. After all, if it’s true that “Politicians in the city got voters to vote for them by promising to make changes that had in fact already been made,” we can certainly infer that “Voters in the city voted for candidates whose promises were worthless.” After all, a promise to make changes that have already been made is worthless.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

Many Inference question correct answers state a conclusion based on a single statement in the passage.

Inference Correct Answers that Reverse Something the Passage Says to State the Logical Equivalent of What the Passage Says

Another common way in which correct answers to Inference RC questions can work is by simply reversing a statement made by the passage to state the logical equivalent of what the passage says. This type of choice is similar to something we see in math: the statement “X is greater than Y,” is the logical equivalent of the reverse statement “Y is less than X.”

To see how this type of choice can work, let’s say that a passage says the following:

By the late 1900s, most of the people in Vietnam were able to read.

In this case, an Inference correct answer that reverses what the passage says to state the logical equivalent could say the following:

(Correct Answer) By the late 1900s, people who could not read were in the minority in Vietnam.

We can see that “people who could not read were in the minority” states the logical equivalent of “most of the people … were able to read” in a reversed way. After, all, if most of the people were able to read, then it must be true that people who could not read were in the minority.

For another example, let’s say that a passage says the following:

Rote memorization is not the most effective method for learning.

In this case, an Inference Correct answer that reverses what the passage says to state the logical equivalent could say the following:

(Correct Answer) There are methods of learning that are more effective than rote memorization.

We can see that “There are methods of learning that are more effective than rote memorization,” states the logical equivalent of “Rote memorization is not the most effective method for learning,” in a reversed way. After, all, if rote memorization is not the most effective method for learning, then it must be true that there are methods of learning that are more effective than rote memorization.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

Some Inference correct answers simply reverse a statement made by the passage to state the logical equivalent of what the passage says.

Inference Question Correct Answers That State a Conclusion Supported by Two or More Statements in the Passage

The third type of Inference correct answers are those that state a conclusion supported by the combination of two or more statements in the passage. These Inference correct answers may be supported by two sentences in the same paragraph or by pieces of information found in different parts of the passage.

For example, let’s say that a passage says the following:

In order for a game company to remain viable in the long term, it must continue to innovate because, in the gaming industry, innovation is occurring nonstop. At the same time, in order to continue to innovate, a game company must retain skilled personnel.

In that case, the correct answer to an Inference question about the passage could be:

(Correct Answer) A game company must retain skilled personnel in order to remain viable in the long term.

We can see that the above correct answer follows from what the paragraph says. After all, if it is true that

In order for a game company to remain viable in the long term, it must continue to innovate

and it is true that

in order to continue to innovate, a game company must retain skilled personnel

then it is true that

A game company must retain skilled personnel in order to remain viable in the long term.

So, in this case, the correct answer is supported by two statements in the same paragraph.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

Some Inference correct answers state something supported by the combination of two or more statements in the passage. These Inference correct answers may be supported by two sentences in the same paragraph or by pieces of information found in different parts of the passage.

Of course, since the correct answer to an Inference question will be supported by one or more statements in the passage, a key aspect of answering an Inference question is finding the information we need in the passage. To find that information, we’ll use basically the same approach we use to find information to support the correct answer to a Detail question. We will:

- Find the focus of the question.

- Choose keywords in the stem or in an answer choice to look for in the passage.

- Use those keywords and what we recall about where things are mentioned in the passage to locate the information we need.

Remember, the information we need for answering RC questions is right there in the passage. We just have to find it.

Consider the following example.

Example 16

S1: In 2013, along with Lars Peter Hansen, Eugene Fama and Robert Shiller were jointly awarded the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science. S2: The combination of the ideas of Fama and Shiller, in conjunction with work done by Hansen, has provided economists with a significantly enhanced understanding of how markets function, one worthy of such a prestigious prize. S3: Even so, the joint award astonished many in the economics community because Fama and Schiller are leading proponents of diametrically different views on how markets function.

S4: In the 1960s, Fama began shaping his ideas regarding what he would later term the “Efficient Market Theory,” which holds that the price movements of financial assets cannot be predicted because the prices of these assets fully reflect all available information. S5: According to the Efficient Market Theory, the prices of financial assets are rationally determined by investors. S6: Consequently, this model does not allow for the existence of asset bubbles, which are, by definition, situations that result from irrational increases in asset prices to levels well above any justified by economic fundamentals. S7: This theory of rational, efficient markets helped propel the rise of index funds, which are portfolios of stocks designed to mimic the performance of financial market indexes. S8: The general theory underlying the use of an index fund is that, if price movements of financial assets cannot be predicted, then stock-picking is a futile exercise, and most investors are better off owning a cross section of the entire market than attempting to determine which stocks will be winners or losers.

S9: On the other hand, Robert Shiller, whose work focuses on the integration of behavioral models into economic models, sees the pricing of financial assets as irrational, sometimes incredibly so, and argues that the predictability of prices is a reflection of irrational but repeating patterns of human behavior. S10: In fact, in his 1989 book “Market Volatility,” Robert Shiller wrote that the idea that stock prices were rational was “one of the most remarkable errors in the history of economic thought.” S11: Shiller sees financial asset bubbles as a natural consequence of irrational human behavior, and as a result believes that markets can and do create large, sustained mispricings. S12: Shiller predicted the sharp decline in stock prices in 2000 and the housing crash that began in 2006.

It can be inferred from the passage that Shiller would agree with which of the following statements regarding the prices of financial assets?

They can be predicted because humans are rational.

They take into account all available information.

Not all mispricings of such assets disappear immediately after occurring.

Irrational increases in such prices do not occur.

Sharp declines in prices of financial assets occur at regular intervals.

Example 16 - Question 1

easy

S1: In 2013, along with Lars Peter Hansen, Eugene Fama and Robert Shiller were jointly awarded the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science. S2: The combination of the ideas of Fama and Shiller, in conjunction with work done by Hansen, has provided economists with a significantly enhanced understanding of how markets function, one worthy of such a prestigious prize. S3: Even so, the joint award astonished many in the economics community because Fama and Schiller are leading proponents of diametrically different views on how markets function.

S4: In the 1960s, Fama began shaping his ideas regarding what he would later term the “Efficient Market Theory,” which holds that the price movements of financial assets cannot be predicted because the prices of these assets fully reflect all available information. S5: According to the Efficient Market Theory, the prices of financial assets are rationally determined by investors. S6: Consequently, this model does not allow for the existence of asset bubbles, which are, by definition, situations that result from irrational increases in asset prices to levels well above any justified by economic fundamentals. S7: This theory of rational, efficient markets helped propel the rise of index funds, which are portfolios of stocks designed to mimic the performance of financial market indexes. S8: The general theory underlying the use of an index fund is that, if price movements of financial assets cannot be predicted, then stock-picking is a futile exercise, and most investors are better off owning a cross section of the entire market than attempting to determine which stocks will be winners or losers.

S9: On the other hand, Robert Shiller, whose work focuses on the integration of behavioral models into economic models, sees the pricing of financial assets as irrational, sometimes incredibly so, and argues that the predictability of prices is a reflection of irrational but repeating patterns of human behavior. S10: In fact, in his 1989 book “Market Volatility,” Robert Shiller wrote that the idea that stock prices were rational was “one of the most remarkable errors in the history of economic thought.” S11: Shiller sees financial asset bubbles as a natural consequence of irrational human behavior, and as a result believes that markets can and do create large, sustained mispricings. S12: Shiller predicted the sharp decline in stock prices in 2000 and the housing crash that began in 2006.

QUESTION
Showing:
Question

It can be inferred from the passage that Shiller would agree with which of the following statements regarding the prices of financial assets?

They can be predicted because humans are rational.

They take into account all available information.

Not all mispricings of such assets disappear immediately after occurring.

Irrational increases in such prices do not occur.

Sharp declines in prices of financial assets occur at regular intervals.
Previous Confirm Finish
Show solution Hide solution
PRESENTED BY :
Scott Woodbury-Stewart Founder and Expert GMAT Instructor Scott Woodbury-Stewart Founder and Expert GMAT Instructor

Text Solution:

The focus of this question is on what “Shiller would agree with … regarding the prices of financial assets.” So, the information we need for answering this question will likely be found in the 3rd paragraph of the passage, which discusses Schiller’s views.

(A) They can be predicted because humans are rational.

This choice starts off correctly, because S9 says, “Robert Shiller … argues that the predictability of prices is a reflection of irrational but repeating patterns of human behavior.” So, S9 implies that Robert Schiller would agree that prices of financial assets “can be predicted.”

However, this choice goes wrong partway through, because S9 says that Shiller argues that “predictability of prices is a reflection of irrational … patterns of human behavior.” So, the passage suggests that Schiller believes that prices can be predicted because humans are irrational, not, as this choice says, because humans are rational.

This choice is a great example of why we have to read choices in their entirety to avoid choosing an incorrect choice.

(B) They take into account all available information.

Scanning the passage for “take into account all available information,” we see that S4 says, “the prices of these assets fully reflect all available information.”

Since the passage presents multiple people’s views, we have to check to see whose view “the prices of these assets fully reflect all available information,” is. Reviewing the beginning of S4, we see that this view belongs to Fama, not Shiller.

Furthermore, scanning the paragraph that discusses Shiller’s views, the 3rd paragraph, we see no mention of prices taking into account all available information.

So, this choice is not something that the passage says Shiller believes.

CORRECT ANSWER(C) Not all mispricings of such assets disappear immediately after occurring.

Scanning the 3rd paragraph for “mispricings,” we see that S11 says, “Shiller … believes that markets can and do create large, sustained mispricings.”

Notice that, if Shiller believes that financial markets create “sustained mispricings,” which are mispricings that last for a significant period of time, then he believes that “Not all mispricings of such assets disappear immediately after occurring.”

So, this choice can be inferred from what one sentence of the passage, S11, says.

(D) Irrational increases in such prices do not occur.

S11 says, “Shiller sees financial asset bubbles as a natural consequence of irrational human behavior.”

Notice that “asset bubbles” are defined in S6 as “situations that result from irrational increases in asset prices.”

So, we can see that, by saying, “Shiller sees financial asset bubbles as a natural consequence of irrational human behavior,” the passage implies that Shiller believes that irrational increases in prices do occur, which is the opposite of what this choice says.

On the other hand, S6 says of the Efficient Market Theory, “this model does not allow for the existence of asset bubbles, which are, by definition, situations that result from irrational increases in asset prices.” So, what S6 says about the Efficient Market Theory matches what this choice says.

So, this choice applies to Fama and the Efficient Market Theory rather than to Shiller.

(E) Sharp declines in prices of financial assets occur at regular intervals.

This choice is related to what the last sentence of the passage says, “Shiller predicted the sharp decline in stock prices in 2000 and the housing crash that began in 2006.”

However, the fact that Shiller predicted those two declines in prices does not indicate that Shiller believes that “Sharp declines in prices of financial assets occur at regular intervals,” as this choice says.

So, while it’s possible that Shiller believes what this choice says, this choice is not supported by the passage.

Correct answer: C
Frequently Asked Questions

Of course, a key aspect of correctly answering Inference questions is eliminating incorrect choices. So, let’s now discuss some common types of incorrect choices that appear in Inference questions.

As you’ll see, the incorrect choices that appear in Inference questions are similar to those that appear in Detail questions. So, what we’ll do is discuss each type of incorrect choice from an Inference perspective and then practice handling that type of choice in the context of an Inference question.

topics.topicName: 3.22 Inference Trap 1: Distortion
topics.content:
3. Detail, Inference, Application, Assumption, Weaken and Strengthen

3.22 Inference Trap 1: Distortion

Distortion trap choices in Inference questions say something related to or close to what can be inferred from the passage, but don’t quite get it right.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

In Inference questions, Distortion trap choices say something related to or close to what can be inferred from the passage, but don’t quite get it right.

For example, let’s say that a passage says the following:

In 1914, Henry Ford stunned the world by doubling the wage of the Ford Motor Company’s assembly line workers to five dollars a day, which was much more than assembly line workers at any other automobile company were paid. He did so to reduce the company’s high employee turnover, which was impairing production and causing the company to have to spend heavily on the hiring of new employees, and the strategy worked. In 1915, the company had to hire only 2000 employees.

An Inference question about the passage could be:

The passage suggests that Ford believed that, by means of a wage increase, the company would

(Distortion Choice) achieve an improvement in product quality.

(Correct Answer) achieve a reduction in costs.

We can see that the Distortion choice, “achieve an improvement in product quality,” misrepresents what can be inferred from the passage. After all, the passage says that Henry Ford doubled the wage to reduce turnover, which was “impairing production.” Thus, the passage suggests that he believed that the company would achieve an improvement in “production,” not an improvement in “product quality.”

Notice how the Distortion choice comes close to saying what can be inferred but goes wrong by using “product quality,” rather than the correct noun, “production.” As we have discussed, often, Distortion choices are incorrect because they use the wrong nouns or modifiers.

On the other hand, the correct answer follows from what the passage says. After all, in saying that Ford increased the wage to reduce turnover, which was “causing the company to have to spend heavily,” the passage suggests that Ford believed that, by means of a wage increase, the company would “achieve a reduction in costs.”

We can see from the above example why it can be easy to choose a Distortion choice in an Inference question. Distortion choices “feel like” what can be inferred from the passage. They say things that we may have gotten the impression can be inferred. For instance, in the case of the above example, we could associate the word “impairing” with poor quality and get the impression that the passage said something about quality.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

Distortion choices in Inference questions are tempting because they “feel like” what can be inferred from the passage. They say things that we may have gotten the impression can be inferred.

Accordingly, to avoid choosing a Distortion choice, before we decide that a choice is the correct answer to an inference question, we should be able to point to specific information in the passage and explain exactly how that information supports our choice.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

Before we decide that a choice is the correct answer to an Inference question, we should be able to point to specific information in the passage and explain exactly how that information supports our choice.

Let’s now practice handling Distortion choices in Inference questions by considering an example.

Example 17

S1: The speed of computers is currently limited by how fast they can move information from where it is located to where it must go next to be processed. S2: One factor that constrains the speed at which information is moved is the speed at which electrons can travel in silicon chips, which are integral computer components. S3: Because it takes electrons longer to travel greater distances, one way to make computers faster is to make the components of silicon chips smaller. S4: Over past decades, making these components smaller is exactly what engineers have done, and this process has resulted in staggering increases in computing power. S5: However, it is becoming increasingly difficult to make these components any smaller; at this point engineers will have to employ new techniques and technologies in order to continue the component miniaturization process.

S6: Advances in ability to visualize with high resolution the surface of a material can help with miniaturization because, to create smaller components, engineers must understand at the atomic level materials with the potential to be used for the creation of computer chips. S7: One promising technique is electron ptychography, which a research team led by David Muller of Cornell University has used to magnify the surface of a sample of crystal 100 million times. S8: Whereas traditional light microscopes utilize lenses to produce magnified images of the surface of a material, electron ptychography utilizes a flow of electrons to create an ultra-highly magnified image extremely representative of the surface of the image scanned.

The passage suggests which of the following about electron ptychography?

It magnifies electrons to produce a representative image.

It is always more useful than traditional light microscopes.

It uses crystal to create a highly magnified image.

It may contribute to computer engineers’ ability to miniaturize.

It has been used to create faster processors.

Example 17 - Question 1

easy

S1: The speed of computers is currently limited by how fast they can move information from where it is located to where it must go next to be processed. S2: One factor that constrains the speed at which information is moved is the speed at which electrons can travel in silicon chips, which are integral computer components. S3: Because it takes electrons longer to travel greater distances, one way to make computers faster is to make the components of silicon chips smaller. S4: Over past decades, making these components smaller is exactly what engineers have done, and this process has resulted in staggering increases in computing power. S5: However, it is becoming increasingly difficult to make these components any smaller; at this point engineers will have to employ new techniques and technologies in order to continue the component miniaturization process.

S6: Advances in ability to visualize with high resolution the surface of a material can help with miniaturization because, to create smaller components, engineers must understand at the atomic level materials with the potential to be used for the creation of computer chips. S7: One promising technique is electron ptychography, which a research team led by David Muller of Cornell University has used to magnify the surface of a sample of crystal 100 million times. S8: Whereas traditional light microscopes utilize lenses to produce magnified images of the surface of a material, electron ptychography utilizes a flow of electrons to create an ultra-highly magnified image extremely representative of the surface of the image scanned.

QUESTION
Showing:
Question

The passage suggests which of the following about electron ptychography?

It magnifies electrons to produce a representative image.

It is always more useful than traditional light microscopes.

It uses crystal to create a highly magnified image.

It may contribute to computer engineers’ ability to miniaturize.

It has been used to create faster processors.
Previous Confirm Finish
Show solution Hide solution
PRESENTED BY :
Scott Woodbury-Stewart Founder and Expert GMAT Instructor Scott Woodbury-Stewart Founder and Expert GMAT Instructor

Text Solution:

All the information we need to answer this Inference question will likely be found in the area of the passage that mentions “electron ptychography,” which is the last two sentences of the passage.

To ensure that we don’t choose a Distortion choice that misrepresents or twists what the passage ways, we can carefully compare every aspect of the choice we’re considering – each verb, noun, and modifier – with the passage.

(A) It magnifies electrons to produce a representative image.

Trap: Distortion

Scanning the sentence that mentions “magnified” in the context of “electron ptychography,” S8, we see that it says, “electron ptychography utilizes a flow of electrons to create an ultra-highly magnified image.”

We can quickly see that “magnifies electrons” in this choice does not match “utilizes a flow of electrons” in the passage.

A good way to avoid choosing this choice is noticing that the noun “electrons” is the wrong noun to use with “magnifies.”

(B) It is always more useful than traditional light microscopes.

Trap: Stretch

The fact that this choice uses the extreme marker “always” is a yellow flag indicating that this choice may be a Stretch choice.

Scanning the area of the passage where “traditional light microscopes” is mentioned, we see that it says, “Whereas traditional light microscopes utilize lenses to produce magnified images …, electron ptychography utilizes a flow of electrons.”

Notice that this comparison of how microscopes and electron ptychography work does not indicate that electron ptychography is “always more useful than traditional light microscopes.”

So, this choice goes beyond what the passage supports.

(C) It uses crystal to create a highly magnified image.

Trap: Distortion

Scanning the sentences in the passage that mention “electron ptychography” for something about “crystal,” we see that the passage says that a research team “has used” electron ptychography “to magnify the surface of a crystal.”

So, the passage says that electron ptychography can magnify crystal, not that it “uses crystal,” as this choice says.

Notice how, in saying that electron ptychography “uses crystal to create a highly magnified image,” this choice combines elements of the passage to say something that sounds like what the passage says but is not supported by the passage.

CORRECT ANSWER(D) It may contribute to computer engineers’ ability to miniaturize.

Scanning the part of the passage that mentions “miniaturization,” we see that S6 says, “Advances in ability to visualize with high resolution the surface of a material can help with miniaturization.” Then S7 says, “One promising technique is electron ptychography.”

We can see that, in mentioning “one promising technique,” the passage is presenting an example of a technique that may be one of the “Advances” that “can help with miniaturization.” So, those two statements in the passage support this choice, since the idea that electron ptychography “can help with miniaturization” matches “It may contribute to computer engineers’ ability to miniaturize.”

Also, S7 says that electron ptychography can be used to “magnify … 100 million times.” That fact means that electron ptychography is a technique that gives engineers “ability to visualize with high resolution the surface of a material,” which the passage indicates “can help with miniaturization.” Thus, we have more information indicating that electron ptychography “may contribute to computer engineers’ ability to miniaturize.”

So, this choice is an inference supported by the passage.

(E) It has been used to create faster processors.

Trap: Distortion

Notice that the passage terms electron ptychography a “promising technique.”

A promising technique is something that may work in the future. This choice, on the other hand, uses “has been used” to indicate that electron ptychography has already been used.

So, this choice misrepresents what the passage says by using the wrong tense verb.

Paying attention to verbs in choices is a key aspect of a winning RC game.

Correct answer: D

topics.topicName: 3.23 Inference Trap 2: Stretch
topics.content:
3. Detail, Inference, Application, Assumption, Weaken and Strengthen

3.23 Inference Trap 2: Stretch

Stretch trap choices in Inference questions state something similar to what can be inferred from the passage but take things further than what can be inferred from the passage.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

Stretch trap choices in Inference questions state something similar to what can be inferred from the passage but take things further than what can be inferred from the passage.

For example, let’s say that a passage says the following:

In 1914, Henry Ford stunned the world by doubling the wage of the Ford Motor Company’s assembly line workers to five dollars a day, which was much more than assembly line workers at any other automobile company were paid. He did so to reduce the company’s high employee turnover, which was impairing production and causing the company to have to spend heavily on the hiring of new employees, and the strategy worked. In 1915, the company had to hire only 2000 employees.

An Inference question about the passage could be:

Which of the following statements about wages can be inferred from the information in the passage?

(Stretch Choice) In 1914, no workers other than Ford Motor Company assembly line workers were paid five dollars a day.

(Correct Answer) When Henry Ford doubled the wage of Ford Motor Company workers in 1914, the daily wage of assembly line workers at most automobile companies was significantly less than five dollars.

Notice that, in using the extrememarker “no … other” in “no workers other than Ford Motor Company assembly line workers were paid five dollars a day,” the Stretch choice goes further than what can be inferred from the passage. After all, the passage provides information on only “assembly line workers at any other automobile company,” not on all workers at all companies. So, the passage does not include information that we can point to and say, “This information means that no other workers were paid five dollars a day.”

On the other hand, the correct answer says the logical equivalent of what the passage says in a reversed way. After all, “the daily wage of assembly line workers at most automobile companies was significantly less than five dollars” conveys in a reversed way the logical equivalent of “five dollars a day … was much more than assembly line workers at any other automobile company were paid.”

To avoid choosing Stretch choices in Inference questions, whenever we see extreme markers or strong language in a choice, we confirm whether the choice actually states an Inference supported by the passage or takes things too far.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

To avoid choosing Stretch choices in Inference questions, whenever we see extreme markers or strong language in a choice in an Inference question, we confirm whether the choice actually states an Inference supported by the passage or takes things too far.

To develop skill in handling Stretch choices in Inference questions, let’s consider an example.

Example 18

S1: Throughout the modern era, there has often been vigorous debate about the impact of technological developments. S2: Naturally, the internet is no exception. S3: In a recent book, The Shallows, author Nicholas Carr contends that the internet degrades human intelligence rather than enhances it. S4: He believes that the internet undermines people’s patience, concentration, and memory, by overloading their brains with stimuli, including the dozens of smartphone notifications received each day by the average person. S5: Carr notes that studies have found that this considerable exposure to internet-based notifications disrupts people’s ability to focus, even when the devices are not being used. S6: For instance, in a 2017 study from the McCombs School of Business, participants suffered a decline in focus despite the fact that their smartphones were turned off and placed in a pocket or face down on the table. S7: Carr finds it particularly alarming that nearly all of the participants were ignorant of this effect, claiming that their phones had not been a distraction.

S8: In contrast, many scholars challenge these concerns while emphasizing numerous benefits of the internet. S9: For example, neuropsychologist Vaughn Bell, PhD, argues that “worries about information overload are as old as information itself, with each generation reimagining the dangerous impacts of technology on mind and brain.” S10: Many others celebrate the power of the internet to provide unprecedented access to a wealth of knowledge, in addition to communication and collaboration tools, at a minimal cost. S11: While some experts, such as Nir Eyal, author of Indistractable, acknowledge that some individuals will inevitably misuse the internet, they argue that the positives vastly outweigh the negatives.

The passage suggests that Carr would most likely agree with which of the following statements about smartphones?

They are the most disruptive type of device that connects to the internet.

They have a negative impact on focus that not all of their users are aware of.

They are distracting to every one of their users even when placed in a pocket or face down on the table.

There are no other devices that send a greater number of notifications to their users each day.

There is no way to prevent them from causing declines in focus.

Example 18 - Question 1

easy

S1: Throughout the modern era, there has often been vigorous debate about the impact of technological developments. S2: Naturally, the internet is no exception. S3: In a recent book, The Shallows, author Nicholas Carr contends that the internet degrades human intelligence rather than enhances it. S4: He believes that the internet undermines people’s patience, concentration, and memory, by overloading their brains with stimuli, including the dozens of smartphone notifications received each day by the average person. S5: Carr notes that studies have found that this considerable exposure to internet-based notifications disrupts people’s ability to focus, even when the devices are not being used. S6: For instance, in a 2017 study from the McCombs School of Business, participants suffered a decline in focus despite the fact that their smartphones were turned off and placed in a pocket or face down on the table. S7: Carr finds it particularly alarming that nearly all of the participants were ignorant of this effect, claiming that their phones had not been a distraction.

S8: In contrast, many scholars challenge these concerns while emphasizing numerous benefits of the internet. S9: For example, neuropsychologist Vaughn Bell, PhD, argues that “worries about information overload are as old as information itself, with each generation reimagining the dangerous impacts of technology on mind and brain.” S10: Many others celebrate the power of the internet to provide unprecedented access to a wealth of knowledge, in addition to communication and collaboration tools, at a minimal cost. S11: While some experts, such as Nir Eyal, author of Indistractable, acknowledge that some individuals will inevitably misuse the internet, they argue that the positives vastly outweigh the negatives.

QUESTION
Showing:
Question

The passage suggests that Carr would most likely agree with which of the following statements about smartphones?

They are the most disruptive type of device that connects to the internet.

They have a negative impact on focus that not all of their users are aware of.

They are distracting to every one of their users even when placed in a pocket or face down on the table.

There are no other devices that send a greater number of notifications to their users each day.

There is no way to prevent them from causing declines in focus.
Previous Confirm Finish
Show solution Hide solution
PRESENTED BY :
Scott Woodbury-Stewart Founder and Expert GMAT Instructor Scott Woodbury-Stewart Founder and Expert GMAT Instructor

Text Solution:

The focus of this Inference question is what “Carr” believes about “smartphones.” We can see that Carr’s beliefs are discussed in S3 through S7, and “smartphones” are specifically mentioned in S4 through S7. So, we know to focus on these four sentences. At the same time, since this focus area is relatively long, we will have to analyze the choices particularly carefully and may have to use keywords in the choices to find the information we need.

A key aspect of getting an Inference question correct is noticing extreme markers or strong language that represents a yellow flag signaling that we may be dealing with a Stretch choice. When we see such clues in a choice, we have to carefully compare the choice with the passage to see whether the passage says something as extreme as what the choice says.

(A) They are the most disruptive type of device that connects to the internet.

 Trap: Stretch

The fact that this choice uses the extreme marker “most” is a yellow flag signaling that this choice may be a Stretch choice.

Scanning the area of the passage where Carr is discussed, we see it says that Carr “believes that the internet undermines people’s patience,” and that “Carr notes that … exposure to … notifications disrupts people’s ability to focus.”

Notice that nothing the passage says suggests that Carr believes that smartphones “are the most disruptive type of device.”

So, this choice goes beyond what the passage supports.

CORRECT ANSWER(B) They have a negative impact on focus that not all of their users are aware of.

 We can scan the area of the passage where Carr is discussed to find the keyword “focus” or a word with a meaning similar to “focus.”

“Focus” is mentioned in S5, S6, and S7.

S7 says, “Carr finds it particularly alarming that nearly all of the participants were ignorant of this effect.”

Since “ignorant of” means the same thing as “not … aware of” in this choice, and since “this effect” uses the look above marker “this,” we can look in the sentences above “this effect” to find what “this effect” is.

We see that S6 says, “participants suffered a decline in focus despite the fact that their smartphones were turned off.” So, the effect that “nearly all of the participants were ignorant of” is “a decline in focus” caused by smartphones.

Since “they have negative impact” in this choice matches smartphones caused “a decline in focus” in the passage, and since “not all of their users are aware of” matches “nearly all of the participants were ignorant of,” we can see that the passage says essentially what this choice says, that smartphones “have a negative impact that not all of their users are aware of.”

Finally, since the passage says that Carr “finds it …alarming” that the participants were ignorant of this negative effect, it’s clear that Carr would agree with what this choice says.

So, this choice can be inferred from what the passage says.

(C) They are distracting to every one of their users even when placed in a pocket or face down on the table.

 Trap: Stretch

The fact that this choice uses the extreme marker “every one” is a yellow flag signaling that this choice could be a Stretch choice.

Scanning the part of the passage that mentions smartphones “turned off and placed in a pocket or face down on the table,” S6, we see that the passage says that participants in a 2017 study “suffered a decline in focus despite the fact that their smartphones were turned off and placed in a pocket or face down on the table.”

Since participants in a 2017 study are not “every one of” smartphone users, this choice goes beyond what the passage says.

(D) There are no other devices that send a greater number of notifications to their users each day.

 Trap: Stretch

The fact that this choice uses the extreme marker “no other” is a yellow flag signaling that this choice could be a Stretch choice.

Scanning the part of the passage that mentions “notifications,” S4, we see that the passage says that Carr believes that “people’s patience, concentration, and memory” are undermined by “the dozens of smartphone notifications received each day by the average person.”

Since the fact that smartphones send “dozens of notifications” does not mean that there are no devices other than smartphones “that send a greater number of notifications,” this choice goes beyond what the passage says.

(E) There is no way to prevent them from causing declines in focus.

 Trap: Stretch

The fact that this choice uses the extreme marker “no way” is a yellow flag signaling that this choice could be a Stretch choice.

Scanning the part of the passage that mentions that smartphones cause “a decline in focus, S6, we see that the passage says, “participants suffered a decline in focus despite the fact that their smartphones were turned off and placed in a pocket or face down.”

The fact that smartphones turned off and put it in a pocket or face down caused declines in focus does not mean that “There is no way” to prevent smartphones from causing declines in focus.

So, this choice goes beyond what the passage says.

Correct answer: B

topics.topicName: 3.24 Inference Trap 3: Speculation
topics.content:
3. Detail, Inference, Application, Assumption, Weaken and Strengthen

3.24 Inference Trap 3: Speculation

A Speculation choice in an Inference question says something that could be true or is likely to be true in reality but is not supported by the passage.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

A Speculation choice in an Inference question says something that could be true or is likely to be true in reality but is not supported by the passage.

The fact that something could be true or is likely to be true in reality does not make it an inference. Inferences must be clearly supported by statements in the passage. So, while these Speculation trap choices reflect what goes on in the real world, they are not correct answers to Inference questions.

To see how a Speculation choice in an Inference question can work, let’s say that a passage says the following:

In 1914, Henry Ford stunned the world by doubling the wage of the Ford Motor Company’s assembly line workers to five dollars a day, which was much more than assembly line workers at any other automobile company were paid. He did so to reduce the company’s high employee turnover, which was impairing production and causing the company to have to spend heavily on the hiring of new employees, and the strategy worked. In 1915, the company had to hire only 2000 employees.

An Inference question about the passage could be the following:

The passage suggests that which of the following resulted from the doubling of wages at Ford Motor Company?

(Speculation Choice) Assembly line workers at other automobile companies left to work for the Ford Motor Company instead.

(Correct Answer) Employee turnover at the Ford Motor Company was lower after the wage increase than before the wage increase.

Notice that the Speculation choice could very well be true given what the passage says. After all, if as the passage says, five dollars a day “was much more than assembly line workers at any other automobile company were paid,” then it could be true that some assembly line workers at other companies left to work for the Ford Motor Company instead.

However, the Speculation choice is not correct, because it’s not supported by the passage. After all, the passage provides no information indicating that assembly line workers at other companies left.

The correct answer, on the other hand, is supported by the passage. After all, if the reason Henry Ford increased the wage was “to reduce the company’s high employee turnover,” and “the strategy worked,” then we can infer that “turnover … was lower after the wage increase than before the wage increase.”

To avoid choosing a Speculation choice in an Inference question, we have to be conscious of using what the passage says rather than our own ideas to support our choice. If we catch ourselves getting ready to choose a choice because of what’s true in the real world, it’s time to shift gears and go back to the passage to confirm whether the passage actually supports that choice.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

To avoid choosing a Speculation choice in an Inference question, we have to be conscious of using what the passage says rather our own ideas to support our choice.

Let’s practice handling Speculation trap choices in Inference questions by considering an example.

Example 19

S1: Some psychologists believe that fairness is a concept exclusive to humans. S2: However, recently conducted research shows that fairness can evolve in not only human societies but also animal societies. S3: In studying the behavior of seven groups of banded mongooses in Uganda, zoologist Harry Marshall determined that, within a group of these small, cat-like animals, there exists a remarkable birth synchrony; most of the expectant females give birth to their pups on the same night, creating what zoologists call a “veil of ignorance” — because all of the pups have almost identical looks, smells, and vocal frequencies, parents are unable to determine which pups belong to which parents and therefore cannot choose to provide them with extra care on that basis alone. S4: Therefore, whereas, in most of the natural world, parents favor their own offspring, these mongoose parents care for all of the pups equitably, giving the litter a better chance of survival than they would otherwise have. S5: For example, by providing extra care to pups born with low birth weights, including allowing these pups the opportunity to suckle greater amounts of milk than heavier pups, female mongooses are able to provide a fairness calibration, with the result that within a few weeks after birth, any disparities in weight among pups have been greatly reduced.

The passage suggests that Harry Marshall’s work provides evidence for which of the following views?

No banded mongoose within a group gives birth to pups on a night when others do not.

Fairness can evolve in animals other than banded mongooses.

Banded mongoose mothers are aware that they give the litter a better chance of survival by caring for all of the pups equitably.

Only banded mongooses experience the phenomenon of birth synchrony.

The veil of ignorance results in mongoose parents’ not providing extra care to their own offspring.

Example 19 - Question 1

easy

S1: Some psychologists believe that fairness is a concept exclusive to humans. S2: However, recently conducted research shows that fairness can evolve in not only human societies but also animal societies. S3: In studying the behavior of seven groups of banded mongooses in Uganda, zoologist Harry Marshall determined that, within a group of these small, cat-like animals, there exists a remarkable birth synchrony; most of the expectant females give birth to their pups on the same night, creating what zoologists call a “veil of ignorance” — because all of the pups have almost identical looks, smells, and vocal frequencies, parents are unable to determine which pups belong to which parents and therefore cannot choose to provide them with extra care on that basis alone. S4: Therefore, whereas, in most of the natural world, parents favor their own offspring, these mongoose parents care for all of the pups equitably, giving the litter a better chance of survival than they would otherwise have. S5: For example, by providing extra care to pups born with low birth weights, including allowing these pups the opportunity to suckle greater amounts of milk than heavier pups, female mongooses are able to provide a fairness calibration, with the result that within a few weeks after birth, any disparities in weight among pups have been greatly reduced.

QUESTION
Showing:
Question

The passage suggests that Harry Marshall’s work provides evidence for which of the following views?

No banded mongoose within a group gives birth to pups on a night when others do not.

Fairness can evolve in animals other than banded mongooses.

Banded mongoose mothers are aware that they give the litter a better chance of survival by caring for all of the pups equitably.

Only banded mongooses experience the phenomenon of birth synchrony.

The veil of ignorance results in mongoose parents’ not providing extra care to their own offspring.
Previous Confirm Finish
Show solution Hide solution
PRESENTED BY :
Scott Woodbury-Stewart Founder and Expert GMAT Instructor Scott Woodbury-Stewart Founder and Expert GMAT Instructor

Text Solution:

The focus of this Inference question is Harry Marshall’s work. So, to find the information we need for supporting our choice, we’ll look in the area of the passage where Harry Marshall and his work are mentioned.

In evaluating each choice, we’ll carefully consider whether it’s supported by what the passage says about Harry Marshall’s work.

Any choice that could be true or is likely true in reality but isn’t supported by information in the passage will be an incorrect Speculation choice.

(A) No banded mongoose within a group gives birth to pups on a night when others do not.

Trap: Stretch

In reading this choice, we see that it uses the extreme marker “no” to convey an extreme meaning. In fact, in saying that NO banded mongoose gives birth on a different night, this choice implies that ALL of the banded mongooses give birth on the same night.

Of course, that extreme meaning is a red flag indicating that this choice may be incorrect. So, we go back to the passage to see whether it says something as extreme as what this choice says about mongooses giving birth.

Scanning the passage, we see that S3 says, “most of the expectant females give birth to their pups on the same night.”

Since “most of the expectant females” is not as extreme as what this choice implies, which is that all of the expectant females give birth on the same night, this choice is not correct.

(B) Fairness can evolve in animals other than banded mongooses.

Trap: Speculation

Scanning the part of the passage that mentions Harry Marshall and his work, we see that it is very specifically about the birth habits of banded mongooses and says nothing about animals other than banded mongooses.

So, while this choice could be true, it’s not supported by what the passage says about Harry Marshall’s work.

(C) Banded mongoose mothers are aware that they give the litter a better chance of survival by caring for all of the pups equitably.

Trap: Speculation

By starting where the passage mentions Harry Marshall and scanning what follows, we can find in S4 “these mongoose parents care for all of the pups equitably, giving the litter a better chance of survival than they would otherwise have.”

However, nowhere in the passage is there any information indicating what “banded mongoose mothers are aware” of. In other words, the passage does not say what’s going on in the minds of banded mongooses. It describes only their actions.

So, while this choice could be true, what it says about what banded mongoose mothers are aware of is not supported by the passage.

(D) Only banded mongooses experience the phenomenon of birth synchrony.

Trap: Speculation

If you picked this choice, you may have noticed that the passage says that the birth synchrony of banded mongooses is “remarkable,” which means “notable” or “unusual.” So, we could perceive “remarkable” as indicating that banded mongooses are the “only” animals that experience birth synchrony.

However, the truth is that the fact that banded mongooses’ birth synchrony is “remarkable” does not necessarily mean that “only banded mongooses experience … birth synchrony.”

So, while what this choice says could be true, the passage does not support this choice.

CORRECT ANSWER(E) The veil of ignorance results in mongoose parents’ not providing extra care to their own offspring.

Finding in the passage information on Harry Marshall and the “veil of ignorance,” we see that, in S3, the passage says the following:

‘Harry Marshall determined that … most of the expectant females give birth to their pups on the same night, creating what zoologists call a “veil of ignorance”’

The passage then goes on to say the following about the “veil of ignorance”:

“because all of the pups have almost identical looks, smells, and vocal frequencies, parents are unable to determine which pups belong to which parents and therefore cannot choose to provide them with extra care on that basis alone.”

We see that the passage conveys that the “veil of ignorance” causes the effect “parents are unable to determine which pups belong to which parents and therefore cannot choose to provide them with extra care.”

Since what this choice says, which is “the veil of ignorance results in,” means “the veil of ignorance causes,” this choice is supported by the passage.

Correct answer: E

topics.topicName: 3.25 Inference Trap 4: Opposite
topics.content:
3. Detail, Inference, Application, Assumption, Weaken and Strengthen

3.25 Inference Trap 4: Opposite

As we have seen in discussing other types of questions, Opposite trap choices say the opposite of what’s correct, and in Inference questions, Opposite choices say the opposite of what the passage supports.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

Opposite trap choices in Inference questions say the opposite of what the passage supports.

To see how an Opposite choice in an Inference question can work, let’s say that a passage says the following:

It was long thought that all animal brains had evolved to have the same chemical messengers—namely, serotonin, dopamine, and nitric oxide. However, discoveries in the late 1990s brought to light organisms called ctenophores whose brains do not use the same chemical messengers that other animal brains use but can handle some of the spatial and memory tasks that other animal brains can handle. This similarity between the abilities of the brains of ctenophores and those of other animals can be attributed to the fact that both types of animals evolved to handle the same environment.

An Inference question about the passage could be the following:

The author of the passage suggests that which of the following is true about animal brains?

(Opposite Choice) It is not possible for an animal brain to handle spatial or memory tasks without using the chemical messengers serotonin, dopamine, and nitric oxide.

(Correct Answer) The environment in which an animal evolves influences the development of abilities by that animal’s brain.

We can see that the Opposite choice says the opposite of what the passage supports. After all, the passage says that ctenophore’s brains “do not use the same chemical messengers (serotonin, dopamine, and nitric oxide) that other animal brains use but can handle some of the spatial and memory tasks that other animal brains can handle.” So, the passage supports the conclusion that it is possible, not impossible, for an animal’s brain to handle spatial and memory tasks without using those chemical messengers.

Notice also that the Opposite choice is incorrect only because it uses the negation word “not” in “not possible.” If the opposite choice did not include “not,” then it would say what the passage supports. So, we can see why an Opposite choice can be tricky. Just a word or two can make a choice that would be supported by the passage into a choice that says the opposite of what the passage says.

The correct answer, on the other hand, is supported by the passage. After all, in saying, “This similarity between the abilities of the brains of ctenophores and those of other animals can be attributed to the fact that both types of animals evolved to handle the same environment,” the author suggests that “The environment in which an animal evolves influences the development of abilities by that animal’s brain.”

To avoid choosing Opposite trap choices in Inference questions, we have to pay attention to the direction of what choices say and what the passage supports and determine whether they match.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

To avoid choosing Opposite trap choices in Inference questions, we have to pay attention to the direction of what choices say and what the passage supports and determine whether they match.

Let’s consider an example.

Example 20

S1: Whereas traditional vehicles burn fossil fuels in their engines, a process that generates carbon dioxide along with other greenhouse gases, which are harmful to the environment, electric vehicles (EVs) derive all of their power from electricity supplied by the electrical grid. S2: As a result, EVs emit neither carbon dioxide nor other greenhouses gases during their operation. S3: Therefore, environmentalists have become proponents of the use of EVs, but the question remains – are EVs actually better for the environment than traditional vehicles?

S4: The manufacture of a midsize traditional vehicle involves the generation of two to three tons of greenhouse gases—aluminum must be smelted, electronic chips must be produced, components must be installed, and the vehicle must be assembled. S5: Interestingly, the manufacture of a comparably-sized EV involves the generation of a greater quantity of greenhouse gases because, in addition to the EV needing to undergo all of the processes that are required for building traditional vehicles, all of the metals used in lithium-ion batteries of EVs must be mined and processed by means of heavy equipment powered by fossil fuel-burning engines. S6: Therefore, surprisingly, before the vehicles have been purchased by customers, the manufacture of an EV has resulted in the production of approximately 70 percent more greenhouse gas emissions than that of a traditional vehicle has resulted in.

S7: However, because, on average, generating the electricity to power an EV creates about 35 percent of the greenhouse gases that are produced in the making and combustion of the fuel used to power a traditional vehicle, with each mile driven, the greenhouse gas emission equation shifts further in favor of the EV. S8: In fact, once both vehicles have been driven for 20,000 miles, the total greenhouse gas emissions associated with each vehicle are about the same. S9: By the time the vehicles have been driven for 100,000 miles, the traditional vehicle is associated with about 80 percent more total greenhouse gas emissions than the EV, and at 200,000 miles, the total greenhouse gas emissions associated with the traditional vehicle reach about 80 tons whereas those associated with the EV reach only about 40 tons.

The passage suggests that, compared with those associated with a traditional vehicle, the total greenhouse gas emissions associated with an EV are generally

smaller in quantity once each type of vehicle has been driven for 20,000 miles

produced in greater quantities during the operation of the vehicles

greater in quantity before each type of vehicle has been driven for 20,000 miles

100 percent greater in quantity once each type of vehicle has been driven for 200,000 miles

produced in smaller quantities during the manufacture of two types of vehicles

Example 20 - Question 1

easy

S1: Whereas traditional vehicles burn fossil fuels in their engines, a process that generates carbon dioxide along with other greenhouse gases, which are harmful to the environment, electric vehicles (EVs) derive all of their power from electricity supplied by the electrical grid. S2: As a result, EVs emit neither carbon dioxide nor other greenhouses gases during their operation. S3: Therefore, environmentalists have become proponents of the use of EVs, but the question remains – are EVs actually better for the environment than traditional vehicles?

S4: The manufacture of a midsize traditional vehicle involves the generation of two to three tons of greenhouse gases—aluminum must be smelted, electronic chips must be produced, components must be installed, and the vehicle must be assembled. S5: Interestingly, the manufacture of a comparably-sized EV involves the generation of a greater quantity of greenhouse gases because, in addition to the EV needing to undergo all of the processes that are required for building traditional vehicles, all of the metals used in lithium-ion batteries of EVs must be mined and processed by means of heavy equipment powered by fossil fuel-burning engines. S6: Therefore, surprisingly, before the vehicles have been purchased by customers, the manufacture of an EV has resulted in the production of approximately 70 percent more greenhouse gas emissions than that of a traditional vehicle has resulted in.

S7: However, because, on average, generating the electricity to power an EV creates about 35 percent of the greenhouse gases that are produced in the making and combustion of the fuel used to power a traditional vehicle, with each mile driven, the greenhouse gas emission equation shifts further in favor of the EV. S8: In fact, once both vehicles have been driven for 20,000 miles, the total greenhouse gas emissions associated with each vehicle are about the same. S9: By the time the vehicles have been driven for 100,000 miles, the traditional vehicle is associated with about 80 percent more total greenhouse gas emissions than the EV, and at 200,000 miles, the total greenhouse gas emissions associated with the traditional vehicle reach about 80 tons whereas those associated with the EV reach only about 40 tons.

QUESTION
Showing:
Question

The passage suggests that, compared with those associated with a traditional vehicle, the total greenhouse gas emissions associated with an EV are generally

smaller in quantity once each type of vehicle has been driven for 20,000 miles

produced in greater quantities during the operation of the vehicles

greater in quantity before each type of vehicle has been driven for 20,000 miles

100 percent greater in quantity once each type of vehicle has been driven for 200,000 miles

produced in smaller quantities during the manufacture of two types of vehicles
Previous Confirm Finish
Show solution Hide solution
PRESENTED BY :
Scott Woodbury-Stewart Founder and Expert GMAT Instructor Scott Woodbury-Stewart Founder and Expert GMAT Instructor

Text Solution:

This question is focused on a comparison of the total greenhouse gas emissions associated with a traditional vehicle with those associated with an EV. Since the entire 2nd paragraph and 3rd paragraph of the passage discuss the greenhouse gas emissions associated with the two types of vehicles, we’ll have to use keywords from each choice to find the information we need for determining whether that choice is correct.

Then, since the passage says so many things about the quantity of greenhouse gases associated with each type of vehicle, we’ll have to be careful to make sure that a we select a choice that matches what the passage supports and don’t make the mistake of choosing one that says the opposite of what the passage says.

(A) smaller in quantity once each type of vehicle has been driven for 20,000 miles

Scanning the passage for “20,000 miles,” we see that S8 says, “In fact, once both vehicles have been driven for 20,000 miles, the total greenhouse gas emissions associated with each vehicle are about the same.”

So, this choice does not match what the passage says, since this choice says that, once each type of vehicle has been driven for 20,000 miles, the greenhouse gases associated with the EV are “smaller in quantity,” whereas the passage says that, at the 20,000 miles point, the greenhouse gas emissions associated with the vehicles are “about the same.”

(B) produced in greater quantities during the operation of the vehicles

Trap: Opposite

Scanning the passage for “operation of the vehicles,” we don’t see the wording “operation of the vehicles” anywhere, but we do see in S7 “with each mile driven.” Since, when a vehicle is “driven,” it is operated, we can compare this choice with S7 to see whether this choice is correct.

We see that S7 implies that the quantity of greenhouse gases produced during the operation of an EV is smaller, not greater, than the quantity of greenhouse gases produced during the operation of a traditional vehicle.

So, this choice says the opposite of what the passage implies.

CORRECT ANSWER(C) greater in quantity before each type of vehicle has been driven for 20,000 miles

Scanning the passage for “20,000 miles,” we see that S8 says, “In fact, once both vehicles have been driven for 20,000 miles, the total greenhouse gas emissions associated with each vehicle are about the same.”

At the same time, to answer this question, we need information on the greenhouse gas emissions associated with each vehicle “before each type of vehicle has been driven for 20,000 miles.”

Looking at the sentences above S8, we see that in S6 says that the manufacture of an EV results in the production of “more greenhouse gas emissions than that of a traditional vehicle has resulted in.”

Then S7 says that, “with each mile driven, the greenhouse gas emission equation shifts further in favor of the EV.”

Thus, we can see that, according to the passage, the EV starts off associated with more greenhouse gas emissions than the traditional vehicle, but the driving of the EV is associated with the production of fewer greenhouse gas emissions than that of the traditional vehicle, with the result that, after being driven for 20,000 miles, the two vehicles are associated with about the same greenhouse gas emissions.

So, we can infer from the passage what this choice says, that “before each type of vehicle has been driven for 20,000 miles,” the greenhouse gas emissions associated with the EV are “greater in total.”

(D) 100 percent greater in quantity once each type of vehicle has been driven for 200,000 miles

Trap: Opposite

Scanning the passage for 200,000 miles, we see that S9 says, “at 200,000 miles, the total greenhouse gas emissions associated with the traditional vehicle reach about 80 tons whereas those associated with the EV reach only about 40 tons.”

We see that the 80 tons of greenhouse gas emissions the passage says are associated with the traditional vehicle are 100 percent more the 40 tons associated with the EV.

So, in saying that the greenhouse gas emissions associated with an EV are generally 100 percent greater once each type of vehicle has been driven for 200,000 miles, this choice says the opposite of what the passage supports.

(E) produced in smaller quantities during the manufacture of two types of vehicles

Trap: Opposite

Scanning the area of the passage where the manufacture of the vehicles is discussed, which is the 2nd paragraph, we see that S6 says, “the manufacture of an EV has resulted in the production of approximately 70 percent more greenhouse gas emissions than that of a traditional vehicle has resulted in.”

Thus, the passage says that the manufacture of an EV results in the production of more greenhouse gases, not “smaller quantities,” than the manufacture of a traditional vehicle results in.

So, this choice says the opposite of what the passage says.

Correct answer: C
Frequently Asked Questions

Let’s now discuss Half-Right trap choices in Inference questions.

topics.topicName: 3.26 Inference Trap 5: Half-Right
topics.content:
3. Detail, Inference, Application, Assumption, Weaken and Strengthen

3.26 Inference Trap 5: Half-Right

We’ve seen Half-Right choices in a number of types of questions, and Half-Right choices in Inference questions follow a pattern similar to that of Half-Right choices in other questions: part of the choice matches what’s supported by the passage, and part of the choice is not supported by what the passage says.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

Half-Right choices in Inference questions are choices such that part of the choice is supported by the passage, and part of the choice is not.

By now, we’ve seen enough Half-Right choices to know how they work and to know that the key to avoiding choosing a Half-Right choice is to read every choice in its entirety and determine whether all of the choice matches the passage.

So, let’s go straight to developing skill in handling Half-Right choices in Inference questions by considering an example.

Example 21

S1: Master farmers and ethical growers, Native Americans indigenous to what is now the United States and Canada demonstrated not only unwavering appreciation of and respect for the plants that they used for sustenance and profit but also an array of sophisticated agricultural techniques that are still widely studied and used in farming today.

S2: Embracing the concept of perennial cultivation, Native Americans ensured that plants were utilized without being killed. S3: For example, they regularly harvested wood and bark from many species of tree, all while taking care to ensure that in doing so, they kept trees alive; from each tree, they took an amount of wood and bark such that the tree would continue to thrive. S4: The trees from which these resources were taken were referred to as “begged from trees” by the natives because they believed that they came to beg for a piece of the tree.

S5: Also used by these indigenous peoples was a technique called intercropping, in which, by planting multiple crops together, they forged a synergy such that characteristics of each plant improved the growth and health of all plants intercropped, all while reducing farming-associated land damage. S6: For example, it was common for the Iroquois to synergistically plant corn, beans, and squash together using a technique known as the “Three Sisters.” S7: The corn provided tall stalks for the beans to climb, the beans not only provided nitrogen, fertilizing the soil, but also stabilized the corn, preventing it from being damaged during heavy winds, and the broad leaves of the squash plants provided ground shade, which both reduced water loss from the soil and prevented weed growth.

S8: Creek Indians, who settled in what is present-day New York, utilized diluted human urine, which contains a wide assortment of minerals essential to plant-growth, including nitrogen and phosphorus, to fertilize their crops. S9: Such a resourceful practice resulted in reduced need for human-generated waste dumps, which in addition to being unsightly and odorous, can damage soil. S10: This practice also allowed crops to grow larger and hardier than they would have without nitrogenous fertilization.

The passage suggests which of the following about Native Americans’ attitude towards plants?

Native Americans valued plants in order to set a good example for future farmers.

The respect demonstrated by Native Americans extended beyond plants to other aspects of nature.

Native Americans were sufficiently knowledgeable about plants to harvest portions of a plant without making the survival of that plant impossible.

The Iroquois planted corn, beans, and squash together to demonstrate their appreciation and respect for those plants.

Native Americans were more successful in agriculture than most other people of their time because Native Americans embraced perennial cultivation.

Example 21 - Question 1

easy

S1: Master farmers and ethical growers, Native Americans indigenous to what is now the United States and Canada demonstrated not only unwavering appreciation of and respect for the plants that they used for sustenance and profit but also an array of sophisticated agricultural techniques that are still widely studied and used in farming today.

S2: Embracing the concept of perennial cultivation, Native Americans ensured that plants were utilized without being killed. S3: For example, they regularly harvested wood and bark from many species of tree, all while taking care to ensure that in doing so, they kept trees alive; from each tree, they took an amount of wood and bark such that the tree would continue to thrive. S4: The trees from which these resources were taken were referred to as “begged from trees” by the natives because they believed that they came to beg for a piece of the tree.

S5: Also used by these indigenous peoples was a technique called intercropping, in which, by planting multiple crops together, they forged a synergy such that characteristics of each plant improved the growth and health of all plants intercropped, all while reducing farming-associated land damage. S6: For example, it was common for the Iroquois to synergistically plant corn, beans, and squash together using a technique known as the “Three Sisters.” S7: The corn provided tall stalks for the beans to climb, the beans not only provided nitrogen, fertilizing the soil, but also stabilized the corn, preventing it from being damaged during heavy winds, and the broad leaves of the squash plants provided ground shade, which both reduced water loss from the soil and prevented weed growth.

S8: Creek Indians, who settled in what is present-day New York, utilized diluted human urine, which contains a wide assortment of minerals essential to plant-growth, including nitrogen and phosphorus, to fertilize their crops. S9: Such a resourceful practice resulted in reduced need for human-generated waste dumps, which in addition to being unsightly and odorous, can damage soil. S10: This practice also allowed crops to grow larger and hardier than they would have without nitrogenous fertilization.

QUESTION
Showing:
Question

The passage suggests which of the following about Native Americans’ attitude towards plants?

Native Americans valued plants in order to set a good example for future farmers.

The respect demonstrated by Native Americans extended beyond plants to other aspects of nature.

Native Americans were sufficiently knowledgeable about plants to harvest portions of a plant without making the survival of that plant impossible.

The Iroquois planted corn, beans, and squash together to demonstrate their appreciation and respect for those plants.

Native Americans were more successful in agriculture than most other people of their time because Native Americans embraced perennial cultivation.
Previous Confirm Finish
Show solution Hide solution
PRESENTED BY :
Scott Woodbury-Stewart Founder and Expert GMAT Instructor Scott Woodbury-Stewart Founder and Expert GMAT Instructor

Text Solution:

The focus of this question is “Native Americans’ attitude towards plants.” So, to correctly answer this question, we have to find information on that topic.

At the same time, Native Americans’ attitude towards plants is discussed in both the 1st paragraph and the 2nd paragraph of the passage, and plants are mentioned throughout the passage. So, there isn’t really a small portion of the passage where the information we need is certain to lie. Therefore, we may have to use the focuses of or keywords in answer choices as clues indicating where in the passage to look for information.

(A) Native Americans valued plants in order to set a good example for future farmers.

Trap: Half-Right

This choice starts off correctly, because the passage does support “Native Americans valued plants.”

However, this choice goes wrong partway through, because the passage says nothing to indicate that Native Americans valued plants for the purpose of setting an example.

This choice is a good example of why we have to read choices in their entirety.

(B) The respect demonstrated by Native Americans extended beyond plants to other aspects of nature.

Trap: Speculation

What this choice says seems quite possible. After all, if Native Americans “demonstrated … unwavering appreciation of and respect for … plants,” then it seems possible, or even likely, that they demonstrated respect for other aspects of nature.

However, what’s possible and what’s supported by the passage are two different things, and this choice is not an inference supported by the passage. After all, the passage says nothing that clearly indicates anything about Native Americans’ attitudes toward aspects of nature other than plants.

CORRECT ANSWER(C) Native Americans were sufficiently knowledgeable about plants to harvest portions of a plant without making the survival of that plant impossible.

This choice follows directly from the first two sentences of the 2nd paragraph. After all, if “Native Americans ensured that plants were utilized without being killed,” and “from each tree, they took an amount of wood and bark such that the tree would continue to thrive,” it follows that “Native Americans’ were sufficiently knowledgeable about plants to harvest portions of a plant without making the survival of that plant impossible.”

(D) The Iroquois planted corn, beans, and squash together to demonstrate their appreciation and respect for those plants.

Trap: Half-Right

To find information related to this choice, we can look for the keywords “planted multiple crops together.” We find this phrase in the 3rd paragraph.

Scanning the 3rd paragraph, we see that this choice starts off correctly, because “Native Americans planted multiple crops together” is supported by “used by these indigenous peoples was a technique … by planting multiple crops together, they forged a synergy.”

However, this choice goes wrong partway through, since the passage never says that Native Americans’ purpose in planting multiple crops together was “to demonstrate their appreciate and respect for those plants.”

This choice is a good example of why we have to read choices in their entirety.

(E) Native Americans were more successful in agriculture than most other people of their time because Native Americans embraced perennial cultivation.

Trap: Half-Right

To find information related to this choice, we can look for the keywords “perennial cultivation.” We find this phrase in the 2nd paragraph.

Scanning the 2nd paragraph, we can see that the second part of this choice is correct, because S2 says that Native Americans “embraced the concept of perennial cultivation.”

However, the beginning of this choice is not supported by the passage since the passage provides no information that clearly indicates that “Native Americans were more successful in agriculture than most other people of their time.”

Correct answer: C
