topics.topicName: 3.27 Inference Trap 6: Nearby
topics.content:
3. Detail, Inference, Application, Assumption, Weaken and Strengthen

3.27 Inference Trap 6: Nearby

In Inference questions, Nearby trap choices are incorrect choices that are based on language located near the information in the passage that supports the correct answer.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

Nearby trap choices in Inference questions are incorrect choices that are based on language located near the information in the passage that supports the correct answer.

To see how a Nearby trap choice in an Inference question can work, let’s say that a passage says the following:

The Industrial Revolution has gone through a number of stages, and it is clear that, over the long term, the Industrial Revolution has produced great benefits. However, during the early decades of the Industrial Revolution, for many people, any gains in well-being attributable to rising wages were more than offset by reductions in overall quality of life.

An Inference question about the passage could be the following:

It can be inferred from the passage that which of the following was true of many people during the early decades of the Industrial Revolution?

(Nearby Trap Choice) They benefited greatly from the Industrial Revolution.

(Correct Answer) Their lives were not as good as they were before the Industrial Revolution began.

We can see why the Nearby trap choice would be tempting. Once we locate the focus of the question, “many people during the early decades of the Industrial Revolution,” in the passage, we see close to it “the Industrial Revolution has produced great benefits.” That language looks a lot like the Nearby choice “They benefited greatly from the Industrial Revolution.” So, seeing that similarity, we could perceive the Nearby choice to be correct.

However, as we know, RC success does not come from word matching. It comes from understanding what we read, and by reading carefully, we see that the point expressed by the passage is the following: The Industrial Revolution has produced great benefits. HOWEVER, during the early decades of the Industrial Revolution, many people experienced reductions in overall quality of life.

Thus, the Nearby trap choice is incorrect, because the passage does not indicate that, during the early decades of the Industrial Revolution, many people “benefited greatly.” Rather it indicates that many people’s lives got worse.

On the other hand, the correct answer follows from what the passage says. After all, if the passage indicates that many people’s lives got worse during the early decades of the Industrial Revolution, then we can infer what the correct answer says, “Their lives were not as good as they were before the Industrial Revolution began.”

So, what’s the takeaway?

The takeaway is that, to avoid choosing Nearby trap choices in Inference questions, we have to be careful not to jump into choosing a choice that merely looks like what we see in the passage near the keywords from the question stem and instead read to understand and, thus, find a choice that truly answers the question asked.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

To avoid choosing a Nearby trap choice in an Inference question, we have to be careful not to jump into choosing a choice that merely looks like what we see in the passage near the keywords from the question stem and instead read to understand and, thus, find a choice that truly answers the question asked.

To develop skill in handling Nearby trap choices in Inference questions, let’s consider an example.

Example 22

S1: Daylight Savings Time (DST), defined as the practice of advancing clocks by one hour in spring, and back one hour in autumn, was introduced in the United States in the spring of 1918 as a perfectly logical wartime measure to save an hour’s worth of fuel each day by reducing the use of artificial light. S2: However, the downsides to this policy currently outweigh the benefits, and therefore DST should be abolished in the United States. S3: Recent research has found that disturbing people’s regular sleep patterns, even by just one hour, can have a negative impact on people’s natural circadian rhythms and health. S4: Notably, one study found that an individual’s risk of experiencing a heart attack increases by 10 percent during the two days following the spring time change. S5: Furthermore, experts on the body’s relationship with light and dark, such as chronobiologist Till Roenneberg, note that the drawbacks of DST include a substantial decrease in employee productivity. S6: While supporters of DST assume that people can quickly adjust, Roenneberg notes that the body clock does not adjust to DST social clock time even over months. S7: Another often overlooked factor is the opportunity cost of the time spent moving hundreds of millions of clocks forwards and backwards each year; one 2008 economic analysis puts this cost at $1.7 billion annually. S8: Naturally, with the numerous problems caused by DST, there is public support for eliminating the time change; a 2019 AP-NORC poll found that only 28 percent of U.S. adults want to continue changing the clocks twice each year.

The information in the passage suggests that Roenneberg believes that which of the following would occur if DST were abolished?

The percentage of people who experience a heart attack in the spring would decrease.

People would never experience problems with their body’s relationship between light and dark.

The opportunity cost of the time spent moving clocks forwards and backwards would be eliminated.

People’s body clocks would more often match the social clock time.

Supporters of DST would no longer assume that people can quickly adjust to time changes.

Example 22 - Question 1

easy

S1: Daylight Savings Time (DST), defined as the practice of advancing clocks by one hour in spring, and back one hour in autumn, was introduced in the United States in the spring of 1918 as a perfectly logical wartime measure to save an hour’s worth of fuel each day by reducing the use of artificial light. S2: However, the downsides to this policy currently outweigh the benefits, and therefore DST should be abolished in the United States. S3: Recent research has found that disturbing people’s regular sleep patterns, even by just one hour, can have a negative impact on people’s natural circadian rhythms and health. S4: Notably, one study found that an individual’s risk of experiencing a heart attack increases by 10 percent during the two days following the spring time change. S5: Furthermore, experts on the body’s relationship with light and dark, such as chronobiologist Till Roenneberg, note that the drawbacks of DST include a substantial decrease in employee productivity. S6: While supporters of DST assume that people can quickly adjust, Roenneberg notes that the body clock does not adjust to DST social clock time even over months. S7: Another often overlooked factor is the opportunity cost of the time spent moving hundreds of millions of clocks forwards and backwards each year; one 2008 economic analysis puts this cost at $1.7 billion annually. S8: Naturally, with the numerous problems caused by DST, there is public support for eliminating the time change; a 2019 AP-NORC poll found that only 28 percent of U.S. adults want to continue changing the clocks twice each year.

QUESTION
Showing:
Question

The information in the passage suggests that Roenneberg believes that which of the following would occur if DST were abolished?

The percentage of people who experience a heart attack in the spring would decrease.

People would never experience problems with their body’s relationship between light and dark.

The opportunity cost of the time spent moving clocks forwards and backwards would be eliminated.

People’s body clocks would more often match the social clock time.

Supporters of DST would no longer assume that people can quickly adjust to time changes.
Previous Confirm Finish
Show solution Hide solution
PRESENTED BY :
Scott Woodbury-Stewart Founder and Expert GMAT Instructor Scott Woodbury-Stewart Founder and Expert GMAT Instructor

Text Solution:

The focus of this Inference question is on Roenneberg and what he believes would occur if DST were abolished. So, to find the information we need for answering the question, we can look in the area of the passage that mentions Roenneberg, which is relatively easy to find, since Roenneberg is capitalized.

At the same time, to arrive at the correct answer, we have to be sure to find the right information. In other words, we have to be careful not to choose a choice just because it’s supported by information located around where “Roenneberg” appears in the passage. The choice has to truly answer the question asked by stating what can be inferred about what Roenneberg believes would occur if DST were abolished.

Everything having to do with Roenneberg is stated in parts of S5 and S6. So, our choice has to be supported by those parts of S5 and S6.

(A) The percentage of people who experience a heart attack in the spring would decrease.

Trap: Nearby

This choice is supported by S4, which describes what “one study found” about “an individual’s risk of experiencing a heart attack.”

Notice that no information that supports this choice located in S5 or S6, where the information about Roenneberg is located. Rather, the information that supports this choice is located above the right information for answering the question.

So, while this choice is related to what Roenneberg is concerned with, this choice is incorrect because what “one study found” about “an individual’s risk of experiencing a heart attack” is not something that “Roenneberg believes.”

(B) People would never experience problems with their body’s relationship between light and dark.

Trap: Stretch

The extreme marker “never” in this choice is a yellow flag signaling that we should check carefully to see whether the passage says something as extreme as what this choice says.

We see that S5 says that Roenneberg and other “experts on the body’s relationship with light and dark” “note that the drawbacks of DST include a substantial decrease in employee productivity.”

Then S6 says that “Roenneberg notes that the body clock does not adjust to DST social clock time even over months.”

Notice that those sentences indicate only that Roenneberg believes DST is one thing that causes people to experience problems with their body’s relationship between light and dark. They don’t say that Roenneberg believes DST is the only thing that causes such problems or that people would never experience such problems if DST were abolished.

So, this choice goes beyond what the passage supports.

(C) The opportunity cost of the time spent moving clocks forwards and backwards would be eliminated.

Trap: Nearby

Notice that the passage discusses “moving clocks forwards and backward” in S7, which is below the sentences about what Roenneberg believes. In other words, the passage mentions Roenneberg’s views and then moves on to “Another often overlooked factor … moving … clocks forwards and backwards,” which is separate from Roenneberg’s views.

So, the passage does not indicate that Roenneberg believes anything about moving clocks forwards and backwards.

To avoid choosing a Nearby trap like this one, we have to be careful to not to choose a choice based on information that is located close to but is not part of the right information for answering the question.

CORRECT ANSWER(D) People’s body clocks would more often match the social clock time.

S6 says, “Roenneberg notes that the body clock does not adjust to DST social clock time even over months.”

If “the body clock does not adjust to DST social clock time even over months,” then moving clocks for DST causes people’s body clocks not to match “social clock time” for months while people’s body clocks adjust.

Of course, if DST causes people’s body clocks not to match “social clock time,” then what follows logically is that, if DST were abolished, people’s body clocks would more often match social clock time.

So, if “Roenneberg notes that the body clock does not adjust to DST social clock time even over months,” then it follows that Roenneberg believes that, if DST were abolished, “People’s body clocks would more often match the social clock time.”

So, this choice is supported by the passage.

(E) Supporters of DST would no longer assume that people can quickly adjust to time changes.

Trap: Nearby

The passage says, “While supporters of DST assume that people can quickly adjust,” in S6, which is one of the sentences that mentions Roenneberg’s views.

However, the passage does not say that Roenneberg believes anything about what supporters of DST “assume.” Rather, it mentions what supporters of DST “assume” simply as a viewpoint in contrast to what Roenneberg “notes.” In other words, the passage says, “While supporters of DST assume X, Roenneberg notes Y.”

So, this choice is based on some information located close to the right information for answering the question but does not answer the question, which is specifically about what Roenneberg believes.

To avoid choosing a Nearby trap like this one, we have to be careful to not to choose a choice based on information that is located close to but is not part of the right information for answering the question.

Correct answer: D

topics.topicName: 3.28 Inference Trap 7: Matches but Incorrect
topics.content:
3. Detail, Inference, Application, Assumption, Weaken and Strengthen

3.28 Inference Trap 7: Matches but Incorrect

As we know, the correct answer to an Inference RC question has two characteristics: it is supported by the passage, and it answers the question asked by the stem.

On the other hand, a Matches but Incorrect trap choice in an Inference question has only one of those characteristics: it is supported by the passage, but it does not answer the question asked.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

A Matches but Incorrect trap choice in an Inference question is supported by the passage, but it does not answer the question asked by the stem.

To see how a Matches but Incorrect choice in an Inference question can work, let’s say that a passage says the following:

During the early decades of the Industrial Revolution, most factories were powered by flowing water, and therefore, manufacturers were constrained to locating factories where they could access sources of water power. However, after James Watt improved the design of the steam engine, it became possible for factories using this alternative source of power to be clustered in industrial cities. The improved steam engine was also used to power means of transportation, such as the steam locomotive, with the result that the speed and ease with which goods could be transported increased significantly. Therefore, the geographic range over which manufacturers could profitably transport goods became greatly expanded.

An Inference question about the passage could be the following:

The author suggests that it was not possible for factories to be clustered in industrial cities before James Watt improved the steam engine because, at that time

(Matches but Incorrect Choice) the geographic range over which goods could be profitably transported was smaller than it was after the improved steam engine came into use.

(Correct Answer) the power source used by most factories would not have been accessible to factories clustered in that way.

We can see why the Matches but Incorrect choice could be tempting. In looking for what “the author suggests” we could see that the passage does suggest that, before James Watt improved the steam engine, “the geographic range over which goods could be profitably transported was smaller than it was after the improved steam engine came into use.” After all, if, as a result of the use of the steam engine in the transportation of goods, “the geographic range over which manufacturers could profitably transport goods became greatly expanded,” then before the use of the steam engine, the geographic range was smaller.

The issue is that the Matches but Incorrect choice is incorrect because it doesn’t answer the question. After all, the question is “it was not possible for factories to be clustered in industrial cities … because,” and the passage does not say that it became possible for factories to be clustered in industrial cities because of anything having to do with the geographic range over which goods could be transported.

The correct answer, on the other hand, does answer the question, because the passage suggests that it was possible for factories to be clustered in industrial cities only because they could use “this alternative source of power,” the steam engine, and therefore did not have to be located where they could access sources of water power.

So, what’s the takeaway?

The takeaway is that, to avoid choosing a Matches but Incorrect choice when answering an Inference question, we have to confirm that the choice we choose not only is supported by what the passage says but also answers the question asked by the stem.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

To avoid choosing a Matches but Incorrect choice in an Inference question, we have to confirm that the choice we choose not only is supported by what the passage says but also answers the question asked by the stem.

Consider the following example.

Example 23

S1: GDP – calculated as the total market value of all final goods and services produced during a specific time period – has long been used as an indicator of national development and progress. S2: However, critics of this use of GDP contend that GDP is an overly simple measure that neither effectively captures key aspects of human progress nor takes into account negative effects of economic development. S3: Accordingly, these critics have proposed the adoption of alternative measures, two of which are Gross National Happiness (GNH) and Genuine Progress Indicator (GPI).

S4: GNH, developed in Bhutan, is calculated by means of a questionnaire presented to a random sample composed of 8,000 of Bhutan’s citizens. S5: The process involved in calculating GNH is remarkably thorough, with each citizen answering 148 questions on a variety of quality of life-related topics. S6: However, no country other than Bhutan has adopted GNH, in part because of the time and expense required for interviewing a number of citizens sufficient for generating the data required for accurately calculating GNH. S7: A country’s GPI, on the other hand, can be calculated via the use of data that is already widely available. S8: In fact, GPI is in part based on information similar to that used in calculating GDP and differs from GDP mainly in that it is based on not only information on aggregate production but also information on negatives associated with economic growth, such as loss of leisure time and the cost of deterioration of nature and natural resources.

The passage implies that which of the following is a reason why some people are critical of the use of GDP?

GDP provides a picture that includes no downsides of economic development.

GDP is calculated via the use of information on aggregate production.

GDP has been used to measure national development for a long period of time.

GDP takes into account positive effects of economic development.

GDP is relatively simple to calculate via the use of data that is widely available.

Example 23 - Question 1

easy

S1: GDP – calculated as the total market value of all final goods and services produced during a specific time period – has long been used as an indicator of national development and progress. S2: However, critics of this use of GDP contend that GDP is an overly simple measure that neither effectively captures key aspects of human progress nor takes into account negative effects of economic development. S3: Accordingly, these critics have proposed the adoption of alternative measures, two of which are Gross National Happiness (GNH) and Genuine Progress Indicator (GPI).

S4: GNH, developed in Bhutan, is calculated by means of a questionnaire presented to a random sample composed of 8,000 of Bhutan’s citizens. S5: The process involved in calculating GNH is remarkably thorough, with each citizen answering 148 questions on a variety of quality of life-related topics. S6: However, no country other than Bhutan has adopted GNH, in part because of the time and expense required for interviewing a number of citizens sufficient for generating the data required for accurately calculating GNH. S7: A country’s GPI, on the other hand, can be calculated via the use of data that is already widely available. S8: In fact, GPI is in part based on information similar to that used in calculating GDP and differs from GDP mainly in that it is based on not only information on aggregate production but also information on negatives associated with economic growth, such as loss of leisure time and the cost of deterioration of nature and natural resources.

QUESTION
Showing:
Question

The passage implies that which of the following is a reason why some people are critical of the use of GDP?

GDP provides a picture that includes no downsides of economic development.

GDP is calculated via the use of information on aggregate production.

GDP has been used to measure national development for a long period of time.

GDP takes into account positive effects of economic development.

GDP is relatively simple to calculate via the use of data that is widely available.
Previous Confirm Finish
Show solution Hide solution
PRESENTED BY :
Scott Woodbury-Stewart Founder and Expert GMAT Instructor Scott Woodbury-Stewart Founder and Expert GMAT Instructor

Text Solution:

The correct answer to this inference question must state “a reason why some people are critical of the use of GDP.” So, we have to be careful to choose a choice that states such a reason. Any choice that is supported by the passage but is not “a reason why some people are critical of the use of GDP” will not be correct.

CORRECT ANSWER(A) GDP provides a picture that includes no downsides of economic development.

Homing in on the part of the passage that discusses “critics” and “economic development,” we see that S2 says that “critics of this use of GDP contend that GDP is an overly simple measure” that does not take into account “negative effects of economic development.”

While the passage does not directly state that the reason why these people are critical of the use of GDP is that it “provides a picture that includes no downsides,” what S2 says implies that people criticize GDP because it does not take into account “negative effects,” which are “downsides.”

(B) GDP is calculated via the use of information on aggregate production.

Trap: Matches but Incorrect

This choice is supported by the passage since S8 implies that GDP is “based on … information on aggregate production.”

However, this choice is not correct, because the fact that GDP is based on information on aggregate production is not a “reason why some people are critical of the use of GDP.” The passage implies that critics have issue with the fact that GDP is “overly simplistic” and does not capture key aspects of human progress, not with the fact that GDP is calculated via the use of information on aggregate production.

We can confirm that this choice is incorrect by noticing that S8 says that one of the measures the critics prefer, GPI, is also “based on … information on aggregate production.” So, the fact that a measure is “based on … information on aggregate production” is not something the critics have an issue with.

To avoid choosing a choice like this one, we have to confirm that a choice we are considering not only is supported by the passage but also answers the question asked by the stem.

(C) GDP has been used to measure national development for a long period of time.

Trap: Matches but Incorrect

This choice matches something the passage says, “GDP … has long been used as an indicator of national development and progress.”

However, this choice is not correct, because the fact that “GDP has been used to measure national development for a long period of time” is not a “reason why some people are critical of the use of GDP.”

The critics have issue with the fact that GDP is “overly simplistic” and does not capture key aspects of human progress, not with the fact that GDP has been used for a long period of time.

To avoid choosing a choice like this one, we have to confirm that a choice we are considering not only is supported by the passage but also answers the question asked by the stem.

(D) GDP takes into account positive effects of economic development.

Homing in on the part of the passage that discusses “critics of this use of GDP” and “effects of economic development,” we see that the passage says that these critics “contend that GDP is an overly simple measure” that does not take into account “negative effects of economic development.”

We can see that the passage does not indicate that the critics have any issue with the fact that “GDP takes into account positive effects of economic development.”

So, this choice is not supported.

(E) GDP is relatively simple to calculate via the use of data that is widely available.

Trap: Matches but Incorrect

This choice is tempting because it is supported by the passage. After all, S7 and S8 say the following:

“GPI … can be calculated via the use of data that is already widely available. In fact, GPI is in part based on information similar to that used in calculating GDP”

We can see that, if GPI can be calculated via the use of widely available data, and if GPI is in part based on information similar to that used in calculating GDP, then it follows that “GDP is relatively simple to calculate via the use of data that is widely available.”

However, even though this choice is supported by the passage, it is incorrect because it does not answer the question asked by the stem since it does not state “a reason why some people are critical of the use of GDP.” After all, the passage does not imply that “critics of this use of GDP” have issue with the fact that GDP is “relatively simple to calculate.

To avoid choosing a choice like this one, we have to confirm that a choice we are considering not only is supported by the passage but also answers the question asked by the stem.

Correct answer: A
Frequently Asked Questions

topics.topicName: 3.29 Inference Trap 8: Wrong Comparison
topics.content:
3. Detail, Inference, Application, Assumption, Weaken and Strengthen

3.29 Inference Trap 8: Wrong Comparison

We’ve seen Wrong Comparison choices in Detail questions already, and Wrong Comparison choices in Inference questions work similarly to those. A Wrong Comparison choice in an Inference question expresses a comparison not supported by the passage.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

A Wrong Comparison choice in an Inference question expresses a comparison not supported by the passage.

To see how a Wrong Comparison choice can work in an Inference question, let’s say that a passage says the following:

It was long thought that all animal brains had evolved to have the same chemical messengers—namely, serotonin, dopamine, and nitric oxide. However, discoveries in the late 1990s brought to light organisms called ctenophores whose brains do not use the same chemical messengers that other animal brains use but can handle some of the spatial and memory tasks that other animal brains can handle. This similarity between the abilities of the brains of ctenophores and those of other animals can be attributed to the fact that both types of animals evolved to handle the same environment.

An Inference question about the passage could be the following:

The author of the passage suggests that which of the following is true about animal brains?

(Wrong Comparison Choice) The brains of ctenophores use fewer chemical messengers than other animal brains use.

(Correct Answer) The environment in which an animal evolves influences the development of abilities by that animal’s brain.

Notice that, even though the Wrong Comparison choice may “feel” as if it’s something the passage says, it’s not really supported by the passage. After all, the fact that ctenophore brains “do not use the same chemical messengers that other animal brains use” does not mean that “The brains of ctenophores use fewer chemical messengers than other animal brains use.” So, the passage does not provide a solid basis for the comparison expressed by the Wrong Comparison choice.

On the other hand, as we discussed previously, the correct answer is supported by the passage.

The strategy for avoiding choosing Wrong Comparison choices in Inference questions is straightforward: if we see that a choice expresses a comparison, we consider the comparison a yellow flag indicating that we may be dealing with a Wrong Comparison choice and check to see whether the comparison is supported by the passage. For the choice to be supported, the passage has to provide a basis for comparing the things compared, and the passage has to support the comparison expressed in the choice, not a different comparison.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

To avoiding choosing a Wrong Comparison choice in an Inference question, if we see that a choice expresses a comparison, we consider the comparison a yellow flag indicating that we may be dealing with a Wrong Comparison choice and check to see whether the comparison is supported by the passage.

Consider the following example.

Example 24

S1: Absolutism, which was particularly widespread during the 17th and 18th centuries in Europe, is a governmental system involving unlimited authority vested in a monarch or dictator. S2: King Louis XIV (1643-1715) of France captured the essence of absolutism when he said, “I am the state.” S3: Many absolutist monarchs sought to provide justification for their absolute power by using the doctrine of the “divine right of kings” and broadened their power by becoming heads of church as well as state. S4: Additionally, influential political and philosophical theorists, including Thomas Hobbes, have argued that unquestioned obedience to a single will is necessary to maintain order and security.

S5: Absolutism stands in stark contrast to constitutionalism, in which a written constitution defines legal limitations on government, a measure that serves to reduce the risk of rulers’ pursuing their own interests at the expense of those of the ruled. S6: Whereas absolutism allows the monarch to make arbitrary judgments in any situation, under constitutionalism, no one is above the rule of law: judges make decisions based on prewritten laws as well as the precedent of earlier judgments. S7: John Locke, an influential political theorist who supported this foundational principle of constitutionalism, argued that “wherever law ends, tyranny begins.” S8: Additionally, unlike absolutism, constitutionalism limits the dominance of a state’s leader by requiring a balance of powers; although abuses of power can still sometimes occur, no one is legally permitted to rule without the agreement of at least one other individual or body, such as the legislative or judiciary branch of government.

It can be inferred from the passage that a government following the principles of constitutionalism would be less likely to experience abuse of power by a leader than an absolutist government would because constitutionalism is

more likely to receive support from influential political theorists

less likely to put emphasis on order and security

less likely to permit rule without agreement

more likely to have a judiciary branch of government

more likely to have separation between church and state

Example 24 - Question 1

easy

S1: Absolutism, which was particularly widespread during the 17th and 18th centuries in Europe, is a governmental system involving unlimited authority vested in a monarch or dictator. S2: King Louis XIV (1643-1715) of France captured the essence of absolutism when he said, “I am the state.” S3: Many absolutist monarchs sought to provide justification for their absolute power by using the doctrine of the “divine right of kings” and broadened their power by becoming heads of church as well as state. S4: Additionally, influential political and philosophical theorists, including Thomas Hobbes, have argued that unquestioned obedience to a single will is necessary to maintain order and security.

S5: Absolutism stands in stark contrast to constitutionalism, in which a written constitution defines legal limitations on government, a measure that serves to reduce the risk of rulers’ pursuing their own interests at the expense of those of the ruled. S6: Whereas absolutism allows the monarch to make arbitrary judgments in any situation, under constitutionalism, no one is above the rule of law: judges make decisions based on prewritten laws as well as the precedent of earlier judgments. S7: John Locke, an influential political theorist who supported this foundational principle of constitutionalism, argued that “wherever law ends, tyranny begins.” S8: Additionally, unlike absolutism, constitutionalism limits the dominance of a state’s leader by requiring a balance of powers; although abuses of power can still sometimes occur, no one is legally permitted to rule without the agreement of at least one other individual or body, such as the legislative or judiciary branch of government.

QUESTION
Showing:
Question

It can be inferred from the passage that a government following the principles of constitutionalism would be less likely to experience abuse of power by a leader than an absolutist government would because constitutionalism is

more likely to receive support from influential political theorists

less likely to put emphasis on order and security

less likely to permit rule without agreement

more likely to have a judiciary branch of government

more likely to have separation between church and state
Previous Confirm Finish
Show solution Hide solution
PRESENTED BY :
Scott Woodbury-Stewart Founder and Expert GMAT Instructor Scott Woodbury-Stewart Founder and Expert GMAT Instructor

Text Solution:

Each of the answer choices in this question expresses a comparison. However, most of the choices are incorrect because the comparisons they express are not supported by the passage.

It would be easy to believe that the comparisons the incorrect choices express are supported by the passage if we were simply to go with our impressions. So, to avoid choosing a Wrong Comparison choice we have to be careful to notice exactly what the passage says and doesn’t say.

(A) more likely to receive support from influential political theorists

Trap: Wrong Comparison

The passage does indicate, in S4, that political theorists have supported absolutism and, in S7, that the political theorist John Locke supported constitutionalism. However, the passage does not indicate how likely it is that political theorists support either of the two forms of government. So, the passage provides no basis for the comparison expressed by this choice.

Furthermore, even if the passage did support this choice, this choice still wouldn’t correctly answer the question, because the passage does not indicate that support from political theorists causes a government to be “less likely to experience abuse of power by a leader.”

(B) less likely to put emphasis on order and security

Trap: Wrong Comparison

If you chose this choice, you may have noticed that S4 says in connection with absolutism, “Additionally, influential political and philosophical theorists … have argued that unquestioned obedience to a single will is necessary to maintain order and security.” So, the passage does make a connection between absolutism and “order and security.”

Notice, however, that the comparison expressed by this choice is not supported, because the passage does not say how likely it is that a constitutionalist government or an absolutist government puts emphasis on order and security. So, the passage provides no basis for a comparison of the likelihood that a constitutionalist government puts emphasis on order and security with the likelihood that an absolutist government does.

CORRECT ANSWER(C) less likely to permit rule without agreement

Scanning the passage for “rule without agreement,” we see that S8 says, “unlike absolutism, constitutionalism limits the dominance of a state’s leader by requiring a balance of powers; although abuses of power can still sometimes occur, no one is legally permitted to rule without the agreement of at least one other individual or body.”

So, we can see that the passage indicates that constitutionalism is “unlike absolutism” in that, under constitutionalism “no one is legally permitted to rule without the agreement of at least one other individual or body.” So, the comparison expressed by this choice, “constitutionalism is less likely to permit rule without agreement,” is supported by the passage.

Also, by saying, “constitutionalism limits the dominance of a state’s leader by requiring a balance of powers; although abuses of power can still sometimes occur, no one is legally permitted to rule without the agreement …,” the passage implies that the likelihood that abuses of power will occur is reduced under constitutionalism because “no one is legally permitted to rule without … agreement.”

So, this choice both is supported by the passage and answers the question by explaining why “a government following the principles of constitutionalism would be less likely to experience abuse of power by a leader than an absolutist government would.”

(D) more likely to have a judiciary branch of government

Trap: Wrong Comparison

If you chose this choice, you may have noticed that S8 says of constitutionalism, “no one is legally permitted to rule without the agreement of at least one other individual or body, such as the … judiciary branch of government.” So, the passage indicates that a constitutionalist government may have a judiciary branch.

Notice, however, that the comparison expressed by this choice is not supported, because the passage does not say how likely it is that an absolutist government has a judiciary branch. So, the passage does not provide a basis for a comparison of the likelihood that a constitutionalist government has a judiciary branch with the likelihood that an absolutist government does.

You may have gotten the impression that the passage indicates that an absolutist government is unlikely to have a judiciary branch, but the passage doesn’t do so.

We have to be careful to base our choices on what the passage actually says rather than go with our impressions.

(E) more likely to have separation between church and state

Trap: Wrong Comparison

If you chose this choice, you may have noticed that S3 says of absolutism, “Many absolutist monarchs … broadened their power by becoming heads of church as well as state.” So, the passage indicates that an absolutist government may not have separation between church and state.

Notice, however, that the comparison expressed by this choice is not supported, because the passage does not say how likely it is that a constitutionalist government has separation between church and state. So, the passage does not provide a basis for a comparison of the likelihood that a constitutionalist government has separation between church and state with the likelihood that an absolutist government does.

Correct answer: C

topics.topicName: 3.30 Inference Trap 9: Mix-Up
topics.content:
3. Detail, Inference, Application, Assumption, Weaken and Strengthen

3.30 Inference Trap 9: Mix-Up

As we’ve seen, a Mix-Up trap choice mixes up different ideas, opinions, methods, or other topics mentioned in a passage, and in Inference questions, Mix-Up choices mix up what can be inferred about one person or thing with what can be inferred about someone or something else.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

Mix-Up trap choices in Inference questions mix up what can be inferred about one person or thing with what can be inferred about someone or something else.

To see how a Mix-Up trap choice in an Inference question can work, let’s say that a passage says the following:

While some historians claim that the sea peoples were chased from their cities by attackers, Peczynski argues that the sea peoples migrated because of damage to their cities by earthquakes. Peczynski points to the fact that lines of columns in the cities were toppled in the same direction as incontrovertible evidence that earthquakes, not attackers, destroyed the cities. However, archeological evidence indicating that numerous wars occurred in the area from which the sea peoples migrated around the time when they appeared in Egypt makes disputing the “attackers” theory difficult.

An Inference question about the passage could the following:

It can be inferred from the passage that Peczynski believes which of the following?

(Mix-Up Choice) It would be easier to dispute the “attackers” theory if there were no archeological evidence indicating that numerous wars occurred in the area from which the sea peoples migrated.

(Correct Answer) Attackers would not have toppled lines of columns in the same direction.

The focus of this Inference question is on what Peczynski believes. So, the correct answer must be an inference supported by the passage regarding what Peczynski believes.

So, notice the issue with the Mix-Up choice. The Mix-Up choice is based on the last sentence of the paragraph, “However, archeological evidence …,” and that sentence does not express what Peczynski believes. It expresses what the author believes. After all, if Peczynski “argues that the sea peoples migrated because of damage to their cities by earthquakes,” and “points to … incontrovertible evidence that earthquakes, not attackers, destroyed the cities,” then clearly it must be the author, not Peczynski, who believes that disputing the “attackers” theory is “difficult.”

Thus, the Mix-Up choice is an inference about the wrong opinion, the author’s opinion, not the opinion the question is about, Peczynski’s opinion.

The correct answer, on the other hand, is an inference about what Peczynski believes. After all, the statement “Peczynski points to the fact that lines of columns in the cities were toppled in the same direction as incontrovertible evidence that earthquakes, not attackers, destroyed the cities,” indicates that Peczynski believes that “Attackers would not have toppled lines of columns in the same direction.”

This example illustrates what we have to do to avoid choosing a Mix-Up trap in an Inference question. When we see that a passage discusses multiple ideas, opinions, methods, or other topics, we have to be careful to keep them straight, and we have to be careful not to mix up the author’s opinion with the opinions of people mentioned in the passage.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

To avoid choosing a Mix-Up trap in an Inference question, when we see that a passage discusses multiple ideas, opinions, methods, or other topics, we have to be careful to keep them straight, and we have to be careful not to mix up the author’s opinion with the opinions of people mentioned in the passage.

Consider the following example.

Example 25

S1: GDP – calculated as the total market value of all final goods and services produced during a specific time period – has long been used as an indicator of national development and progress. S2: However, critics of this use of GDP contend that GDP is an overly simple measure that neither effectively captures key aspects of human progress nor takes into account negative effects of economic development. S3: Accordingly, these critics have proposed the adoption of alternative measures, two of which are Gross National Happiness (GNH) and Genuine Progress Indicator (GPI).

S4: GNH, developed in Bhutan, is calculated by means of a questionnaire presented to a random sample composed of 8,000 of Bhutan’s citizens. S5: The process involved in calculating GNH is remarkably thorough, with each citizen answering 148 questions on a variety of quality of life-related topics. S6: However, no country other than Bhutan has adopted GNH, in part because of the time and expense required for interviewing a number of citizens sufficient for generating the data required for accurately calculating GNH. S7: A country’s GPI, on the other hand, can be calculated via the use of data that is already widely available. S8: In fact, GPI is in part based on information similar to that used in calculating GDP and differs from GDP mainly in that it is based on not only information on aggregate production but also information on negatives associated with economic growth, such as loss of leisure time and the cost of deterioration of nature and natural resources.

The author implies that a potential advantage of using the measure GPI is

the thoroughness of the process used in calculating it

its simplicity in comparison to two other popular measures

its reliance on only information on aggregate production

its inclusion of effects of economic development other than positive ones

its demonstrated success in measuring quality of life in Bhutan

Example 25 - Question 1

easy

S1: GDP – calculated as the total market value of all final goods and services produced during a specific time period – has long been used as an indicator of national development and progress. S2: However, critics of this use of GDP contend that GDP is an overly simple measure that neither effectively captures key aspects of human progress nor takes into account negative effects of economic development. S3: Accordingly, these critics have proposed the adoption of alternative measures, two of which are Gross National Happiness (GNH) and Genuine Progress Indicator (GPI).

S4: GNH, developed in Bhutan, is calculated by means of a questionnaire presented to a random sample composed of 8,000 of Bhutan’s citizens. S5: The process involved in calculating GNH is remarkably thorough, with each citizen answering 148 questions on a variety of quality of life-related topics. S6: However, no country other than Bhutan has adopted GNH, in part because of the time and expense required for interviewing a number of citizens sufficient for generating the data required for accurately calculating GNH. S7: A country’s GPI, on the other hand, can be calculated via the use of data that is already widely available. S8: In fact, GPI is in part based on information similar to that used in calculating GDP and differs from GDP mainly in that it is based on not only information on aggregate production but also information on negatives associated with economic growth, such as loss of leisure time and the cost of deterioration of nature and natural resources.

QUESTION
Showing:
Question

The author implies that a potential advantage of using the measure GPI is

the thoroughness of the process used in calculating it

its simplicity in comparison to two other popular measures

its reliance on only information on aggregate production

its inclusion of effects of economic development other than positive ones

its demonstrated success in measuring quality of life in Bhutan
Previous Confirm Finish
Show solution Hide solution
PRESENTED BY :
Scott Woodbury-Stewart Founder and Expert GMAT Instructor Scott Woodbury-Stewart Founder and Expert GMAT Instructor

Text Solution:

The correct answer to this Inference question will describe what the passage implies is a “a potential advantage of using the measure GPI.”

A challenge of answering this question is that the passage mentions three measures, GDP, GNH, and GPI, all of which are measures of economic development and progress and all of which have names that start with the letter G. So, we have to be careful to choose a choice about a potential advantage of using GPI, rather than a choice about a potential advantage of using one of the other two measures.

Scanning the passage, we see that the part that discusses GPI is S7 and S8 at the end of the second paragraph. So, the information that supports the correct answer will likely come from this area of the passage, since information from another area of the passage will likely be about one of the other measures, rather than about GPI.

(A) the thoroughness of the process used in calculating it

Trap: Mix-Up

The only part of the passage that mentions “thoroughness of the process” is S5, which says, “The process of calculating GNH is remarkably thorough.”

Since S5 is about GNH, not GPI, this choice applies to the wrong measure and, therefore, is incorrect.

We have to be careful not to choose a choice that applies to the wrong concept.

(B) its simplicity in comparison to two other popular measures

Trap: Half-Right

This choice could be tempting because it starts off somewhat correctly. After all, the passage says, in S7, “A country’s GPI, on the other hand, can be calculated via the use of data that is already widely available.” In saying that, the passage implies that GPI has an advantage over GNH, in that GPI is simpler to calculate.

At the same time, implying that GPI is simpler to calculate is not quite the same as implying that GPI itself has “simplicity” that other measures don’t have, and that subtle difference is a yellow flag signaling that this choice is likely incorrect.

In fact, this choice goes wrong partway through, because the passage does not imply that GPI is simpler than “two other popular measures.” It implies only that GPI is simpler to calculate than one other measure, GNH, and never says that GPI is simpler than the other popular measure mentioned, GDP.

(C) its reliance on only information on aggregate production

Trap: Mix-Up

Scanning the part of the passage that discusses GPI, we see that it does mention “information on aggregate production.”

However, it mentions “information on aggregate production” in the context of saying, “GPI … differs from GDP mainly in that it is based on not only information on aggregate production but also information on negatives associated with economic growth.”

So, we can see that the passage indicates that GPI is based on more than “information on aggregate production”; GPI is based also on “information on negatives.” In other words, unlike this choice, the passage indicates that GPI does NOT rely “on only information on aggregate production.”

In fact, in saying that GPI “differs from GDP” in that GPI is based on more than “information on aggregate production,” the passage implies that GDP is based on “only information on aggregate production.”

So, this choice applies to GDP, not GPI.

CORRECT ANSWER(D) its inclusion of effects of economic development other than positive ones

Scanning the part of the passage that discusses GPI (S7 and S8), we see that it says, “GPI … differs from GDP mainly in that it is based on not only information on aggregate production but also information on negatives associated with economic growth.”

We can see that, in saying that GPI is based also on “information on negatives,” the passage indicates that GPI includes “effects of economic development other than positive ones.” Thus, this choice accurately describes a characteristic of GPI.

Also, the passage indicates that “critics” have issue with the fact that GDP does not take into account “negative effects of economic development.” So, what the passage says overall implies that GPI’s “inclusion of effects of economic development other than positive ones” is a potential advantage of GPI over GDP.

(E) its demonstrated success in measuring quality of life in Bhutan

Trap: Mix-Up

The only part of the passage that mentions “quality of life in Bhutan” is the first two sentences of the second paragraph, which discuss GNH as it is used in Bhutan and mention “questions on a variety of quality of life-related topics.”

Since quality of life in Bhutan is mentioned only in the context of GNH, and not in the context of GPI, this choice is incorrect because it applies to only to GNH, not GPI.

We have to be careful not to choose a choice that applies to the wrong concept.

Correct answer: D
Frequently Asked Questions

Let’s now wrap up our discussion of Inference questions by discussing Inference “EXCEPT” or “LEAST” questions.

topics.topicName: 3.31 Inference “EXCEPT” or “LEAST” Questions
topics.content:
3. Detail, Inference, Application, Assumption, Weaken and Strengthen

3.31 Inference “EXCEPT” or “LEAST” Questions

Inference questions will sometimes include the word “EXCEPT,” or “LEAST in their stems. For example, here are some Inference stems that include “EXCEPT” or “LEAST”:

It can be inferred from the passage that all of the following could be accomplished through improving access to the internet EXCEPT:

The author implies that all of the following benefit penguins EXCEPT:

The passage LEAST supports the inference that a city can become healthier as a result of

When an Inference question has the word “EXCEPT” or “LEAST” in the stem, four out of the five answer choices will be supported by the passage. These answer choices will be incorrect.

The correct answer will be the one choice that is not supported by the passage.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

When an Inference question has the word “EXCEPT” or “LEAST” in the stem, four out of the five answer choices will be supported by the passage. These answer choices will be incorrect. The correct answer will be the one choice that is not supported by the passage.

Since an Inference “EXCEPT” or “LEAST” question asks us to do the opposite of what we normally do in answering a Inference question, in answering such a question, we have to keep in mind that it’s an Inference “EXCEPT” or “LEAST” question and be extra careful not to fall into our normal habit of choosing a choice that is supported by the passage.

Consider the following example.

Example 26

S1: Master farmers and ethical growers, Native Americans indigenous to what is now the United States and Canada demonstrated not only unwavering appreciation of and respect for the plants that they used for sustenance and profit but also an array of sophisticated agricultural techniques that are still widely studied and used in farming today.

S2: Embracing the concept of perennial cultivation, Native Americans ensured that plants were utilized without being killed. S3: For example, they regularly harvested wood and bark from many species of tree, all while taking care to ensure that in doing so, they kept trees alive; from each tree, they took an amount of wood and bark such that the tree would continue to thrive. S4: The trees from which these resources were taken were referred to as “begged from trees” by the natives because they believed that they came to beg for a piece of the tree.

S5: Also used by these indigenous peoples was a technique called intercropping, in which, by planting multiple crops together, they forged a synergy such that characteristics of each plant improved the growth and health of all plants intercropped, all while reducing farming-associated land damage. S6: For example, it was common for the Iroquois to synergistically plant corn, beans, and squash together using a technique known as the “Three Sisters.” S7: The corn provided tall stalks for the beans to climb, the beans not only provided nitrogen, fertilizing the soil, but also stabilized the corn, preventing it from being damaged during heavy winds, and the broad leaves of the squash plants provided ground shade, which both reduced water loss from the soil and prevented weed growth.

S8: Creek Indians, who settled in what is present-day New York, utilized diluted human urine, which contains a wide assortment of minerals essential to plant-growth, including nitrogen and phosphorus, to fertilize their crops. S9: Such a resourceful practice resulted in reduced need for human-generated waste dumps, which in addition to being unsightly and odorous, can damage soil. S10: This practice also allowed crops to grow larger and hardier than they would have without nitrogenous fertilization.

The passage suggests that the use of Three Sisters technique results in each of the following EXCEPT:

an increase in growth of crops

a decrease in damage to farmland

a reduction in the likelihood that heavy winds would cause damage to certain plants

an improvement in the health of plants on a farm

squash plants’ having broad leaves

Example 26 - Question 1

easy

S1: Master farmers and ethical growers, Native Americans indigenous to what is now the United States and Canada demonstrated not only unwavering appreciation of and respect for the plants that they used for sustenance and profit but also an array of sophisticated agricultural techniques that are still widely studied and used in farming today.

S2: Embracing the concept of perennial cultivation, Native Americans ensured that plants were utilized without being killed. S3: For example, they regularly harvested wood and bark from many species of tree, all while taking care to ensure that in doing so, they kept trees alive; from each tree, they took an amount of wood and bark such that the tree would continue to thrive. S4: The trees from which these resources were taken were referred to as “begged from trees” by the natives because they believed that they came to beg for a piece of the tree.

S5: Also used by these indigenous peoples was a technique called intercropping, in which, by planting multiple crops together, they forged a synergy such that characteristics of each plant improved the growth and health of all plants intercropped, all while reducing farming-associated land damage. S6: For example, it was common for the Iroquois to synergistically plant corn, beans, and squash together using a technique known as the “Three Sisters.” S7: The corn provided tall stalks for the beans to climb, the beans not only provided nitrogen, fertilizing the soil, but also stabilized the corn, preventing it from being damaged during heavy winds, and the broad leaves of the squash plants provided ground shade, which both reduced water loss from the soil and prevented weed growth.

S8: Creek Indians, who settled in what is present-day New York, utilized diluted human urine, which contains a wide assortment of minerals essential to plant-growth, including nitrogen and phosphorus, to fertilize their crops. S9: Such a resourceful practice resulted in reduced need for human-generated waste dumps, which in addition to being unsightly and odorous, can damage soil. S10: This practice also allowed crops to grow larger and hardier than they would have without nitrogenous fertilization.

QUESTION
Showing:
Question

The passage suggests that the use of Three Sisters technique results in each of the following EXCEPT:

an increase in growth of crops

a decrease in damage to farmland

a reduction in the likelihood that heavy winds would cause damage to certain plants

an improvement in the health of plants on a farm

squash plants’ having broad leaves
Previous Confirm Finish
Show solution Hide solution
PRESENTED BY :
Scott Woodbury-Stewart Founder and Expert GMAT Instructor Scott Woodbury-Stewart Founder and Expert GMAT Instructor

Text Solution:

This question is focused on the Three Sisters technique. So, to find the information we need in the passage, we can look for the keywords “Three Sisters,” which appear only in the 3rd paragraph.

We see that the Three Sisters technique is discussed in S6, which begins with the look above marker “For example.” Looking above S6, we see that S5 is about “a technique called intercropping.” So, we can see that the Three Sisters technique is an example of intercropping. Thus, all the information on intercropping and on the Three Sisters technique applies to this question.

Now, since this question is an Inference “EXCEPT” question, we will eliminate four choices that ARE supported by the passage. The remaining choice, the one NOT supported by the passage, will be the correct answer.

(A) an increase in growth of crops

As we discussed in the introduction to this explanation, the passage indicates that the Three Sisters technique is an example of intercropping.

Thus, since S5 says that, in intercropping, “characteristics of each plant improved the growth … of all plants intercropped,” we can infer that the use of Three Sisters technique, an example of intercropping, results in “an increase in growth of crops.”

Supported by the passage? Yes.

(B) a decrease in damage to farmland

As we discussed in the introduction to this explanation, the passage indicates that the Three Sisters technique is an example of intercropping.

Thus, since S5 says that, in intercropping, indigenous peoples reduced “farming-associated land damage,” we can infer that the use of Three Sisters technique, an example of intercropping, results in “a decrease in damage to farmland.”

Supported by the passage? Yes.

(C) a reduction in the likelihood that heavy winds would cause damage to certain plants

Scanning the 3rd paragraph, we see that it says that the beans planted by Iroquois who used the Three Sisters technique “stabilized the corn, preventing it from being damaged during heavy winds.”

“Corn” in the passage is synonymous with “certain plants” in this choice. So, the information in the passage supports this choice.

Supported by the passage? Yes

(D) an improvement in the health of plants on a farm

As we discussed in the introduction to this explanation, the passage indicates that the Three Sisters technique is an example of intercropping.

Thus, since S5 says that, in intercropping, “characteristics of each plant improved the … health of all plants intercropped,” we can infer that the use of Three Sisters technique, an example of intercropping, results in “an improvement in the health of plants on a farm.”

Supported by the passage? Yes.

CORRECT ANSWER(E) squash plants’ having broad leaves

Scanning the 3rd paragraph for the keywords “squash plants” and “broad leaves” we see that the only place “broad leaves of the squash plants” are mentioned is in S7, which says, “the broad leaves of the squash plants provided ground shade.”

Then, by reviewing S7 and S6, we can see that the passage does not imply that the leaves’ being “broad” is a result of the Three Sisters method. Rather, the passage implies that broad leaves are a feature of squash plants that helps make the Three Sisters method work.

So, this choice is not supported by the passage and thus is the correct answer to this Inference “Except” question.

Supported by the passage? No.

Correct answer: E
Frequently Asked Questions

Let’s now discuss Application questions.

topics.topicName: 3.32 Application Questions
topics.content:
3. Detail, Inference, Application, Assumption, Weaken and Strengthen

3.32 Application Questions

Application questions ask us to apply information from the passage in a context outside of what the passage discusses.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

Application questions ask us to apply information from the passage in a context outside of the passage.

In answering an application question, our job will be to identify an example that is analogous to something in the passage, to determine the opinion of the author or another person about something not mentioned in the passage, or to make some other kind of connection between what the passage says and something outside the context of the passage.

In other words, the correct answer to an Application question will be about something outside of the passage that is related to the passage in a particular way.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

The correct answer to an Application question will be about something outside of the passage that is related to the passage in a particular way.

For example, let’s say a passage describes a relationship between two organisms; an application question might ask us to identify the answer choice that presents a similar relationship that has nothing to do with organisms, maybe a relationship within an economic system or between parts of a machine. So, our ability to grasp relationships, make connections, and understand the author’s opinions, sentiments, and motivations will help us answer application questions.

Here are some examples of the types of questions stems that appear in Application questions:

Which of the following is the best example of folk art as it is defined in the passage?

Which of the following most clearly represents an instance of the butterfly effect as it is described in the passage?

Which of the following would be most consistent with the practice of stoicism as it is described in the passage?

Of the following experiments, which of them would be most likely to be performed by a researcher in the field of landscape limnology as it is described in the passage?

The counseling mentioned in highlighted text in the passage would be most beneficial to a person experiencing which of the following?

The relationship between hummingbirds and flowers described by the passage is most similar to which of the following?

The passage suggests that Vernadsky would probably have objected most strongly to which of the following proposals?

Be sure that you’re ready to quickly recognize Application questions.

Must Know:
Toggle bookmark

Learn to recognize the common and predictable language used by Application questions in Reading Comprehension.

Let’s now discuss a strategy for correctly answering Application questions.
